Whereas under PEF Act, the principal employer is statutorily liable in terms of the provisions of the Act to comply with the provisions therein; in terms of ESI Act, the principal employer is entitled to recover the amount of contribution payable by the immediate employer for them. S.45-A ESI Act enables the appropriate authority to recover such dues both from
HeadNote.description:
Provisions compared and analysed.

The purport and object of both the statutes, for all intent and purport, is the same. In the proceedings initiated under S.45-A of ESI Act, an immediate employer or principal employer may also show that they are not liable to deposit any contribution on behalf of the employees as the establishment in question did not come within the purview thereof. The purpose of the proceedings, under both the Acts is to determine the amount due from any employer in respect of the employees under the statutory schemes. Both the Acts envisage compliance of principles of natural justice. The proviso to S.45-A of ESI Act provides for a statutory mandate of giving a reasonable opportunity of being heard. The quantum of amount due has to be determined in respect of all contract workers engaged by the contractors. The principal employer would be entitled to recover the contributions from the contractor; they being the immediate employers. Whereas under PEF Act, the principal employer is statutorily liable in terms of the provisions of the Act to comply with the provisions therein; in terms of ESI Act, the principal employer is entitled to recover the amount of contribution payable by the immediate employer for them. S.45-A ESI Act enables the appropriate authority to recover such dues both from - principal as also the immediate employer. It provides for an opportunity of hearing to both of them.			 [Para 12,14]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Writ petition against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Order of assessment of unpaid PF contributions - Writ petition against - Maintainability - Statutory remedy of appeal available u/S.7-I r.w. S. 7-O - Held, in an appropriate case where bonafides of employer are visible and in order to ensure that ends of justice are met, a petition could be entertained without exhausting the statutory remedy of appeal.	(Para 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Writ petition against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Writ petition against - Maintainability - Statutory remedy of appeal available u/S.7-I r.w. S. 7-O - Petitioner however filed writ petition - By impugned order authority seeks to recover Rs.32.28 crore approx. out of which Rs.5 crore deposited by petitioner - Yet outstanding amount would be Rs.27.09 crore - Held, grievance of petitioner can be entertained if he inclines to deposit some amounts in the court as expected u/S. 7-I r.w. S.7-O of EPF Act - Object of filing petition directly in High Court should not be to avoid 75% deposit mandated by EPF Act - Petitioner not inclined to deposit the same - Hence, petition dismissed. (Paras 19, 20, 21, 23)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Establishment rendering expert services
HeadNote.description: Establishment rendering expert services - Whether, covered under EPF Act - Notification dated 17th May, 1971 issued to include all "establishments rendering expert services" under EPF Act - However, another Notification dated 29th May, 1971 issued clarifying that only those establishments rendering expert services and employing twenty or more persons, are covered under EPF Act - Therefore, establishment though rendering expert services if not satisfied said condition is not covered under EPF Act. 	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Establishment rendering expert services
HeadNote.description: Establishment rendering expert services - Interpretation of Notification dated 29th May, 1971 - Establishments mentioned in Notification after words "such as" - Are merely illustrative and not exhaustive - If intention of Govt. was to include all establishments rendering expert services, then there would be no need to issue said Notification.	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Winding up proceedings
Duty of liquidator
HeadNote.description:
Winding up proceedings - Claim of provident fund - Duty of liquidator - If Provident Fund is maintained by company, then liquidator cannot deny his liability to pay sums accumulated in the same - Liquidator must follow the matter with the Provident Fund Authorities and see to it that the amounts due and payable are deposited with him and ultimately paid to the workmen.

As far as Provident Fund is concerned, if that fund is maintained by the company, then the liquidator cannot deny his liability to pay sums accumulated in the same.  In other words, it is workmens' dues and it is the duty of the liquidator to move the Provident Fund authorities if the fund is transferred to them for management and administration and assist the workmen in recovery of all contributions.  The liquidator cannot leave the matter to the workmen or the applicant in this case.  Even if the Provident Fund Commissioner has not moved any application in the prescribed form, the liquidator in the facts and circumstances of this case, must follow up the matter with the Provident Fund authorities and see to it that the amounts due and payable are deposited with him and ultimately paid to the workmen. To enable the liquidator to move the Provident Fund Authorities, he is at liberty to seek such directions as are necessary from the Court.					 [Para 36,37]

Under the term "workmen's dues" what is covered is the sums due from a Provident Fund or the pension fund or any other fund for the welfare of the workers maintained by the company.  The sums due from this fund may be the contributions of both employer and employee, accumulated therein.  That means accumulated till the date the winding up order is passed.  The liquidator cannot be expected to make good any short fall or deficit because he is not an employer, as is understood by the applicant herein.  In other words, when the Provident Fund Act mandates creation of a fund consisting of deductions and contributions from employer-employees, it can never be the intention that a person like Liquidator is obliged to forward any contribution from the funds collected by him after disposal of the assets and properties of the company in liquidation.  As has been explained above, the argument is misconceived because if the liquidator is not the employer, then merely because he steps in after a winding-up order is made, does not mean that after he has stepped in he should go on contributing to the Provident Fund on the basis that the relationship between the company in liquidation and the employee subsists or continues in law.  The Liquidator cannot be expected to deposit any monies in such funds. He has to utilise the monies realised from sale and disposal of the assets and properties of the company in liquidation in the manner directed by company law.  It was never intended therein that he should deposit any sums in the funds. All that can be expected from the Liquidator is to assist the workmen in realising the sums due to them from the Provident Fund and that expectation will have to be fulfilled by the Liquidator.  That he fulfils such an expectation of the applicant and other employees, is something which has been achieved by court's directions issued to him. In these circumstances, the request to direct the Liquidator to make contribution of employer's share to the Provident Fund Authorities for the relevant period, cannot be granted. AIR 1960 Cal. 19 - Ref. to.   [Para 39]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Appeal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Maintainability - Impugned order charging interest on belated payment of provident fund - Order passed in exercise of power u/s.7Q is an independent action and not a composite order passed u/Ss.7A and 7Q together - Appeal not maintainable against such order. 		(Paras 18, 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Levy of interest
HeadNote.description: Levy of interest - Exercise of power u/s.7Q - Applicability of principles of natural justice - Held, levy of interest is only an arithmetical calculation - Yet there can be errors with regard to period and calculation - Therefore, when a demand is raised by independent order u/s.7Q, affected person should have right to file an objection with regard to computation but in a limited spectrum.	(Paras 24, 28)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Appeal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Maintainability - Right of appeal cannot be assumed to exist unless expressly provided for by the statute - Remedy of appeal must be legitimately traceable to the statutory provisions - An appeal for its maintainability must have clear authority of law.	(Para 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Amount due from employer
HeadNote.description:
Amount due from employer - Sugar bags i.e. goods pledged with bank by employer, sugar will continue to be assets of establishment for purpose of S.11(2) - Hence, they could be attached and sold by Recovery officer in terms of S.8-B.

The sugar bags pledged with the appellant-bank constituted assets of the establishment for the purpose of Section 11(2) of the Act. The deeds of pledge executed by the management of the Sugar Mills as security for repayment of loan etc. did not have the effect of transferring of the ownership of the sugar bags to the appellant-bank and the Recovery Officer did not commit any illegality by attaching the same and the High Court was fully justified in directing payment of a portion of the sale price to the Assistant Commissioner for being appropriated towards the provident fund dues of the workers. Thus, even though symbolic custody of the sugar bags was given to the appellant-bank as security for repayment of loan etc., the Sugar Mills continued to be owner thereof. In other words, the sugar bags pledged with the appellant-bank continued to be movable property i.e. assets of the establishment, which could be attached and sold by the Recovery Officer in terms of Section 8-B or by adopting alternative modes of recovery enumerated in Section 8-F.						 [Para 36,40,43]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Interest and damages
HeadNote.description:
Interest and damages - Can be treated as first charge on assets of establishment.

Interest payable in terms of Section 7-Q and damages imposed under Section 14-B of the Act can be treated as first charge on the assets of the establishment payable in priority to all other debts within the meaning of Section 11(2). Hence, it cannot be said that the amount of interest payable under Section 7-Q and damages leviable under Section 14-B do not form part of the amount due from an employer for the purpose of Section 11(2) of the Act. The expression "any amount due from an employer" appearing in sub-section (2) of Section 11 has to be interpreted keeping in view the object of the Act and other provisions contained therein including sub-section (1) of Section 11 and Sections 7-A, 7-Q, 14-B and 15(2) which provide for determination of the dues payable by the employer, liability of the employer to pay interest in case the payment of the amount due is delayed and also pay damages, if there is default in making contribution to the Fund. If any amount payable by the employer becomes due and the same is not paid within the stipulated time, then the employer is required to pay interest in terms of the mandate of Section 7-Q. Likewise, default on the employer's part to pay any contribution to the Fund can visit him with the consequence of levy of damages. There is no plausible reason to give a restricted meaning to the expression 'any amount due from the employer' and confine it to the amount determined under Section 7-A or the contribution payable under Section 8. If interest payable by the employer under Section 7-Q and damages leviable under Section 14 are excluded from the ambit of expression "any amount due from an employer", every employer will conveniently refrain from paying contribution to the Fund and other dues and resist the efforts of the concerned authorities to recover the dues as arrears of land revenue by contending that the movable or immovable property of the establishment is subject to other debts. Any such interpretation would frustrate the object of introducing the deeming provision and non obstante clause in Section 11(2).   [Para 46,47]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Establishment whether covered by the Act
HeadNote.description: Establishment whether covered by the Act - Show cause notice must be given with clean details to enable proper reply - Earlier establishment was treated as "Expert Services" and show cause notice was served - Establishment was thereafter treated as "Health club" but show cause notice was not changed - Department directed to issue fresh notice with necessary details. 	(Paras 8, 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Establishment whether covered by the Act - Burden of proof - Petitioner placing on record documents to prove its case that there were only 12 employees working in the establishment - Burden shifts on Department to prove its case that there were more than twenty employees working in the establishment - Mere presence of more than 20 persons is not sufficient, they must be employees of the establishment.	(Paras 9, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Word "owner" or "occupier"
HeadNote.description: Word "owner" or "occupier" - Has to be used disjunctively - Cases wherein owner of factory is company, it is the company which is principal employer and not a director.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Recovery of
HeadNote.description: Arrears of Provident Fund Contribution payable by owner - Recovery of - Cannot be made by attaching and confiscating personal property of Managing Director of Company.		(Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Requirement to pass speaking order - Order of affirmation need not contain elaborate reasons as order of reversal - Only requirement, in case the appellate authority affirms the order of lower authority, is to make independent assessment and record brief reasons to reflect application of mind - Further, giving of same reasons cannot mean that there is no independent assessment of material on record - When an order is affirmed, there bound to occur reproduction. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Inquiry by Commissioner
HeadNote.description: Inquiry by Commissioner - Direction for payment of contribution by principal employer - Upon failure of contractor to make such payment - Challenge, on ground that Commissioner did not properly inquire into identity and number of eligible employees - However, impugned order reflects that several opportunities were given to produce relevant material but petitioner provided no information - Contractors were also made parties upon request of petitioner - Commissioner made reasonable efforts to ascertain identity and number of eligible employees and gave sufficient opportunity to petitioner to rebut the evidence produced by Workers' Union - No procedural flaw and no perversity in order of Commissioner. 			(Paras 14 to 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Applicability of Act
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Order that petitioner has appointed more than 20 persons in establishment - Provisions of Act are made applicable to establishment - Petitioner did not produce any record in form of muster roll, salary certificate or any document - Petitioner could not prove that he has employed persons less than 20 - Non-consideration of E.S.I.S. returns and challans has not caused any prejudice to petitioner - Order of Tribunal, upheld. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Applicability of Act
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Petitioner purchasing maida and other articles for manufacture of wafers - Petitioner sells product to wholesalers - Petitioner is covered under notification issued under the Act by Central Government - Contention that sale of goods to wholesalers only should not be considered as sale, cannot be accepted. 			(Paras 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Appeal
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Limitation - Initial order holding petitioner-establishment to be covered under EPF Act was passed on 24th June, 2003 - Not challenged till date - Subsequent order passed on 03.10.2005 only determines amount payable on basis of earlier order - Challenge is to said order after period of four years - Thus, appeal u/S.7A of EPF Act was barred by limitation. 	(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Establishment
HeadNote.description: Establishment - Whether, covered by EPF Act - Inquiry report showed that petitioner-establishment has employed 17 employees in addition to 3 Security Guards - PF Authorities hold establishment to be covered under EPF Act - Challenge on count that Security Guards were employed through independent security agency and therefore, could not have been counted for reckoning statutory requirement of engaging 20 employees for being covered under said Act - Nothing on record to show that Security Guards provided by Security Agency were on principal to principal basis - Also, not established on record that said agency was having independent registration under Act and was paying provident fund contributions of those Security Guards - Hence, said security guards being employees of establishment, establishment covered under the Act.	(Paras 10, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Employee
HeadNote.description: Employee - Security guards engaged in establishment through independent agency - Nothing on record to show that they were engaged on principal to principal basis - Also, not established that said agency was having independent registration under the Act and was paying provident fund contributions of those Security Guards - Hence, Security guards covered u/S.2(f) of EPF Act. 	 (Paras 11, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Grant of exemption
HeadNote.description: Grant of exemption - All exemptions to be granted under S.17 shall be subject to the terms and conditions as given in Appendix-A to the scheme - Appropriate Government will consider whether the condition specified in S.17 are fulfilled. (Para 3)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Damages and interest
Levy of
HeadNote.description: Damages and interest - Levy of - Delay in initiating proceedings for - No limitation prescribed for taking steps to levy interest and impose damages - Said exercise has to be undertaken within reasonable time - Merely delay in initiating action, cannot amount to prejudice - Unless prejudice is caused due to delay, proceedings cannot be vitiated on account of belated initiation. (1998) 2 SCC 242 Rel. on. 2012 II LLJ 681(Mad) Disting. 			(Paras 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Levy of, on delayed payment of contribution - From June 1992 till February 2001 - Plea that S.7Q came into effect on 1.7.1997, employer not liable to pay interest for period prior to 1.7.1997 - In view of Scheme (1952), there was already power to levy damages by way of penalty for delayed payment - Only difference is that instead of damages under para 32A of Scheme, employer is liable to pay interest u/S.7Q of Act - Employer liable to pay interest for period prior to 1.7.1997. AIR 1974 SC 125 Rel. on. 	(Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Damages
Imposition of
HeadNote.description: Damages - Imposition of - While imposing damages, it is expected to take into consideration number of defaults, period of delay, frequency of default and amounts involved - Except stating that late release of grant in aid would not be sufficient ground, there is no other consideration by authority - Power to enforce damages being quasi-judicial in nature, same must be based on sound and objective considerations - This aspect missing in order of authority - Imposition of damages, not proper - Matter remanded for reconsideration. 2006(6) ALL MR 124 Foll. 2007(4) ALL MR 584 Disting. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: PF dues
HeadNote.description: PF dues - In case of winding up of insolvent company - Claim of Provident Fund Commissioner regarding employees contribution - Salaries payable to employees for relevant period have been paid in full, i.e. without deducting any employees' contribution to Fund - These amounts have been directly received by employees in winding up and hence, same are not claimable separately by applicant. 		(Para 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Damages for delay in payment of PF dues
HeadNote.description:
Damages for delay in payment of PF dues - As the company is wound up, damages claimed from Official Liquidator - No adjudication nor even inquiry proposed in matter of determining damages u/S.14B - In absence of adjudication, there is no provable debt as on date of winding up order - Submission that adjudication u/S.14B is merely a matter of calculation, not acceptable - It is actually like a decree or order of damages arrived at after hearing parties and subject to a statutory appeal - Moreover, that jurisdiction rests exclusively with authorities under PF Act - No question of Official Liquidator himself adjudicating damages - Till such adjudication is made, there is no debt provable before Official Liquidator - No case for Official Liquidator awarding any such damages u/ S.14B. 

AIR 1974 SC 1265 Ref.to.	(Paras 6, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Private schools
Initiation of recovery
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Private schools - Default in deposit of provident fund contribution - Initiation of recovery - Exemption from applicability of provisions of Central Act i.e. EPF Act - Entitlement to - Appellant running 29 schools/colleges and receiving 100% grant-in-aid from State Govt. - Around 1151 employees employed by appellant covered by CPF scheme of State Govt. (except 16 part time employees) - Appellant's establishment fulfills twin conditions specified u/S.16(1)(b) of EPF Act - S.16 of EPF Act does not envisage concept of partial exemption - Therefore, merely because 16 employees were not eligible for benefit of State CPF scheme, exemption status granted to appellant u/S.16 of EPF Act, will not cease or stand withdrawn automatically - Appellant entitled to exemption u/S.16 - Initiation of recovery against appellant, held without authority of law. 2007 ALL SCR 766 Rel. on. 			(Paras 23, 25, 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Private schools
HeadNote.description:
Private schools - Default in deposit of provident fund contribution - Question as to whether appellant school is an establishment covered by any one of excepted category specified in S.16 of EPF Act - Discussed.

	In the instant case the question arises is whether the appellant school is an establishment covered by any one of the excepted category specified in Section 16 of the Central Act. The appellant has invoked clause (a) as well as clause (b) of Section 16 (1) of the Central Act. As regards the argument hinging on clause (a), it proceeds on the premise that the appellant's school (in which 16 part-time employees were working), had employed less than fifty persons and working without the aid of power. This argument, cannot come to the aid of the appellant. Inasmuch as, the appellant is running 29 schools/colleges and has employed around 1151 permanent employees. Section 2A of the Central Act predicates that where an establishment consists of different departments or has branches, whether situate in the same place or in different places, all such departments or branches shall be treated as part of the same establishment. In other words, the fact that the appellant has employed less than 50 permanent employees and who are working without the aid of power in the school in which the 16 part-time employees were also working, will not take the matter any further. Appellant has neither pleaded the material facts nor adduced any proof, so as to rebut the presumption stipulated in Section 2A of the Central Act - that all the schools and colleges run by the appellant were part of the same establishment. The fact that the appellant is a Co-operative Society registered under the State Co-operative Societies Act by itself will not extricate the appellant from the application of the Central Act.

	The fact that the appellant is not falling within the ambit of clause (a) of Section 16(1), however, can be no impediment for the appellant to peruse the argument regarding exemption by relying on clause (b) of Section 16(1) thereof. Because, the excepted categories specified in Section 16 are mutually exclusive. They are separated by the word "or". Sub-clause (b) of Section 16(1) is an independent excepted category. It is attracted to any other establishment belonging to or under the control of the Central Government or a State Government "and" whose employees are entitled to the benefits of contributory provident fund or old age pension in accordance with any scheme or rule framed by the Central Government or the State Government governing such benefits. These twin conditions are required to be satisfied by the concerned establishment, seeking exemption from the provisions of the Central Act. In the present case, the employees working in the concerned schools/colleges of the appellant are covered by the contributory provident fund scheme framed by the State Government, subject to eligibility. The second condition required for seeking exemption under the Central Act is thus fulfilled. 				 [Para 18,19]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Educational institutions
HeadNote.description:
Educational institutions - Default in deposit of provident fund contribution - Question as to whether Central Act or State Act will apply - Conjoint reading of S.1 of Central Act with notification dt.19/2/1982 makes it clear that Central Act would apply to all colleges and schools, subject to provisions of S.16 of Central Act.

	On a plain reading of provision of S.1 of EPF Act it is evident that the Central Act applies to the establishments referred to therein. In the present case, the appellant's establishment may fall within the purview of "other establishment" referred to in sub-clause (b) of Section 1(3). It is indisputable that the Central Government in exercise of the powers conferred by clause (b) of sub-Section (3) of Section 1 of the Central Act has published a Notification being No.S.O.-986, dated 19.02.1982 on 06.03.1982, so as to include all the educational institutions in the category of "any other establishment", namely; University; College (Whether or not affiliated to a University); School (Whether or not recognized or aided by the Central or a State Government); any scientific institution; any institution in which research in respect of any matter is carried on; and any other institution in which the activity of imparting knowledge or training is systematically carried on.

	A conjoint reading of Section 1 of the Central Act with the aforesaid notification, makes it clear that the Central Act would apply to all the colleges and schools, subject to the provisions of Section 16 of that Act.			 	 [Para 16,17]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Employers liability to pay employees contribution
HeadNote.description:
Employers liability to pay employees contribution - It would arise only from 1.5.86 and not retrospectively from 1.10.1984.

Though the Cinema theatres employing five or more persons would be liable to pay their own contribution to the provident fund with effect from 1st October, 1984, the date section 24 of the Cine Workers Act came into force, they would not be liable to pay the employees' contribution for the period from 1st October, 1984 to 30th April, 1986. The liability to pay such contribution would arise only from 1st May, 1986.

(1991)3  SCC   119  followed.  [Para 3]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Employee
Definition
HeadNote.description:
Employee - Definition - Expression "in connection with the work of establishment" - Means that there must be nexus between establishment and work of employee - Nexus may be a loose connection.

Any person who is employed for wages in any kind of work, manual or otherwise, in an establishment and who gets his wages directly or indirectly from the employer is an employee.  Similarly, an employee who is employed for wages in any kind of work, manual or otherwise, in connection with the work of an establishment and who gets his wages directly or indirectly from the employer is also an employee.  It would also include any person employed by or through a contractor in or in connection with the work of the establishment.  It would also include any person engaged as an apprentice not being an apprentice engaged under Apprentice Act, 1961 or under the standing orders of establishment. The expression "in connection with the work of establishment" means that there must be some nexus between the establishment and work of the employee, though it may be loose connection.  The work should not be irrelevant for the purposes of establishment.  It is sufficient if it is incidental to it.  It is enough if the employee does some work which has relevance to or link with the establishment.  In other words such work should not be extraneous or contrary to the purpose of the establishment but need not be integral to it either. AIR 1978 SC 1478 Relied on.   [Para 8,9]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Providend Fund
Validity
Proper
HeadNote.description: Providend Fund - Non granting of benefits to contract employees - Validity - Drivers used by Managers of Company - Their wages paid by managers reimbursed by company alongwith overtime and uniforms etc - Finding that drivers are paid directly or indirectly by company and hence were employees under S.2(f) - Proper - They were entitled to benefits of Employees Provident Fund.	(Paras 9, 14)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Grant-in-aid towards contribution of employer in EPF
HeadNote.description: Grant-in-aid towards contribution of employer in EPF - Claim for increase in - Petitioner receiving grants from State Govt. at rate of 8.5% of emoluments of employees as per G.R. of 1970 - Petitioner claiming that employers' contribution u/S. 6 of Act was increased to 12% from 1997 therefore Govt. should also increase grants payable to petitioner - No statutory right exists with petitioner to claim increase in grants payable to petitioner - Govt. under G.R. of 1970 has merely given assurance and Court cannot compel State Govt. to enhance or increase grants payable to petitioner - Claim liable to be rejected.  (Para 3)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Recovery of excess grant-in-aid
HeadNote.description: Recovery of excess grant-in-aid - Paid towards contribution of employer in EPF - Respondent-Govt. sought recovery of Rs.43,43,387/- being excess grant released by it to petitioner - Petitioner gave proposal of repayment of amount in installment of Rs.2 lakhs per month - Respondent did not raise any objection to proposal of petitioner - Petition dismissed with direction to petitioner to pay monthly installment before 10th day of every month.  (Paras 4, 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: "Excluded employee"
HeadNote.description: "Excluded employee" - "Fund" referred to in paras 2(f), 26, 69 - Is "fund" created under scheme of 1952 and reference is not to any other "Fund" - Thus, to be covered under expression "excluded employee" by virtue of para 2(f)(i) r.w. para 69(i)(a), employee must be such who was member of Fund established under scheme of 1952 and who had withdrawn full amount of his accumulations in said fund on retirement from service after attaining age of 55 years - Therefore, retired railway employees who had withdrawn all superannuation benefits including full amount of accumulations in Provident fund accounts - Cannot be treated as "excluded employees" - Such employees on re-employment can be brought within purview of Act and scheme. (Paras 14, 15, 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Payment of contribution
Exemption
HeadNote.description: Payment of contribution - Exemption - There is no concept of any holidaying in payment of contribution by employer by merely moving application for exemption - In absence of order of exemption u/S.17 passed by competent authority, employer liable to make payment of its contribution.	(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Order of damages
HeadNote.description: Order of damages - Power of Provident Fund Commissioner to impose an order of damages - Power arises when employer defaults in payment of any contribution to the fund or in making transfers of accumulations required to be transferred or in the payment of charges payable under the Act, the scheme or under any of the conditions specified in S.17 - The Commissioner is in the eventuality of such a default, empowered to recover from the employer such damages not exceeding the amount of arrears as he may think fit to impose. AIR 1979 SC 1803 - Ref. to.			(Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Power of Provident Fund Commissioner to impose damages u/s.14-B
HeadNote.description:
Power of Provident Fund Commissioner to impose damages u/s.14-B - Power is a judicial power - Nature of the power being quasi-judicial, exercise of the discretion must be for sound and objective considerations.

The power to impose damages under Section 14-B is a judicial power.  Section 14-B does not mandate that an order for damages must follow in the event of every default. Section 14-B confers a discretion upon the Provident Fund Commissioner to impose damages not exceeding the amount of arrears. Within the ceiling that is imposed by the statute the Provident Fund Commissioner has a discretion. The nature of the power being quasi-judicial, the exercise of the discretion must be for sound and objective considerations. Regulation 32-A under which a graded scale for imposition of damages has been provided cannot be regarded as a rigid or inflexible prescription. The Regulations cannot fetter the exercise of the power which is conferred upon the Provident Fund Commissioner by the provisions of the enactment, but guide and channelize the exercise of discretion. Similarly, Regulation 32-B structures the exercise of the discretion to reduce or waive the imposition of damages. Neither Regulation 32-A nor Regulation 32-B can be regarded as inflexible.						 [Para 10]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Penal Code (1860), S.77
HeadNote.description:
Penal Code (1860), S.77 - Officer who passes an order under S.7A  of EPF & MP Act - Is entitled to get protection as envisaged under S.77 of IPC and S.3(1) of the Judges (Protection) Act. 

2009 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 80 Ref. to. 			(Paras 21, 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Execution of
HeadNote.description:
Order passed by Regional Provident Fund Commissioner - Execution of - Such an order attains finality and can be executed against the employer by following the procedure which is similar to the procedure of execution of a decree and it also entails penal consequences.

2012 ALL MR (Cri) 359 (S.C.)  Ref. to. 			(Para 41)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Exemption u/S.16(1)(a)
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Applicability of EPF Act - Exemption u/S.16(1)(a) - Petitioner-educational institution is employing less than 50 persons who work without aid of power - Single Judge held that even if electricity or power is used for lighting, cooling or heating, work of teaching is with aid of power - Not proper - Held, since Act is piece of beneficial and social welfare legislation, it must be interpreted liberally - Use of electricity must necessarily have direct or proximate nexus with work - Imparting of education with aid of electronic gadgets like computers, projectors or like, may possibly imply that working is with aid of power - But, if use of power is only to operate tube-lights or fans, it shall not imply that imparting of education is with aid of power - Order of Single Judge set aside.  2016(150) FLR 163, 1988 LAB IC 302, 1993 (2) LLJ 394, 1979 ALLMR ONLINE 389, 1981 ALLMR ONLINE 81 (S.C.) Ref. to.  2003 I CLR 233 Disting. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Interpretation
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Expression "with aid of power" - Interpretation - Single Judge interpreted said expression that only establishments to which there is no power supply are exempted - Not proper - Act being piece of beneficial and social welfare legislation must be interpreted liberally - That narrow, technical or pedantic interpretation which may frustrate legislative object and intent, must be avoided - Expression "with aid of power" must receive purposive interpretation to ensure that legislative object and intent as advanced rather than diluted or nullified - Use of power/electricity must necessarily have direct or proximate nexus with work - Some activity or process integral to working must be aided with power for an establishment be termed as working with aid of power. 			(Paras 14, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Exemption u/S.16(1)(b)
HeadNote.description: Applicability of EPF Act - Exemption u/S.16(1)(b) - Petitioner-society is educational institution employing less than 50 person who works without aid of power at relevant time - During pendency of dispute, State Government has extended grant-in-aid to institution - On that basis society may demonstrate that in view of such grant-in-aid society shall continue to be exempted - In case of any subsequent change like increase in strength of employees, authority is at liberty to take appropriate decision on applicability of Act to society. 	(Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Interpretation of words 'belonging to' and 'under the control of'
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of words 'belonging to' and 'under the control of' - Two words have different connotations - 'Belonging to' signifies ownership - 'Under the control of' signifies control other than ownership.

The two words have different connotations.  The words "belonging to" signifies ownership i.e. the Government owned institutions would be covered under the said part and the words "under the control of" signifies control other than ownership since ownership has already been covered under the words "belonging to".  The two words are separated by the word "OR" and therefore these two words refer to two mutually exclusive categories of institutions.  While the institutions "belonging" to the Central or the State Government would imply the control of the State but the privately owned institutions can be "under the control of" the Government in various ways such as by granting or withdrawing recognition, exercising Financial Control, Functional Control like management control by take over, restrictions on transfer of management and transfer of immovable properties, prohibition on closure of any teaching of any subject, administrative controls like recruitment, removal, service terms.  The State Act is a complete code in itself with regard to the educational institutions and the State Government exercises substantive control over the institutions even though the institutions are not "owned" by it.  [Para 30]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Constitution of India, Arts.246(2), 254(2)
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Arts.246(2), 254(2) - Applicability of 1952 Act to Non-Governmental Educational Institutions in a State.

In this case, the respondent institutions were paying Provident Fund dues to the State Government as per the Scheme framed by the State Government under the State Act.  Employees thereof were entitled to the benefit of the Provident Fund.  State Government sought transfer of balance standing to its credit to the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner.  High Court in writs challenging the action held that the respondent institution is entitled to be excluded from applicability of the Central Act, 1952.  In appeal question before Supreme Court was whether 1952 Act applied to the Non-Government Educational Institutions or not and whether the respondents will fall under Section 16(1)(b).  As the State Act received Presidential assent it prevails over the Central Act in Rajasthan, Central EPF Act would not apply to the educational institutions in the State which are governed by the State Act.  Supreme Court accepted the contention that in order to be covered under the exception to Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952, following two conditions have to be satisfied by the establishment seeking to be exempted from the provisions of the Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952 : (i) it must be an establishment belonging to or under the control of the Central Government or a State Government and (ii) it must be an establishment whose employees are entitled to the benefit of contributory provident fund or old age pension in accordance with any scheme or rule framed by the Central Government or the State Government governing such benefits.  The provisions of the State Act of 1989 make it clear that respondent institution is a recognized educational institution managed by private management and is within the effective management of the State Government and, therefore, it is entitled to be excluded from the applicability of the Central Act, 1952.  Appeals filed by the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner dismissed and the judgment passed by the High Court affirmed.					     [Para 12,14,28,41]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Sentence
HeadNote.description: Sentence - Default in payment of employers and employees contribution already deducted - Accused convicted on their own plea of guilty and sentenced to suffer S.I. till rising of the court and pay a fine - Magistrate not recording any special reasons for lesser sentence than the minimum - Fact that subsequent to date of offence factory was closed down cannot be a ground for leniency in awarding sentence - Held minimum sentence of S.I. for 3 months and fine of Rs. 2000/- each ought to have been awarded. heading: "Employer"
HeadNote.description: "Employer" - Employer could be either owner or occupier of the factory - Directors of company cannot be termed as 'employers' and cannot be held responsible for default in payment of contribution and deemed to have committed offence punishable under S.406 IPC. (Paras 9, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Fund and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Application for grant of exemption
HeadNote.description:
Application for grant of exemption - The proposal for grant of exemption placed before the CBT (EPF) - Rejected, as it violates one of the conditions mentioned in Appendix-A to the Scheme - But CBT (EPF) didn't determine whether the conditions specified in S.17 of the said Act have been fulfilled - Application restored and directed to be re-examined.

The primary requirement which the appropriate Government has to consider is as to whether the conditions specified in Section 17 of the Act have been fulfilled. In so far as the provisions of Clause 17 and 18 of Appendix-A to the scheme are concerned, it is evident from a bare reading of Paragraph 27AA that the exemptions to be granted under Section 17 shall be subject to the terms and conditions as given in Appendix-A. In other words, while granting an exemption the Appropriate Government is within its jurisdiction in imposing conditions which require compliance with the requirements specified in Appendix-A. In the impugned order the appropriate Government has not considered as to whether the conditions specified in Section 17 have been fulfilled. If the appropriate Government comes to the conclusion that the conditions specified in Section 17 have been fulfilled, it would be within its power to grant an exemption subject to compliance of conditions which it may impose including those that are spelt out in Appendix-A of Paragraph 27AA of the Scheme.  [Para 3]

heading: Nomination
HeadNote.description:
Nomination - Deceased nominated his cousin brother and real sister - Cousin brother and real sister were to receive amount on 50:50 basis - Actually total amount of provident fund was paid to sister alone - Nominee/cousin brother is merely authorized to receive amount for benefit of heir of deceased - Defendant No.3/Sister is only successor of deceased - Plaintiff/cousin brother though nominee of provident fund amount is not entitled to get any share in it.

The word 'vest' in section 10(2) does not clothe nominee with absolute title or beneficial title in respect of provident fund amount lying to the credit of deceased.  The nomination is merely authorized to receive the amount for the benefit of heirs of the deceased.  In other words, vesting of amount in nominee is for limited purpose of receiving the amount from employer and handing over the same to the heirs entitled there to.  The amount can be claimed by the heirs of deceased in accordance with law of succession governing them.  1993 Mh.L.J. 228, 1988(1) CLR 596, AIR 1984 SC 346 - Followed.  [Para 16,17,19]

heading: Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Pawan Hans Employees Provident Fund Trust Regulations, Regs.1.3, 2.5 - Benefit under EPF Act - Entitlement - Company owned by Central Govt. and can be termed as Government Company u/S.2(45) of Companies Act - Failed to make out case of exemption u/S.16 from applicability of provision of the Act - Member of respondent, Trade union in continuous employment of company for longtime and receiving wages/salary directly from Company without involvement of any contractor and other similarly situated contractual employees - Would be entitled to benefits of Provident Fund under PF Trust Regulations - Said employees, however, entitled to PF benefits from month when they filed writ petition before High Court and not from date of members joining Trade Union. 			(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Reduction of damages
HeadNote.description: Reduction of damages - Act specifically confers power on Tribunal to modify, reduce, annul order appealed against, including power to pass orders as it thinks fit - Order of respondent Appellate Tribunal to reduce damages from 60% to 40% is not interfered with.2011 LLR 28, 2011(3) ALL MR 204 Ref. to. 		(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Powers of Tribunal
Scope
HeadNote.description: Powers of Tribunal - Scope - Tribunal ordered reduction in damages in exercise of its appellate powers - Appellants however contended that power to reduce quantum of damages is that of Central Board under Scheme of 1952 - Held, power of Tribunal to order reduction can be read u/s.7-L - Central Board also has that power but same is not exclusive - Scheme framed under the Act cannot modify appellate powers conferred under that Act.	(Paras 5, 6)

HeadNote.description:
Employers liability to pay employees contribution - It would arise only from 1.5.86 and not retrospectively from 1.10.1984.

Though the Cinema theatres employing five or more persons would be liable to pay their own contribution to the provident fund with effect from 1st October, 1984, the date section 24 of the Cine Workers Act came into force, they would not be liable to pay the employees' contribution for the period from 1st October, 1984 to 30th April, 1986. The liability to pay such contribution would arise only from 1st May, 1986.

(1991)3  SCC   119  followed.  [Para 3]

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Funds Appellate Tribunal (Procedure) Rules (1997)
heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Application filed under S.14-B - Limitation - Period of pendency of bona fide application under S.14-B is liable to be excluded - Grant of an opportunity to the petitioner to contest the matter, held, does not mean a decision on merits itself. 	(Para 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees' Provident Funds Appellate Tribunal (Procedure) Rules (1997)
heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Scope and applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act - Appeal against an order passed by authority under Employees' Provident Funds Act - Period of limitation of 60 days prescribed by R.7(2) for filing appeal to Tribunal - It is a special law of limitation - Held, provision of S.14 of Limitation Act would apply also to special law of limitation.	(Paras 6 to 9)

heading: Manufacturing process
HeadNote.description:
Manufacturing process - Appellant running hotel with 16 employees - Appellant's witness in oral evidence states that kitchen, meals and snacks were being prepared - LPG gas is used as source of heat energy - Further, statement that there was deep freezer for preservation, chilling of food articles - Preparation of food in kitchen is manufacturing process - Raw food articles are altered, served with garnishing - These activities are well within definition of 'Manufacturing Process'. 
1993 (4) SCC 364, 1980 LAB I C 100, 2012(1) CLR 84, 2005 (4) LLN 149, 2001 (2) LL J Karnataka 973, 1995 (1) Mh.L.J. 63 Ref. to. (Paras 19, 22)

heading: Constitution of India, Art.226
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Certificate of ward of insured person - Application for issuance of, by petitioner-daughter of insured person - For the purpose of taking admission in Medical College under quota reserved for wards of insured persons (ESIC quota) - Refusal to grant, on ground that petitioner's father does not fulfill criteria as required under Admission Notice dt.28/6/2017 - Clause 8 of said notice states that insured person shall be an employee as defined in ESI Act and he/she should have been in continuous insurable employment for a minimum period of 5/4/3 yrs. as on 1st January of the year of admission and should have paid at least 78 days of contribution in each contribution period during these 5/4/3 yrs. - Petitioner's father registered under ESI Scheme on 12/6/2011 - Thereafter he was continued till 30/9/2015 - From 1/10/2015 to 30/9/2016 he was out of coverage of wage limit, as his salary was increased - He was not paying contribution from 1/10/2015 to 30/3/2016 and no record found from 1/4/2016 to 30/9/2016 - In such circumstances petitioner's father not fulfilling criteria to issue ward of insured persons certificate and therefore not eligible.	 (Paras 20, 21, 22, 23, 30)

heading: Contribution period
HeadNote.description:
Contribution period - Means the period not exceeding six consecutive months - No minimum period has been prescribed - R.2(2A) cannot be interpreted to mean that if an employee has worked for a lesser period, he is not entitled to coverage under the Act.

	Rule 2(2A) of the Rules provides period not exceeding six consecutive months as "contribution period" no minimum period has been prescribed. The Rule 2(2A) cannot be interpreted to mean that if an employee has worked for a lesser period he is not entitled for the coverage under the Act.

 Similarly, Regulations 26 to 31 of Regulations of 1950 is also of no avail as the Regulations make it clear that for the wage period, contribution has to be made by the employer as provided in Regulation 31 otherwise he is liable to make payment as provided in Regulation 31A and amount carry interest, which is recoverable as arrears of land revenue. It is also settled that interest cannot be waived. Regulation 36 also makes it clear that when an employee is employed by an employer for a part of the wage period, the contribution in respect of such wage period shall fall due on the last date of the employment in that wage period. The intendment of regulation is clear to cover work rendered in part of wage period. 			 [Para 9]

heading: Penal Code (1860), Ss.21 and 161
HeadNote.description:
Penal Code (1860), Ss.21 and 161 - Panel doctor under ESI Scheme is not a public servant - He cannot be prosecuted for offences under Prevention of Corruption Act.

Prevention of Corruption Act (1947), S.5(1)(d) and 5(2).

A panel doctor under the ESI scheme is not a public servant within the meaning of S.21 of Penal Code.  Therefore, he cannot be prosecuted for offences under S.5(1)(d) and 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. [Para 14]

The term insurance medical officer does not mean that he must be an employee of the Corporation or there exists a master servant or command - obedience relationship.  The panel doctors are appointed by way of a contract signed between the Corporation and such private practitioners and they are responsible to provide medical treatment to the insured persons (as well as to the families) who are registered with them and for such medical service rendered by them, they submit the bills which are reimbursable by the Corporation as per the rates stipulated or agreed upon.  The medical benefits so provided are from the dispensary/hospital/consulting room of such panel doctors and they are limited to such insured persons who are registered under them.  The relationship between the Corporation and such panel doctors is therefore, merely contractual without any specific term of tenure and obviously the tenure is at the pleasure of each of the parties to the contract.  [Para 10]

To perform a public duty, one must occupy a public office or must be in the employment of the State or a Corporation established by the Government either under a Central or a State Act.  A perusal of the contract signed between the Corporation and the panel doctor in pursuance of the enabling powers U/s 59(2) of the Act, indicates that there is nothing to show that a panel doctor is an employee of the Corporation and therefore, the contentions that such a panel doctor performs a public duty by way of providing medical benefits to the insured persons or to their families as the case may be, cannot be sustained.				 [Para 11]

heading: Casual workers
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Casual workers - Applicability of ESI Act - Petitioner is Public Amusement Club engaged in business of conducting Horse Races - It engaged services of some persons on certain days in week only for 2-3 hours when races are conducted - Demand notice issued for payment of ESI contribution towards such Race Days Persons to petitioner - Challenged before ESI Court contending that these Race Days Persons are also employed in other establishments on days when races are not conducted - ESI Court held them under coverage of ESI Act - Petitioner had taken up matter up to Apex Court and that Court had also given same decision - By taking recourse to S.39(4) of ESI Act and Reg.38 of the Regulations, petitioner approached Writ Court for clarification as to which employer, whether petitioner or employer with whom Race Day Persons are employed on regular basis, is liable to pay ESI contribution - Not permissible to petitioner to raise similar contentions which were already considered by Apex Court, while fastening liability upon petitioner - Such attempt is not only to avoid payment of ESI contribution, but also in belittling judgment of Apex Court which is final - Judgment of Apex Court has to be treated as binding on E.S.I. Court and on Writ Court also - Petition dismissed. (2004) 12 SCC 645, 2016 ALL SCR 867 Ref. to. 	(Paras 19, 36, 38, 43)

heading: ESI contribution
Failure to pay
HeadNote.description:
ESI contribution - Failure to pay - Levy of damages S.85-B does not envisage imposition of damages in all situations.

Section 85-B of the Act empowers the Corporation to recover damages in the event an employer fails to make the payment of the amount due in respect of contribution; subject, however, to the condition that the amount thereof would not exceed the amount of arrears as may be specified in the Regulations.  Proviso appended thereto incorporates the principles of 'Natural Justice'.	 [Para 11]

An employee being required to be compulsorily insured, the employer is bound to make his part of the contribution.  An employee is also bound to make his contribution under the Act.  But the same does not mean that levy of damages in all situations would be imperative.  Section 85-B of the Act uses the words 'may recover'.  Levy of damages thereunder is by way of penalty.  The Legislature limited the jurisdiction of the authority to levy penalty, i.e., not exceeding the amount of arrears.  Regulation 31-C of the Regulations, therefore, in our opinion, must be construed keeping in view the language used in the Legislative Act and not de hors the same.   [Para 13,14]

A penal provision should be construed strictly.  Only because a provision has been made for levy of penalty, the same by itself would not lead to the conclusion that penalty must be levied in all situations.  Such an intention on the part of the legislature is not decipherable from Section 85-B of the Act.  When a discretionary jurisdiction has been conferred on a statutory authority to levy penal damages by reason of an enabling provision, the same cannot be construed as imperative.  Even otherwise, an endeavour should be made to construe such penal provisions as discretionary, unless the statute is held to be mandatory in character.		 [Para 17]

heading: Levy of penalty
Failure to pay
Damages
HeadNote.description: Levy of penalty - Failure to pay - Damages - Existence of mens rea or actus reus to contravene a statutory provision is necessary ingredient for levy thereof of damages and quantum.	(Para 21)

heading: Applicability of Act
Validity of notice
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Act extended to sugar factories by notification from 1-8-2000 - Provisions of Act became applicable 12 months preceding the appointed date - Alleged non-compliance with provisions of the Act - Notice under S.45(2) to show cause why criminal cases be not instituted in terms of S.85(g) - Validity of notice - Notice issued without first ascertaining jurisdictional fact about applicability of Act to respective employers and giving them an opportunity to comply with the Act - Employers were entitled to show that even for the preceding twelve months provisions of the Act had no application to them - Authorities directed to give opportunity of hearing and then determine whether jurisdictional fact existed for applicability of Act and action thereunder.	(Paras 21, 23, 26, 34)

heading: Employer's contribution
Delay in payment
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Delay in payment - Liability to pay interest on delayed contribution is statutory - It cannot be waived by Corporation. 2008 ALL SCR 1796 Rel. on. 	(Para 21)

heading: Offence under
Prosecution for
Rel. on.
HeadNote.description:
Offence under - Prosecution for - Late deposit of prescribed contributions by employer - Admittedly there was delay in filing return and making contributions - Acquittal on ground that persons who visited premises and factory as also person who submitted proposal for sanction were not examined - Held, such acquittal merely on technicalities hence improper - Liable to be set aside.	(Para 5,10)

AIR 1961 SC 1, 2000 Cr.L.J. 1401, (1979) 4 SCC 573, (1958) 1 LLJ 598, (2000) I CLR 372 - Rel. on.

heading: 'Factory'
HeadNote.description:
'Factory' - Definitions in Factories Act and in ESI Act are not the same. 

The definition of "factory" in Factories Act and E.S.I. Act are not the same. Explanation II of Section 2(m) of the Factories Act is inserted in the Factories Act and not in the E.S.I. Act. It marks difference in its interpretation and application. In the definition of "factory" under Factories Act the words "worker working" are used, while in the E.S.I. Act, in the section defining "factory", the term "person employed for wages" are used. A difference in these two definition of one word "factory" can be explained by example. A clerk or staff in the premises is not covered under the definition of "worker" under the Factories Act, however, under the ESI Act, the word "worker" is not used but the legislature chose the word "person" and for "working", the word "employed" is used. Thus, the premises where person is employed for a clerical work is covered under the definition "factory" under the E.S.I. Act. Therefore, definition of "factory" has wider meaning under the ESI Act than the Factories Act.

If manufacturing process is carried out as contemplated under Section 2(12) of the E.S.I. Act, then that particular unit cannot be made an exception to the application of the E.S.I. Act. To borrow the meaning from the provision of Explanation II of Section 2(m) of the Factories Act, will be a mayopic view defeating the object and spirit of the E.S.I. Act. The meaning of the term "factory" for the purpose of E.S.I. Act is not to be understood in the context of Explanation II of Section 2(m) of the Factories Act. This is not a harmonious construction of the Statute. Application of E.S.I. Act is not a regressive but a progressive step and to think that if E.S.I. Act is made applicable then it will affect I.T. industry adversely is a futile fear.
2009 ALL SCR 1731 Rel. on.          [Para 19,21]

heading: Manufacturing process
HeadNote.description:
Manufacturing process - Includes computer related activities like development, programming etc., though not mentioned in definition.

The meaning of the term "manufacturing process" under Section 14AA of the E.S.I. Act shall have the meaning assigned to it u/s.2(k) of Factories Act. While reading Explanation-II of Section 2(m) of the Factories Act, the phrase "if no manufacturing process is carried on" is to be read necessarily in respect of the substance manufactured in the premises by any means or any method including the computer. The language of Explanation-II is to be read in a literal sense by applying rule of literal interpretation.

Many verbs describing different activities are mentioned in the said definition. It is true that each activity and verb has its own connotation. The Factories Act was enacted in 1948 and at the relevant time, use of computer and software was alien to the Legislature. Naturally, the words which are more appropriate, precisely describing the activities carried out with the help of the computers i.e. development of software, programming of data, application etc. were neither known nor in practice at the relevant time when the Act was enacted. Albeit, the absence of these words, the manufacturing of the substance with the help of computers can be covered generally under the activities which are mentioned in the definition of manufacturing process as making, altering, treating, adapting etc. Thus, the Section defining manufacturing process allows a wide interpretation. This can be substantiated by giving example that some other activities like turning, milling, fitting welding, drilling, ironing, cooking, painting etc. are not specifically mentioned in the definition of manufacturing activities though these are considered as manufacturing process at various work places and covered under different 'verbs' used in the definition of manufacturing process. Therefore, though computer related activities like development, programming, application are not mentioned in the definition and to that effect there is no amendment in the section; the definition takes care of activities like development and application.         [Para 18,20]

heading: Company failing to deposit the share of contribution recovered from the wages of the employees
HeadNote.description:
Company failing to deposit the share of contribution recovered from the wages of the employees - Held, when the company is itself the owner of the factory, it is only the company that is liable but not the Directors of the company.

When the definition of principal employer in Section 2(17) refers to the "owner" or "occupier" of a factory, the principal employer can be either the owner or the occupier depending upon the facts of each case. When there is an owner of the factory that owner must be considered as the principal employer liable for contribution.

Under Section 40 of the words "owner" and "occupier" have been used disjunctively. The Court also referred to Section 100 of the Factories Act and said that even under the Factories Act, 1948, the Legislature has clearly contemplated that in the cases of a factory, a company can be the "occupier". Therefore, when the owner of a factory is a company it is the company which is the principal employer and not its director.  [Para 6,7]

Therefore, even if the definition of "principal employer" is read under the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 in Explanation 2 to Section 405 of the Indian Penal Code, the directors of the company, in the present case, would not be covered by the definition of "principal employer" when the company itself owns the factory and is also the employer of its employees at the head office.  [Para 10]

heading: Contempt proceedings
Order of stay
HeadNote.description:
Contempt of Courts Act (1971), Ss.2, 12 - Contempt proceedings - Order of stay - Order not a judgment in rem - Order obtained by misrepresentation - Cannot be put into use as a foundation for contempt - Using court proceedings for selfish gains by unscrupulous people, needs to be deprecated.

In this case conduct of the petitioner is such that he has by misrepresentation secured an order, and failed to comply with the said payment, and the said order is now being but into use as a foundation for contempt. It is, therefore, a case where a person, who has no respect for the truth and fairness, is invoking the jurisdiction of Court in the guise of solemn and sincere effort for enhancement and maintenance of majesty and prestige of Law and of Court. This attitude of using the court proceedings for selfish gains by unscrupulous people needs to be deprecated.  One needs to identify the hound under the hide of a sheep lamenting for the cause of justice.						    [Para 33,36]

heading: Limitation
Framing of issue
HeadNote.description: Limitation Act (1963), Ss.5, 12 - Limitation - Framing of issue - Objection regarding limitation raised - In absence of framing the issue relating to limitation, held, the judgment suffers from the defect of improper exercise of jurisdiction.	(Para 17)

heading: Complainant a workman and insured person under E.S.I. Act
HeadNote.description: Complainant a workman and insured person under E.S.I. Act - Complaint about accident and amount of compensation - Consumer Forum has no jurisdiction to entertain such type of complaints - E.S.I. Act being a Special Act, the relief available to Complainant was to approach E.S.I. Court for appropriate relief.	(Para 2)

heading: Jurisdiction of Consumer Forum
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Consumer Forum - Matters governed by E.S.I. Act - Consumer Forum has no jurisdiction to entertain and try the matters which are governed by E.S.I. Act - Proper course open to complainant is to go to E.S.I. Court. JT (1995)2 SC 441 - Rel. on.			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Grievance
Redressalof
Two remedies available
HeadNote.description: Consumer Protection Act (1986),Ss.2(1)(d), 12 - Grievance - Redressalof - Two remedies available - When tworemedies are available, they are mutuallyexclusive - Complainant has to approach oneAuthority and not two authorities simultaneously for the same relief. (Para 10)

heading: Service
HeadNote.description: Service - Medical service rendered by ESI Hospital - Wherever charges are borne under insurance policy, it would be a service rendered within ambit of S.2(1)(o) - It cannot be said to be a free service rendered by E.S.I. hospital/dispensary.	(Paras 12, 14)

heading: Damages
HeadNote.description:
Medical negligence by ESIC doctors - Damages - Claims can be entertained by consumer forum - Such claim does not fall within scope of employees Insurance Court.

Cause of action for negligence arises only when damage occurs and thus the claimant has to satisfy the court on the evidence that three ingredients of negligence, namely, (a) existence of duty to take care; (b) failure to attain that standard of care; and (c) damage suffered on account of breach of duty, are present for the defendant to be held liable for negligence. Therefore, the claimant has to satisfy these ingredients before he can claim damages for medical negligence of the doctors and that could not be a question which could be adjudicated upon by the Employees' Insurance Courts which have been given specific powers of the issues, which they can adjudicate and decide. Claim for damages for negligence of the doctors or the ESI hospital/dispensary is clearly beyond the jurisdictional power of the Employees' Insurance Court. An Employees' Insurance Court has jurisdiction to decide certain claims which fall under sub-section (2) of Section 75 of the ESI Act. A bare reading of Section 75(2) also does not indicate, in any manner, that the claim for damages for negligence would fall within the purview of the decisions being made by the Employees' Insurance Court. Further, it can be seen that any claim arising out of and within the purview of the Employees' Insurance Court is expressly barred by virtue of sub-section (3) to be adjudicated upon by a civil court, but there is no such express bar for the consumer forum to exercise the jurisdiction even if the subject-matter of the claim or dispute falls within clauses (a) to (g) of sub-section (1) of Section 75 or where the jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the claim is vested with the Employees' Insurance Court under clauses (a) to (f) of sub-section (2) of Section 75 if it is a consumer's dispute falling under the Consumer Protection Act.   [Para 20]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Bar of E.S.I. Act - Claim against insurer of offending vehicle and not against employer of deceased - Bar of S.53 would not come in the way to grant compensation to deceased.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Notice for dismissal/discharge etc.
HeadNote.description:
Notice for dismissal/discharge etc. - Prohibition against operate only during period of illness - Such notice can become operative or valid after period of illness.

Reading of Section 73(2), shows that even if a notice of dismissal or discharge or reduction is given to an employee during the period of illness specified in sub-section (1), the same shall not be valid or operative. In a case where such notice is given during the said period of illness, the same shall remain in abeyance because the same is not valid nor the same can be made operative during that period. It does not mean that such a notice cannot become operative or valid after the period of illness, as specified in sub-section (1), is over. In the instant case, the sanctioned period of illness contemplated by sub-Section (1) of Section 73 is from 12.06.1986 till 01.10.1986 and the show cause notice came to be issued on 22.06.1986 i.e. during the said period of illness. The show cause notice therefore, could not become operative nor could be said to be valid during the period from 12.06.1986 till 01.10.1986. But then it is noteworthy that in case of petitioner, this show cause notice was neither made operative nor valid during the said period of illness specified by sub-Section (1) and the action to terminate services of the petitioner by dismissal order took place as late as on 19.03.1987 i.e. after the specified period.  						

Consequently dismissal order of the petitioner employee dated 19-03-1987 cannot be said to be void. Also, the employer filed and proved a statement of absence and attendance of the petitioner employee. Perusal of the same clearly shows that the petitioner employee  remained absent on 114 days out of 365 days in a year. From the reasons for his absence one is fully convinced that the petitioner indulged in habitual absence and the reasons furnished by him on many occasions appear to be bogus. If the petitioner could remain on leave/unauthorised absence of 114 days out of 365 days in a year, one can understand what kind of duty he must have performed. The petitioner, for all the above reasons therefore, is not entitled to any relief muchless claim for backwages.

heading: Parties
HeadNote.description:
Parties - Employer must not only implead ESIC but also implead atleast some of the workers concerned in representative capacity or the trade-union representing the workers - Concerned employee has to be heard before a determination is made against him that he is not an employee of employer concerned.

The rules of natural justice require that if any adverse order is made against any party, he/she must be heard. Thus if a determination is given by the Employees Insurance Court that the concerned persons are not the employees of the petitioner, and that determination is given even without hearing the concerned persons, it will be clearly against the rules of natural justice. Section 75 of the Act does not mention who will be the parties before the Insurance Court. Since the determination by the Insurance Court is a quasi-judicial determination, natural justice requires that any party which may be adversely affected or may suffer civil consequences by such determination, must be heard before passing any order by the authority/court. Wherever any petition is filed by an employer under Section 75 of the Act, the employer has not only to implead the ESIC but has also to implead atleast some of the workers concerned (in a representative capacity if there are a large number of workers) or the trade-union representing the said workers. If that is not done, and a decision is given in favour of the employer, the same will be in violation of the rules of natural justice. After all, the real concerned parties in labour matters are the employer and the workers. The ESI Corporation will not be in any way affected if the demand notice sent by it under Section 45-A/45-B is quashed.   [Para 9,11]

heading: Disability benefit
HeadNote.description: Disability benefit - Two cumulative conditions to be satisfied by injured person are that the claimant must be an insured person and that injury had been suffered when he was an employee - Claimant was employee upto 30-9-1989 - Suffered injury on 15-6-1990 - Would not be entitled to disability benefit though his contribution period and his status as insured continued upto 30-6-1990.	(Para 7)

heading: Appeal
Interference
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Interference - When in any law where an appeal on facts alone is available, interference even in such an appeal would not be permissible unless findings are shown to be erroneous due to any illegality - Held, just because another opinion on facts is possible, interference shall not be permissible. 2001 SCC (L&S) 1121 and 2002 SCC (L&S) 1037 - Ref. to.	(Para 32)

heading: Bar to dismiss employee during sickness
HeadNote.description: Bar to dismiss employee during sickness - Delinquent employee producing benefit payment slips issued by ESI - Labour Court finding that employee had received sickness benefits and consequently dismissal order would be void in view of S.73 - This finding endorsed by Industrial Court - No case made out for interference by High Court with concurrent findings.	(Para 12)

heading: Followed.			(Paras 26, 33)
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Commissioner for Workmen's Compensation - Death due to injuries caused because of fire in petitioners company - Father of deceased making application to Commissioner for Workmen's Compensation - Jurisdiction of Commissioner objected - Objection rejected holding that petitioner-Company was not a member of E.S.I.C. - Held, once necessity of coverage is ruled out in light of interpretation placed on S.53 of E.S.I. Act by Supreme Court, then the view of Commissioner cannot be sustained - Objection could not be overruled on ground that insured was not covered during his life time. 2003(2) S.C.C. 138 - Followed.			(Paras 26, 33)

heading: Employee
Who is
Contractor's employee
HeadNote.description:
Employee - Who is - Contractor's employee - Merely because the establishment is a "factory" it does not mean that even contractor's employees engaged by an employer would necessarily fall within definition of "employee" under S.2(9) of the Act - They must do work incidental to the purpose of the factory.

In the present case, the work of the factory, as has come in evidence, is cutting, polishing and finishing. It is only when a complete contract is taken, the principal employer is required to carry out also the work of laying or fixing the marble. Merely because the establishment is a 'factory' it does not mean that even contractor's employees engaged by an employer would necessarily fall within the definition of 'employees' under Section 2(9). They must do work incidental to the purpose of the factory. The work of the factory has been spelt out earlier.
