Merely because the material is supplied at the site and that is laid by the contractor i.e. immediate employer, it cannot be said that, there would be work which is incidental to the work of the factory or for the purpose of the factory.  Incidental for the purpose of the factory would mean that it has some connection with the ordinary work of the factory. That is not the evidence in the instant case.  1998 Lab.I.C. 157 and 1991(1) CLR 669 - Referred to.	 [Para 10]

heading: "Principal employer" under S.2(17) of ESI Act and "employer" under S.2(e) of Provident Fund Act
HeadNote.description: "Principal employer" under S.2(17) of ESI Act and "employer" under S.2(e) of Provident Fund Act - These two provisions are pari materia. Penal Code (1860), S.406. 1998(4) ALL MR 389 (S.C.) - Followed.(Para 6)

heading: Principal employer
Liability
HeadNote.description:
Principal employer - Liability - Manager appointed for carrying out provisions of the Act - Director cannot be prosecuted for violations of the Act.

Clauses in the definition in S.2(17) will not conjointly apply for prosecution, but the clause can be applied only alternatively. If in given case clause (1) applies all other clauses will be excluded. Therefore, where a Manager is appointed for carrying out provisions of the Act, a director of the company will be excluded from the definition clause. In view of the above proposition of law, as laid there is no justification for the prosecution of the petitioner  for the violation of the provisions of E.S.I. Act.

AIR 1991 SC 1741 Rel.on.  [Para 7]

heading: Expression 'wages'
HeadNote.description: Expression 'wages' - 'Inam' payment cannot be construed as 'wages' within meaning of S.2(22). AIR 1968 SC 413 and II LLJ 396 Rel. on. Decision in F.A.No. 108 of 1973 (Dr.Dhanuka J.) disting. (Para 8)

heading: Insured employee dying during course of employment
HeadNote.description: Insured employee dying during course of employment - His dependents would not be entitled to get any compensation or damages from employer under the Workmen's Compensation Act, 1923 - Legal heirs, however, had received amount of Rs.4 Lacks which was directed to be deposited by employer in court - Held in view of fact that litigation was pending since a decade employer should not recover it by way of deducting periodical sum that is paid to legal heirs of deceased employee. 		(Para 12)

heading: Quashing of proceeding
HeadNote.description: Quashing of proceeding - Proceeding for failure to pay contribution - Particulars of accusations are already explained to accused - Prosecution for failure to pay contribution lodged against accused should proceed in accordance with law, on merits - Proceeding cannot be quashed. 	(Para 5)

heading: Non-payment of contribution
HeadNote.description:
Non-payment of contribution - Being an economic offence, court has no discretion to reduce fine amount lesser than Rs.5,000/- - Discretion as per proviso to S.85, is confined only in respect of term of imprisonment.

The object of creating offence and penalty under the Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948 is clearly to create deterrence against violation of provisions of the Act which are beneficial for the employees. Non-payment of contributions is an economic offence and therefore the Legislature has not only fixed a minimum term of imprisonment but also a fixed amount of fine of five thousand rupees under Section 85(a)(i)(b) of the Act. There is no discretion of awarding less than the specified fee, under the main provision. It is only the proviso which is in the nature of an exception whereunder the court is vested with discretion limited to imposition of imprisonment for a lesser term. Conspicuously, no words are found in the proviso for imposing a lesser fine than that of five thousand rupees. In such a situation the intention of the Legislature is clear and brooks no interpretation. The law is well settled that when the wordings of the Stature are clear, no interpretation is required unless there is a requirement of saving the provisions from vice of unconstitutionality or absurdity. Neither of the twin situations is attracted herein.
	Hence the question is answered in favour of the appellant and it is held that the amount of fine has to be Rupees five thousand and the courts have no discretion to reduce the same once the offence has been established. The discretion as per proviso is confined only in respect of term of imprisonment. 	 [Para 8,9]

heading: Application u/S.75
HeadNote.description: Application u/S.75 - Employees to be impleaded - Held, employer has not only to implead ESIC in application u/S.75, but also to implead employees or at least some of them as party respondent. (2009) 9 SCC 485 Foll.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Demand of contribution
HeadNote.description: Demand of contribution - By clubbing two different units - Units clubbed on ground of unity of ownership - Order of clubbing passed on basis of observation in inspection report that both units have common workforce and common point for collection of revenue - Though both units were proximately situated, no evidence to show that they had common workforce and common point for collection of revenue - Further, inspection report was not signed by representative of employer of units in question - No factual or legal basis to order clubbing of both units - Demand of contribution by clubbing units, improper.  (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Penal Code (1860), Ss.21 and 161
HeadNote.description:
Penal Code (1860), Ss.21 and 161 - Panel doctor under ESI Scheme is not a public servant - He cannot be prosecuted for offences under Prevention of Corruption Act.

Prevention of Corruption Act (1947), S.5(1)(d) and 5(2).

A panel doctor under the ESI scheme is not a public servant within the meaning of S.21 of Penal Code.  Therefore, he cannot be prosecuted for offences under S.5(1)(d) and 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. [Para 14]

The term insurance medical officer does not mean that he must be an employee of the Corporation or there exists a master servant or command - obedience relationship.  The panel doctors are appointed by way of a contract signed between the Corporation and such private practitioners and they are responsible to provide medical treatment to the insured persons (as well as to the families) who are registered with them and for such medical service rendered by them, they submit the bills which are reimbursable by the Corporation as per the rates stipulated or agreed upon.  The medical benefits so provided are from the dispensary/hospital/consulting room of such panel doctors and they are limited to such insured persons who are registered under them.  The relationship between the Corporation and such panel doctors is therefore, merely contractual without any specific term of tenure and obviously the tenure is at the pleasure of each of the parties to the contract.  [Para 10]

To perform a public duty, one must occupy a public office or must be in the employment of the State or a Corporation established by the Government either under a Central or a State Act.  A perusal of the contract signed between the Corporation and the panel doctor in pursuance of the enabling powers U/s 59(2) of the Act, indicates that there is nothing to show that a panel doctor is an employee of the Corporation and therefore, the contentions that such a panel doctor performs a public duty by way of providing medical benefits to the insured persons or to their families as the case may be, cannot be sustained.				 [Para 11]

heading: Mining industry
Appropriate Government
HeadNote.description:
Mining industry - Appropriate Government - Application of Notification dt. 21-6-1977 issued by the Government of Goa extending provisions of Act to mining industry - Mines situated at Pisurlen and office of the mine at Sanquelin - Payment of staff and workers made through office at Sanquelin while mining operations carried out at Pisurlen - Head office was at Panaji - Held appropriate Government is State Government and not Central Government.

1962 Supp (3) SCR 934 Rel. on.	(Para 2,3)

heading: "Shop"
HeadNote.description: Notification issued by State Government Dt.21-6-1977, Schedule, Item 2 - "Shop" - Notification made applicable to shop - Head Office of mine - All business and trading activities done in Head Office - No material to show any work connected with any of activities defined in Mines Act, 1952 being carried out in Head Office - Held, 'Head Office can be treated as "shop" liable for contribution.  AIR 1988 SC 79 Applied. AIR 1966 SC 925 Disting. (Paras 5,6,7)

heading: "Shop"
HeadNote.description:
"Shop" - Advertising Agency selling its expert and consulting services in different fields - Premises from where it carries on its activities is a "shop".

The business carried on by appellants in this case has of consultancy services to its customers in respect of industrial, technical, marketing and management activities and preparation of project reports by engaging the services of architects, engineers and other experts. In substance, the nature of activities carried on by the appellant is commercial or economical and would amount to parting with the same at a price. The premises of advertising agency could reasonably be said to be shop. AIR 1984 SC 1700 Disting. AIR 1994 SC 1154 Rel. on.  [Para 7]

heading: Contribution towards Employee's State Insurance
HeadNote.description:
Contribution towards Employee's State Insurance - Geographical unity and functional integrality in management of 5 units - Held, 5 units can be considered as one factory - Business and work of one unit not independent of others - ESI Act is applicable to all factories.

In the present case, the evidence on record is unambiguous and establishes the fact that there was functional integrality between the units, therefore the five units can be considered as one factory. The business and work of one unit was not independent of the others. The ESI Act is applicable to all factories. The work "factory" has been defined under the said Act in section 2(12) as meaning the premises including the precincts thereof wherein 10 or more persons were employed on wages in the preceding 12 months and in which a manufacturing process is being carried out with the aid of power or where 20 persons are employed in a manufacturing process, without the aid of power.  Under section 2(14-AA), 'manufacturing process' is assigned the same meaning as manufacturing process under the Factories Act. There is no doubt that the five units which are situated either in the same premises or in the precincts of the premises are involved in manufacturing process and therefore, the ESI Act is applicable as the number of employees working in each of the five units was between 5 and 7. AIR 1960 SC 56 - Referred to.	 [Para 12]

heading: Applicability of Act
Establishment
What constitutes
Hyderabad Race Club
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Establishment - What constitutes - Hyderabad Race Club - By notification of 1975 Club was brought within purview of Act but it was not very clear till decision of Apex Court in 1987 - ESIC itself was not quite sure whether Hyderabad Race Club was establishment under 1975 notification - Hence finding of High Court that demand in respect of period before 1987 cannot be enforced was unassailable.	(Para 6)

heading: Employee
Definition of
HeadNote.description: Employee - Definition of - Includes Director of company, who had been receiving remuneration for discharge of duties assigned to him.  (1998) 1 SCC 86 Rel. on. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Claim for compensation
HeadNote.description: Claim for compensation - Rejection, on ground that claim petition is barred by S.53 of ESI Act - Employer and claimant were covered by ESI Act - Plea of claimant that employer paid contribution under ESI Act after accident, therefore bar u/S.53 is not applicable - S.2(14) provides that once employee is insured person, in respect of whom contributions are paid by employer, he is entitled for benefits provided by ESI Act, irrespective of date on which contribution is paid - Temporary identity certificate issued by ESIC shows that claimant was registered as insured person on date of accident - Plea of claimant not tenable - Claimant being in category of insured person, in view of bar u/S.53 of ESI Act, he is not entitled to recover compensation from employer under Employees' Compensation Act - Rejection of claim for compensation, proper. (2003) 2 SCC 138 Rel. on. 	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Exemption of a factory or establishment or class of factories or establishments
HeadNote.description: Exemption of a factory or establishment or class of factories or establishments - Positive notification of exemption is a must - There is no automatic exemption, merely because a particular area falls within ambit of MIDC or such other area - Non-availability of medical facilities, may be an irregularity but that cannot be the reason to grant total exemption from paying contribution under ESI Act.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Casual workers
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Casual workers - Applicability of ESI Act - Petitioner is Public Amusement Club engaged in business of conducting Horse Races - It engaged services of some persons on certain days in week only for 2-3 hours when races are conducted - Demand notice issued for payment of ESI contribution towards such Race Days Persons to petitioner - Challenged before ESI Court contending that these Race Days Persons are also employed in other establishments on days when races are not conducted - ESI Court held them under coverage of ESI Act - Petitioner had taken up matter up to Apex Court and that Court had also given same decision - By taking recourse to S.39(4) of ESI Act and Reg.38 of the Regulations, petitioner approached Writ Court for clarification as to which employer, whether petitioner or employer with whom Race Day Persons are employed on regular basis, is liable to pay ESI contribution - Not permissible to petitioner to raise similar contentions which were already considered by Apex Court, while fastening liability upon petitioner - Such attempt is not only to avoid payment of ESI contribution, but also in belittling judgment of Apex Court which is final - Judgment of Apex Court has to be treated as binding on E.S.I. Court and on Writ Court also - Petition dismissed. (2004) 12 SCC 645, 2016 ALL SCR 867 Ref. to. 	(Paras 19, 36, 38, 43)

heading: Firm borrowing money from State Financial Corporation by mortgaging property and committing default in re payment
HeadNote.description: Firm borrowing money from State Financial Corporation by mortgaging property and committing default in re payment - Property of Firm put to auction by Corporation after following procedure - Petitioner firm purchasing property in auction - Such transfer is not transfer under the Transfer of Property Law - ESI Corporation cannot recover arrears of contribution that was due and payable by erstwhile owner from petitioner firm.

heading: Service charge collected by Hotel Management from Customers
HeadNote.description: Service charge collected by Hotel Management from Customers - Service charge payable by all Customers without any option - Distributed to employees equally once in three months - Are not wages under S.2(22).	(Para 10)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Offence under ESI Act - Filing of complaint under - Limitation - Period of limitation prescribed under S.86(3) of ESI Act removed by amendment - It does not mean that period of limitation is totally omitted - Result of removal of limitation under special law would only result in limitation under the general law governing cases under Act - Complaint filed for offence under Act beyond period of one year as prescribed under S.468(2)(b) of Cri.P.C. is barred by limitation.	(Para 6)

heading: Appeal under S.82(2)
HeadNote.description: Appeal under S.82(2) - Question involved was whether workmen engaged were covered by the definition of "employee" under S.2(9) of the Act - High Court without considering factual aspects abruptly concluding that the case was covered by decision in 1996(3) SCALE 806 - Matter remitted to High Court for considering factual aspects to determine whether provisions of the Act were applicable to category of persons engaged.		(Para 7)

heading: Appeal
Referred to.	(Para12)
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Application under S.75 of E.S.I. Act - Plea raised by appellants that appellants is registered as a "theatre" and not as a "shop" - Plea not raised before the trial Court or E.S.I. Court - Cannot be considered by appellate Court. AIR 1965 SC 1325 - Referred to.	(Para12)

heading: Contribution towards Employees' State Insurance
HeadNote.description: Contribution towards Employees' State Insurance - Application under S.75 of E.S.I. Act - Judgment of designated Court - Judgment showing that the Judge has discussed all the pros and cons of the issues which were urged in order to saddle the respondent with payment of contribution for the impugned period - Reasoning adopted and finding recorded by designated Court appearing to be legal and proper - Hence, no interference warranted. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 949 - Ref. to.			(Paras 5 & 6)

heading: Applicability of ESI Act
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of ESI Act - Hotel and Bar employing more than 10 persons in a year - Using a deep freezer and a bottle cooler to preserve raw materials and for cooling drinks - No amount of man power is likely to achieve function of freezer or bottle cooler - Therefore use of these gadgets does not bring the establishment within ambit of ESI Act so long as it employs less than 20 persons.

In the definition of "factory" in Section 2(12) of Employee's State Insurance Act (or even Section 2(m) of Factories Act), the legislature intended to cover establishments where 20 or more persons are employed in a manufacturing process. This limit was reduced to 10 when the process was carried out with the aid of power. Obviously, since use of power reduces the need of work force. The object is to ensure that an establishment does not escape from the applicability of benevolent provisions of these statutes by using power to mechanize processes and reduce work force.  Thus if power has been used for performing a task for which labour would have otherwise been required, then such a process aided by power would be relevant. No amount of manpower is likely to achieve preserving articles by cooling them, which a freezer does, or cooling bottles for which a bottle cooler is used. Therefore, use of these gadgets does not bring the establishment within the ambit of Employee's State Insurance Act, so long as it employs less than 20 persons.	Moreover, provisions of the Act are made applicable to factories employing 20 persons or even 10 persons when manufacturing process is aided by power. Thus, it is only when power replaces manpower that reduced strength of persons employed also attracts the provisions of the Act.		 [Para 9,11]

heading: Employee
Scope of S.2(9)
HeadNote.description: Employee - Scope of S.2(9) - Workers concerned with changing electrical wiring and they worked for about two hours in a day for a short period - No evidence to establish that the work done by the workers was ancillary, incidental or having any relevance to the object of the Respondent Company - Company not exercising any control or supervision over the work carried out by these workers - Held, it cannot be said that such workers would be covered by S.2(9) of the E.S.I. Act. 1992(1) CLR 932 and AIR 1986 SC 1686 - Referred to.	(Para 14)

heading: Liability to pay contribution
HeadNote.description: Liability to pay contribution - Business of interior decoration - Professionals, consultants, furnishers, designers etc. - Work was carried out by them through their own manpower over which respondent had no control - No evidence produced by ESI corporation that workers engaged by contractors for temporary period or short duration for specific job were paid by respondent and not by contractors - No nexus or functional integrity or inter changeability proved - Held Insurance Court was justified in holding that applicant firm was not liable to pay contribution as claimed by the Corporation.	(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Principal employer
HeadNote.description: Principal employer - Whether accused is the principal employer of an establishment - Such a fact ought to be established beyond all reasonable doubts and not by preponderance of probability. 2003 Vol.105(2) Bom.L.R. 206 - Rel. on.			(Paras 11 & 17)

heading: Appeal under E.S.I. Act
HeadNote.description: Appeal under E.S.I. Act - No substantial question of law involved in the matter - Issues involved are issues of fact, which are properly appreciated and answered by lower Court and therefore, it would brook no interference - Appeal dismissed.	(Para 6)

heading: Principal employer
Contribution
HeadNote.description: Principal employer - Contribution - Can be recovered from Company and Principal employer - Managing Director or any other Director cannot be made personally liable to pay the contribution. 1998(4) ALL MR 389 (S.C.) - Rel. on.			(Para 8)

heading: Letters patent appeal
Maintainability of
HeadNote.description: Letters patent appeal - Maintainability of - Order of E.S.I. Court - E.S.I. Court presided over by Member of Judicial Service within meaning of Art.236(b) of Constitution of India - While dealing with an application under S.75 of E.S.I. Act, it exercises judicial powers and it is a court - Against the order passed by E.S.I. Court, an appeal lies before High Court under S.82 of E.S.I. Act - If the appeal decided by Single Bench, S.100-A of Civil P.C. would certainly bar any further appeal before Division Bench, notwithstanding clause 15 of Letters Patent Appeal Code - In view of bar provided under S.100-A of Civil P.C., held, this Letters Patent Appeal cannot be entertained. 2001(3) ALL MR 370, 2003(4) Mh.L.J. 883 - Ref. to.	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Employee
HeadNote.description:
Employee - Employees of contractors who supply milk to federal society whose main business is purchasing milk and pasteurization of the same - Held even assuming that the transportation of milk is incidental to the purpose of factory or establishments for want of any supervision of the appellants on the work of such employees, these employees are not covered by the definition of 'employee' under Section 2(9) of the Act.

The ordinary meaning of the word 'supervision' is 'authority to direct' or 'supervise' i.e., to oversee. The expression 'supervision of the principal employer' under Section 2(9) means something more than mere exercise of some remote or indirect control over the activities or the work of the workers. A direct disciplinary control by the principal employer over the workers engaged by the contractors may also be covered by the expression 'supervision of the principal employer'. The circumstances, as in the case of HCMPSU Ltd., that the authorized representatives of the principal employer are entitled to travel in the vehicle of the contractor free of charge or in the case of BURDCMPS Union, that the principal employer has right to ask for removal of such workers who misbehave with their staff are not the circumstances which may even remotely suggest the control or interference exercised by the appellants over the workers engaged by the contractor for transportation of milk. From the agreements entered into by the appellants with the contractors, it does not transpire that the appellants have arrogated to themselves any supervisory control over the workers employed by the contractors. The said workers were under the direct control of the contractor. Exercise of supervision and issue of some direction by the principal employer over the activities of the contractor and his employees is inevitable in contracts of this nature and that by itself is not sufficient to make the principal employer liable. That the contractor is not an agent of the principal employer under Section 2(9)(ii) admits of no ambiguity. No evidence has been collected by the E.S.I. Corporation during the inspection of the appellants' establishments or from the contractors that the appellants have any say over the terms and conditions of employment of these employees or that the appellants have any thing to do with logistic operations of the contractors. As a matter of fact, there is nothing on record to show that principal employer had any knowledge about the number of persons engaged by the contractors or the names or the other details of such persons. There is also no evidence that the appellants were aware of the amount payable to each of these workers. In the circumstances, even if it be held that the transportation of milk is incidental to the purpose of factory or establishment, for want of any supervision of the appellants on the work of such employees, these employees are not covered by the definition of 'employee' under Section 2(9) of the Act.  (1992)1 SCC 441, (1978)4 SCC 204 - Rel.on.   [Para 22]

heading: Employee
HeadNote.description: Employee - Casual labour engaged by sub-contractor to do specialized nature of work - Payment made to sub-contractor for work done - Casual labourers cannot be treated as workers of respondent in absence of supervision and control exercised by respondent on the workers. 			(Para 7)

heading: Rel.on.	(Paras 7, 9)
HeadNote.description: Demand of employer's contribution - Petition filed by employer without impleading workers or their representative - Natural justice requires that any party which may be adversely affected must be heard before passing any order - Order allowing petition without hearing workers is liable to be set aside. 2009 ALL SCR 2520 - Rel.on.	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Application challenging contribution under several heads of accounts - Rejection of - Validity - Insurance Inspector had visited premises of applicant on several occasions and prepared reports - Order passed without supplying copies of inspection reports to applicant - Order could have been passed only after furnishing  copies of  reports to applicant and after giving  them opportunity of hearing on basis of those inspection reports and observation sheets - Order suffers from non observance of rules of natural justice and for want of  fairness to grant opportunity of hearing - Order rejecting application not proper. 			(Paras 1, 2)

heading: Insurance claim
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Insurance claim - Entitlement to - Plea of respondent that employee died due to heart attack which was not employment injury - No evidence produced to rebut the presumption that employee died during course of employment and in factory premises - Even opinion of doctor regarding death was cryptic - Held, presumption u/s.51-A squarely applies to the facts of the case - Claimant therefore entitled to get dependents' benefits. 			(Para 11)

heading: Contribution payable by employer
HeadNote.description: Contribution payable by employer - Payment to labour contractor for loading and unloading work - Whether to be considered for determining contribution - Appellant pleading that only 25% of such amount paid be considered for fixing contribution to be payable by appellant - No record produced to show terms upon which loading and unloading work was executed - In absence of such material entire amount paid to contractor has to be considered as wages - Held, appellant was not entitled to claim of 25% of amount paid for fixing his contribution payable. 	(Para 12)

heading: Applicability of S.75
Notification issued by
Competent
HeadNote.description: Applicability of S.75 - Notification issued by - Govt. of Goa dt.02-07-1977 under S.1(5) covering appellant company under provisions of Act - Competent - No case made out by appellant that its establishment does not fall within entries enumerated in said notification - Appellant held, not entitled to declaration under S.75, that provisions of Act do not apply to its establishment - Further liability to contribute has nothing to do with receipt of benefits and there is no limit for recovery of contribution - Merely because appellant challenged demand of contribution and lis is pending for long time - Would not exempt appellant from liability to pay contribution with interest.	(Paras 29, 31, 32)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal against order u/S.45A - Limitation - Commencement of period of sixty days - Impugned order passed on 22/3/2013 - Petitioner got actual knowledge about order only on 28.3.2013 when it was received by him - Appeal filed on 25.5.2013 was within period of sixty days of such knowledge - Held, in absence of actual or constructive knowledge of order sought to be challenged, period of limitation would not commence from date of order itself - It is only after getting actual or constructive knowledge of such order, party concerned can decide whether to challenge such order or not - Hence, appeal not barred by limitation. 2003(4) ALL MR 1186 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 2244, 2009 Cri.L.J. 2595 Ref. to. 			(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Interest and damages
Liability to pay
HeadNote.description: Interest and damages - Liability to pay - Whether, absolved upon stay order and thereafter, furnishing bank guarantee - Merely because Court has granted stay to recovery of contribution, cannot relieve liability to pay interest and damages which is statutory liability, for relevant period during which stay order was in operation - As regards furnishing bank guarantee, it does not provide payment of interest on amount of contribution, much less payment of damages, that liability still remains and survives - Therefore, ESI Corporation is entitled to recover amount of interest and damages.	 (Paras 9, 15, 18, 20)

heading: "Factory"
HeadNote.description:
"Factory" - Mere presence of refrigerator and grinder in hotel is not sufficient to render the establishment a "factory".

For holding an establishment to be a 'factory' within the meaning of section 2(12) of the Act it must first be established that some work or process is carried on in any part of the establishment that amounts to 'manufacturing process' as defined under section 2(k) of the Factories Act, 1948. In case the number of persons employed in the establishment is less than twenty but more than ten then it must further be established that the manufacturing process in the establishment is being carried on with the aid of power. Further, the use of power in the manufacturing process should be direct and proximate. The expression 'manufacturing process being carried on with the aid of power' in section 2(12) of the Act does not mean a very indirect application of power such as use of electric bulbs for providing light in the work-area. Unless the links are established, that is to say, it is shown that some process or work is carried on in the establishment which qualifies as 'manufacturing process' within the meaning of section 2(k) of the Factories Act and the manufacturing process is carried on with the aid of power, the mere presence of a refrigerator and a grinder there, even though connected to the main power line may not necessary lead to the inference that the establishment is a factory as defined under section 2(12) of the Act.						  [Para 13]

heading: Establishment
HeadNote.description: Establishment - Clubbing of different establishments for coverage of ESI scheme - Different establishments having functional integrality, unity in management, financial unity, geographical proximity, unity in supervision and control and general unity of purpose - Though they were having separate registration under Sales Tax Act, Shops and Establishments Act and Income-tax Act all the units were interdependent and supplementary to each other for their textile business - Held they were rightly treated as one establishment for E.S.I. Act.		(Paras 14, 18, 19)

heading: Demand for contribution
HeadNote.description: Demand for contribution - Necessity to comply with principles of natural justice - Show cause notice referred to some information on basis of which contribution demanded towards past liability of appellant - However, details of such information not provided to appellant despite repeated requests - Held, non-supply of requisite material to appellant amounts to non-compliance with principles of natural justice - It would vitiate entire exercise - Order u/S.45A not sustainable - Matter remitted back for reconsideration by authorities. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Complaint u/Ss.85(a), 85(d)
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Complaint u/Ss.85(a), 85(d) - Filed by Employees State Insurance Corporation against respondent - Though case was pending since 1995, there was no progress in matter - Magistrate acquitted respondent by virtue of direction of Supreme Court - Legality - Submission that as economic offence was involved, it was saved from operation of directions of Supreme Court - Contribution in question has admittedly been paid - More than 15 years has been passed after date of impugned order of acquittal - Respondent hotel closed down and does not carry business any more - No illegality in order of acquittal. 

1997 ALL MR (Cri) 3 (S.C) : 1997(1) ALL MR 49 (S.C.) Foll. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Exemption from applicability of ESI Act
HeadNote.description: Exemption from applicability of ESI Act - Rejection of claim for period from 01.04.2009 to 09.02.2012 - Ground that in view of amended S.91A of ESI Act exemption cannot be granted retrospectively - Exemption was refused by letter of Law and Judiciary Department of Govt. of Maharashtra - Said decision communicated to petitioner was not taken either by Appellate Authority or by Competent Authority under Statute but is an administrative decision of State Govt. - But even if said letter of Govt. is set aside by Court and application of petitioner was sent for de-novo consideration it would have to be considered on touchstone of S.91A - S.91A clearly states that exemption would take effect prospectively - No case made out to interfere with letter of Govt. refusing exemption to petitioner. 			(Paras 8, 9, 12)

heading: Exemption from operation of ESI Act
HeadNote.description: Exemption from operation of ESI Act - Power is vested in Government - ESI Court cannot grant exemption - It cannot also decide question of legality or otherwise of order passed by Govt. relating to exemption - Parties cannot agree to vest jurisdiction in the Court, by consent.

heading: Employer's contribution
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Recovery of, for period from 01.10.2004 to 30.09.2005 - Opposed on ground that ESI Act is not applicable as better medical facilities were provided by petitioner-company to its employees - Act becomes applicable to area of Butibori where petitioner-company is established vide notification dt.28.09.2004 - No provision in Act exempting establishment of petitioner from complying with provisions of Act on ground pleaded by them - Only remedy available to petitioner-company is to move appropriate Govt. and to claim exemption u/S.87 of Act - Court cannot quash and set aside notification or prevent recovery of employer's contribution. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Constitution of India, Art.226
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Certificate of ward of insured person - Application for issuance of, by petitioner-daughter of insured person - For the purpose of taking admission in Medical College under quota reserved for wards of insured persons (ESIC quota) - Refusal to grant, on ground that petitioner's father does not fulfill criteria as required under Admission Notice dt.28/6/2017 - Clause 8 of said notice states that insured person shall be an employee as defined in ESI Act and he/she should have been in continuous insurable employment for a minimum period of 5/4/3 yrs. as on 1st January of the year of admission and should have paid at least 78 days of contribution in each contribution period during these 5/4/3 yrs. - Petitioner's father registered under ESI Scheme on 12/6/2011 - Thereafter he was continued till 30/9/2015 - From 1/10/2015 to 30/9/2016 he was out of coverage of wage limit, as his salary was increased - He was not paying contribution from 1/10/2015 to 30/3/2016 and no record found from 1/4/2016 to 30/9/2016 - In such circumstances petitioner's father not fulfilling criteria to issue ward of insured persons certificate and therefore not eligible.	 (Paras 20, 21, 22, 23, 30)

heading: Order of damages
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Delayed payment of contribution - Order of damages - Challenge to - Proceeding rendered infructuous in view of payment of dues on basis of two communications - Respondent company neither made an application for withdrawal of E.I. case nor had filed any application for disposing of the case as infructuous - Held, merely on the basis of the two communications the Employees Insurance Court should not have held that the proceeding had been rendered infructuous in view of the payment of the dues - It was necessary for the Employees Insurance Court to decide whether the dues were actually paid or not.	(Para 6)

heading: Functional integrity
Two petrol pumps
HeadNote.description: Functional integrity - Two petrol pumps - Respondent supervising and controlling sales in all its branch offices and taking share of their income - There is functional integrity between them - Held, in the present case, both the petrol pumps, therefore, constitute a single entity. 1980(II) L.L.J. 232 and 2001(88) FLR 347 - Ref. to.		(Para 7)

heading: Payment of interest
HeadNote.description: Payment of interest - Liability to pay interest is statutory - There is no power of waiver.	(Para 6)

heading: "Manufacturing Process"
Use of Airconditioners
Dist.						 [Para 11]
HeadNote.description:
"Manufacturing Process" - Use of Airconditioners - Can be said to be covered under definition of the word "manufacturing process" only if some alterations were done to the air conditioner or the air conditioner was modified to make it suitable for some new use - Mere use of air conditioners in the lodging rooms for the comfort of the customers would not be sufficient to hold that the employer Hotel was carrying on "Manufacturing process" within the meaning of S.2(k) of the Factories Act.

The Dictionary meaning of the word "adapted" in the New International Webster's Comprehensive Dictionary is to make suitable, as by remodeling, to modify, to conform to a situation or environment.  Thus, "adapt" would not mean using the thing or article as it is.  To adapt means to make an article suitable by remodeling so as to conform to a situation or an environment.  Even according to the Concise Law Dictionary "To Adapt" means to make suitable, to alter as to fit for a new use, to change by adaptation, etc.  Thus, it cannot be said by any stretch of imagination that the word "adapt" means that the thing or article is itself fit and suitable.  As can be seen from the Dictionary meaning, something more has to be done to the article by adopting it.  In fact, adaptation would mean a process of modifying a thing so as to suit a new condition.  Thus, the use of air conditioner could have been said to be covered under the definition of the word "manufacturing process" only if some alternations were done to the air conditioner or the air conditioner was modified to make it suitable for some new use.  Mere use of sir conditioners in the lodging rooms for the comfort of the customers would not be sufficient to hold that the employer Hotel was carrying on "manufacturing process" within the meaning of Section 2(k) of the Factories Act.  Since it is not the case of the Corporation that any other process mentioned in Section 2(k)(i) of the Factories Act was experienced by or carried on, on the air conditioner with a view to its use, it cannot be said that the Corporation was justified in passing the order under Section 45-A of the Act as the only term applicable in the instant case, according to the Corporation was "adapting" and as already pointed out herein above, the word 'adapting' could not be applied to the facts of this case as the air conditioner was not 'adapted' for its use in the hotel room.  1995(II) CLR 70 & 1987 Lab.I.C. 1197 - Dist.						 [Para 11]

heading: Notification issued by Government of Maharashtra No.ESI-1875/800/PH-15, Clause 3
HeadNote.description: Notification issued by Government of Maharashtra No.ESI-1875/800/PH-15, Clause 3 - Scope and applicability of - Head Office of appellant in Pune having only 8 employees - Act not applicable to the Head Office and consequently it could not be made applicable to the branch offices, nor the persons employed in the Head Office and the persons employed in branch offices would be clubbed together for applying the provisions of the Act. 2000(1) LLJ (SC) 1 - Referred to.	(Para 4)

heading: Factories
HeadNote.description: Factories - Scope and applicability of E.S.I. Act - Provision of E.S.I. Act applicable in respect of factories by virtue of S.1(4) of the Act. AIR 1993 SC 252 - Rel. on.	(Paras 8 & 9)

heading: Writ jurisdiction
Alternate remedy
HeadNote.description: Writ jurisdiction - Alternate remedy - Petitioners having remedy of filing proceedings before E.S.I./Labour Court for determination of disputes in relation to questions or disputes arising under the Act - It is impermissible for the petitioner to raise the challenge before two different forums - Petitioners approaching Writ Court without disclosing the fact of pendency of proceedings before E.S.I. Court - Material defect as regards withholding of vital facts from the Court by the Petitioners - Petition dismissed. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 793 - Ref. to.			(Para 22)

heading: Applicability of Act
Petrol pump
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Petrol pump - Pumping oil is manufacturing process within meaning of S.2(k) of Factories Act - Object and intention of ESIC Act need not be considered in view of language used in S.2(k)(ii) of Factories Act which is clear enough - Hence, Act applies to petrol pump and notice for making contribution was valid.	(Paras 9-11)

heading: ESI contribution
Failure to pay
HeadNote.description:
ESI contribution - Failure to pay - Levy of damages S.85-B does not envisage imposition of damages in all situations.

Section 85-B of the Act empowers the Corporation to recover damages in the event an employer fails to make the payment of the amount due in respect of contribution; subject, however, to the condition that the amount thereof would not exceed the amount of arrears as may be specified in the Regulations.  Proviso appended thereto incorporates the principles of 'Natural Justice'.	 [Para 11]

An employee being required to be compulsorily insured, the employer is bound to make his part of the contribution.  An employee is also bound to make his contribution under the Act.  But the same does not mean that levy of damages in all situations would be imperative.  Section 85-B of the Act uses the words 'may recover'.  Levy of damages thereunder is by way of penalty.  The Legislature limited the jurisdiction of the authority to levy penalty, i.e., not exceeding the amount of arrears.  Regulation 31-C of the Regulations, therefore, in our opinion, must be construed keeping in view the language used in the Legislative Act and not de hors the same.   [Para 13,14]

A penal provision should be construed strictly.  Only because a provision has been made for levy of penalty, the same by itself would not lead to the conclusion that penalty must be levied in all situations.  Such an intention on the part of the legislature is not decipherable from Section 85-B of the Act.  When a discretionary jurisdiction has been conferred on a statutory authority to levy penal damages by reason of an enabling provision, the same cannot be construed as imperative.  Even otherwise, an endeavour should be made to construe such penal provisions as discretionary, unless the statute is held to be mandatory in character.		 [Para 17]

heading: Levy of penalty
Failure to pay
Damages
HeadNote.description: Levy of penalty - Failure to pay - Damages - Existence of mens rea or actus reus to contravene a statutory provision is necessary ingredient for levy thereof of damages and quantum.	(Para 21)

heading: "Shop"
Economic activity
HeadNote.description: "Shop" - Scope and applicability of ESI Act - Economic activity - Respondent-Society rendering services to the members which are domestic in nature like operating lifts, water supply, electricity, cleaning, sweeping and security - Held, these services are essential for the very existence and security of its members and society building - They are in the nature of personal services and cannot be said to be economic activity - Such services would not make the respondent-society a "shop" - Therefore, impugned order holding that respondent-society is covered by E.S.I. Act is liable to be set aside. 2007(1) ALL MR 645 & 2004(6) SCC 191 - Ref. to.	(Para 51)

heading: Notification dt.18-9-1978, Item 3
HeadNote.description: Notification dt.18-9-1978, Item 3 - Unless extended and made applicable specifically by notification and/or by any other mode, the society and/or such companies cannot be treated as an establishment as defined - Held, respondent/societies/companies do not fall within the purview of the said notification and, therefore, respondents/societies are not amenable to the provisions of the Act.			(Para 36)

heading: Word "shop"
HeadNote.description: Notification dt.18-9-1978, Item 3(iii) - Word "shop" - Societies where no economic activity is carried out - Cannot be taken under the umbrella of the word "shop" to extend the provisions of E.S.I. Act - Notification mentions the word "shop" and not the "society" - Shops and societies are two words with different and distinct meaning in all respects.	(Para 47)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Contribution payable by employer - Determination of - Insurance Corporation must give reasonable hearing opportunity to employer before such determination.

heading: Contribution by employer
Determination of
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Contribution by employer - Determination of - Number of employees employed in establishment - Burden of proof - Burden lies on Employer and not on the Corporation to prove number of employees - Ascertainment of such number automatically decides about applicability of the Act to such establishment.

heading: Contribution of Employer
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Contribution of Employer - Determination of - On show cause notice being issued employer denied applicability of the Act to his establishment - No evidence adduced supporting such denial - Corporations' reminder remained unreplied - Determination of Contribution on basis of available material - Is justified. (Para 7)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Substantial question of law - Question whether managing director, Sweepers, Cleaners, Liftman and Car cleaners were employees are not is a question of fact and not a substantial question of law - Appeal not maintainable (obiter) (Para 6)

heading: Employees
Contract of service
Essentials
HeadNote.description:
Employees - Contract of service - Essentials - On facts held sweepers, cleaners and liftman whose services were availed of by establishments situate in one floor of the rented premises in a big building were not 'employees' within S.2(9).

The four indicia of a contract of service are, (a) the masters power of selection of his servant, (b) the payment of wages or other remuneration, (c) the master's right to control the method of doing the work, and (d) the master's right of suspension or dismissal. 1946(62)TLR, 427(429) Relied on.  [Para 10]

In the present case the evidence shows that the sweepers/the cleaners, and the liftmen are engaged by M/s Liberty Cinema who are either the owners or the landlords of a multistoreyed building, on a portion of the 4th floor of which the Respondent has its establishment in a tenanted premises. The part-time employees such as the sweepers/the cleaners, and the liftmen of the building were common for all the tenants. They were being paid by M/s Liberty Cinema, the owners of the building. May be by way of tips or gratuitous payments the Respondent might be paying those staff members some regular amounts against vouchers. Those amounts are very meagre. To the liftmen, the Respondent paid Rs.25/- per month and to the sweeper/cleaner the Respondent paid Rs.80/- per month. On this evidence it would be just not possible to find that the Respondent has a power of selection of the sweeper/th cleaner, or the liftman. The Respondent also could not be said to have a right to control the method by which the sweepers/the cleaners and the liftmen would do their work and certainly by no stretch of logic it could be said that the Respondent has a right of suspension or dismissal over the sweepers/the cleaners and the liftmen. Out of the four indicia at least three are not satisfied in this case. So far as the Respondent is concerned, the sweepers/the cleaners and the liftmen cannot be said to be the employees within the meaning of that word as defined in Section 2(9) of the Act.  [Para 11]

heading: Employee
Car cleaner
HeadNote.description: Employee - Car cleaner - Casual service rendered by car cleaner for a paltry sum of Rs.60/- per month - He cannot be considered as an employee. (Para 12)

heading: Managing Director of a company would be a principal employer and not an 'employee' of the company. 1985 Lab. I.C.1318 Relied on. (Paras 13,14)
HeadNote.description: Managing Director of a company would be a principal employer and not an 'employee' of the company. 1985 Lab. I.C.1318 Relied on. (Paras 13,14)

heading: Freight charges
HeadNote.description:
Freight charges - Activity of loading and unloading of medicines is regular in business of respondent - Respondent engages hamalies for said activity - Activity is conducted under supervision of respondent - It is not evidence of respondent's witness that hamalies are engaged by any 3rd person - Not that hamalies hired are not particular individuals - Hamalies will have to be treated as employees within meaning of S.2(9) - Demand of freight charges by appellant cannot be denied.

1996 (9) SCC 644 Rel. on.

1989 II CLR 229, 2002 II CLR 349 Ref. to. 		 [Para 7]

heading: Repair and maintenance charges
HeadNote.description: Repair and maintenance charges - Demand made by appellant - Memorandum directing that where employer is unable to give details for payment made towards labour charges - Regional Director could fairly determine contribution of 25% of total amount of bills - ESI Court found that Regional Director had assumed total amount of bills for recovery of contribution - Order is non speaking order - ESI Court set it aside with liberty to appellant to pass fresh order of determination of claim under S.45A - Order upheld. 	(Para 8)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Jurisdiction of High Court in appeal under S.82 is restricted to finding out if E.S.I. Court has committed substantial error of law - High Court cannot re-appreciate evidence with a view to finding faults with appreciation of evidence made by E.S.I. Court - Correctness of findings recorded by E.S.I. Court on evidence before it cannot be gone into.

Held that on the evidence on record, the Court below has found ample justification for clubbing the two units, viz. the Appellant and the Private Limited Co. for the purpose of covering the Appellant under the Act.  No exception is possible to be taken to that view of the court below for the court below has not committed any error of law far less a substantial error of law in reaching those findings and conclusions.

AIR 1962 SC 1314, AIR 1979 SC 798 and L. & A. No.97 of 1985 in F.A.No.445 of 1984(Bom) followed.  [Para 10,11,20,22]

heading: Clubbing two units
HeadNote.description:
Clubbing two units - Firm converted into Private Ltd. Co. which came to be registered in June 1962 - Clubbing appellant, a proprietary concern, with Private Ltd. Co. from 18th April 1959 - On facts, held, order was unsustainable.

In the instant case, the court below has quite properly borne in mind the tests for deciding whether the two units form part of but one establishment and, the view expressed by the court below about justification being there for clubbing the Appellant a proprietary concern of with the Private Limited Co. is unexceptionable.  [Para 24]

The contention on behalf of the appellant that the Respondent has passed orders about clubbing of the Private Limited Co. and the Appellant with effect from 18th April 1959 while M/s Modern Textile Rayon and Silk Mills Pvt. Ltd. as a Private Limited Co. came to be registered in June 1962 and therefore no orders clubbing the Private Limited Co. with the Appellant could be passed effective from 18th April 1959 cannot be accepted. True, M/s. Modern Textile Rayon and Silk Mills Pvt. Ltd. came to be incorporated as the Private Limited Co. in June 1962.  But prior thereto there was a partnership firm in the name of Modern Textiles of which Mr.A.C.Shah was the partner right from the beginning and the Private Limited Co. took over that firm (Modern Textiles) as a going concern.  Therefore whether it was Modern Textiles, a firm or whether it was M/s Modern Textile Rayon and Silk Mills Pvt. Ltd., a Private Limited Co, the existence of that unit or that establishment or that body admittedly is there since prior to 18th April 1959 in one form or the other.  True, under law a company is distinct from its members or directors.  A company is distinct from a firm which it has taken over as a going concern.  Nonetheless in the present case we are only concerned with the invocation of the principle of clubbing for the purpose of covering the Appellant under the provisions of the Act.   For that purpose, only the number of employees working with the Private Limited Co. or the erstwhile firm M/s Modern Fabrics would be the relevant factor and that number of employees would not in any manner be affected merely by the firm m/s Modern Fabrics getting converted into the Private Limited Co.  Therefore there is no warrant for saying that the Appellant could not have been clubbed with the Private Limited Co. from 18th April 1959 though of course the Private Limited Co. came into existence as a company only in June 1962.  Prior to 1962 there existed a firm M/s Modern Fabrics, of which Mr.A.C.Shah was admittedly a partner.  In Private Limited Co. Mr.A.C.Shah is the Managing Director.  Under these circumstances, the argument on behalf of the Appellant that in any view of the matter the Appellant could not have been clubbed with the Private Limited Co. with effect from 18th April 1959 is required to be rejected.  [Para 25]

heading: Trial court on evidence holding that three units could be clubbed together to constitute one factory within meaning of S.2(12)
HeadNote.description:
Trial court on evidence holding that three units could be clubbed together to constitute one factory within meaning of S.2(12) - Held, High Court could not re-appreciate evidence as no question of law and much less substantial question of law arose - Held further that in concluding that three establishments  owned by different persons constituted  one factory no irrelevant or erroneous test was applied by trial court.

On the basis of pleadings and appreciation of evidence on record, the trial Court has concluded and held that the three units could be clubbed together to constitute one factory within the meaning of S.2(12) of the Act.  It is not possible to reappreciate the evidence on record in order to record a finding of facts, even if it is assumed for the sake of argument that the trial Court was wrong in appreciating the evidence on record, that cannot amount to any question of law and far less a substantial question of law to sustain this appeal under 82(2) of the Act.  Since involvement of any substantial question of law has not been demonstrated in the appeal, it is liable to be dismissed on this ground alone.  [Para 8]

No test to club different units in one factory within the meaning of 2(12) of the Act is conclusive and all the tests as laid down by the Delhi High Court in the case of Peter Sewing Machine Company reported in AIR 1970 Delhi 182 need not be satisfied.  In the facts of the case, the trial Court was justified in treating the three establishments owned by the different persons as one factory within the meaning of 2(12) of the Act and in so concluding no irrelevant or erroneous test has been applied by the trial Court.

Case law discussed.  [Para 11]

heading: Delay in demanding contribution
HeadNote.description:
Delay in demanding contribution - On facts held there was not gross delay.

The insurance Inspector of the Respondent had occasionally visited the Appellant between the years 1962 and 1972.  However, the letter calling upon the Appellant to get it registered under the provisions of the Act with effect from 1st April 1962 was addressed on 4th June, 1975.  The Appellant had informed the Respondent that the said three units could not be clubbed together to constitute one factory within the meaning of 2(12) of the Act.  Thereafter, the letters were issued to recover particular amount of contribution from the Appellant in respect of the period from 1st April 1972 to 30th June 1973 and from 1st July 1973 to 31st December 1974.  In the facts of the case, it is not possible to hold that there was gross delay on the part of the Respondent in raising the demand upon the Appellant.  Though reliance was placed on the case of KT Rolling Mills Pvt.Ltd. decided by this Court wherein it has been held that the proceedings under Section 14B Employees' Provident Funds and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 1952 initiated in 1986 in respect of delay in payment of contributions for the period commencing from July 1968 to October 1977 were liable to be quashed on the ground of delay even though the Act was a social welfare legislation, the Supreme Court has reversed the said decision of this Court.  As held by the Supreme Court there can be no dispute in law that when a power is conferred by statute without mentioning the period within which it could be invoked, the same has to be done within reasonable period, as all powers must be exercised reasonably and the exercise of the same within reasonable period would be fact of reasonableness.  However, the facts stated hereinabove go to show that there was no gross delay on the part of the Respondent in exercise of power in demanding contribution from the Appellant.

AIR 1995 SC 943 and 1993 Mah L.J. 947 Referred.  [Para 12]

heading: Certiorari
HeadNote.description:
Certiorari - Order of Employees Insurance Court - No substantial question of law involved - No appeal against the order maintainable - Party aggrieved cannot get a right of appeal indirectly by filing a writ petition under Art.226.

If there is no substantial question of law in that case how even a writ petition would lie under the extra ordinary jurisdiction of Article 226 of the Constitution of India.  If the legislature has denied an ordinary remedy of appeal and has given a very limited or restricted right of appeal, a party aggrieved cannot get a right of appeal indirectly by filing a writ petition under Article 226.  The legislature in its wisdom has made the decisions of the EI Court conclusive and Court cannot undermine the legislative wisdom by allowing a party to adopt a backdoor method of giving challenge to such decisions through Article 226 of the Constitution of India, which is an extra ordinary remedy and which cannot be reduced or converted as an optional or alternative remedy for a substantive appeal which is legislatively denied, except where there is a substantial question of law involved. [Para 5]

heading: Appeal
What is
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Substantial question of law - What is - A Perverse order would involve a substantial question of law and would be appealable under S.82(2).

A perverse order would involve a substantial question of law and would be appealable under section 82(2) of the ESI Act.  To construe that an order passed by the EI Court which suffers from such serious infirmity of perversity and pulpable absence of evidence is not an appealable order, would create havoc to say the least.  Such an order would certainly affect the basic rights of the parties to get a decision on the basis of the evidence adduced by them before the court and it is the fundamental duty of any adjudicating court to consider such evidence and record its findings after giving cogent reasons for its decision or conclusion.  If such adjudicating authority fails to record reasons in its order for its conclusions it would certainly be a perverse order.  If such an adjudicating authority has no evidence of any nature at all and still it records a finding one way or the other which is not supported by any evidence, it would also be a perverse order and can be challenged in an appeal on the ground of substantial question of law.  A finding contrary to the evidence or material on record would also be perverse.  It is not open to any party to by-pass the statutory appeal provided under the ESI Act and to rush to take resort to the extra ordinary remedy under Article 226 of the Constitution of India.		 [Para 6]

heading: New buildings
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - New buildings - Provisions of E.S.I. Act are applicable even to new buildings. (Para 11)

heading: Employees
Distinguished.						 [Para 16,24]
HeadNote.description:
Employees - Persons engaged by contractors for work of Construction - Work not carried out elsewhere away from the factory or establishment of the appellant, but it was carried out very much within the premises of the appellant apparently under immediate gaze or overseeing of the appellant or its agents - Persons are the employees within the meaning of S.2(9)(ii) of E.S.I. Act - Appellant is liable to pay contribution under the provisions of E.S.I. Act.

In the present case the work of construction was not carried out elsewhere away from the factory or establishment of the appellant, but it was carried out very much within the premises of the appellant apparently under the immediate gaze or overseeing of the appellant or its agents. As such the judgment in Subhash Chandra Bose case is not helpful to the case of the appellant.

Thus there is no difficulty in holding that the persons engaged by the contractors in the present case are the employees within the meaning of Section 2(9)(ii) of ESI Act the contractors being immediate employer within the meaning of Section 2(13) and the appellant being principal employer within the meaning of Section 2(17) of ESI Act. It, therefore, follows that the appellant is liable to pay contribution under the provisions of ESI Act.  (1992)1 SCC 441 - Distinguished.						 [Para 16,24]

heading: Appeal under
HeadNote.description:
Appeal under - Lies against such order as is enforceable as if it is a decree.

An appeal lies against such order which is enforceable as if it is a decree passed in a suit by a Civil Court.  Therefore, an appeal under section 82 of the Act shall lie against an order which has the characteristics of a decree.  Such orders could be only those orders passed under section 75 of the Act which have flavour of or trapping of determination or adjudication of the rights and obligations of the parties.  Only such orders can be said to be appealable under section 82 of the Act and no other.  In the instant case, the appeal, therefore, is liable to be dismissed on the short count as not maintainable since impugned order of the E. I. Court does not have a status which can be equated with that of a decree passed in a suit by a Civil Court nor it has a force of a decree as understood in law.  [Para 22,23]

heading: Appellate Jurisdiction
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Appellate Jurisdiction - Powers of Appellate Court - Scope - Appellate Court is expected to confine itself to a substantial question of law and not intrude into questions of fact.

The appellate Court, in an appeal filed under section 82 of the Act, is expected to confine itself to a substantial question of law.  The appellate Court is not expected to introduce into the questions of fact.  The existence of a "substantial question of law", is the sine qua non for the exercise of appellate jurisdiction by the High Court.  The High Court can exercise its jurisdiction under section 82 only on the basis of substantial questions of law.

The order refusing to summon an additional witness is an order based on exercise of discretion in respect of procedural matter.  The impugned order is a speaking order, passed after hearing both parties, that too after taking into account all the facts and circumstances of the case.  The view taken is a reasonable and possible view sustainable on the material available.  Exercise of discretion by the Court below cannot be said to be perverse.  The appellant could neither highlight any substantial question of law nor could frame any substantial question of law in the memo of appeal.	 [Para 25,26]

heading:
Provisions compared and analysed.

The purport and object of both the statutes, for all intent and purport, is the same. In the proceedings initiated under S.45-A of ESI Act, an immediate employer or principal employer may also show that they are not liable to deposit any contribution on behalf of the employees as the establishment in question did not come within the purview thereof. The purpose of the proceedings, under both the Acts is to determine the amount due from any employer in respect of the employees under the statutory schemes. Both the Acts envisage compliance of principles of natural justice. The proviso to S.45-A of ESI Act provides for a statutory mandate of giving a reasonable opportunity of being heard. The quantum of amount due has to be determined in respect of all contract workers engaged by the contractors. The principal employer would be entitled to recover the contributions from the contractor; they being the immediate employers. Whereas under PEF Act, the principal employer is statutorily liable in terms of the provisions of the Act to comply with the provisions therein; in terms of ESI Act, the principal employer is entitled to recover the amount of contribution payable by the immediate employer for them. S.45-A ESI Act enables the appropriate authority to recover such dues both from
HeadNote.description:
Provisions compared and analysed.

The purport and object of both the statutes, for all intent and purport, is the same. In the proceedings initiated under S.45-A of ESI Act, an immediate employer or principal employer may also show that they are not liable to deposit any contribution on behalf of the employees as the establishment in question did not come within the purview thereof. The purpose of the proceedings, under both the Acts is to determine the amount due from any employer in respect of the employees under the statutory schemes. Both the Acts envisage compliance of principles of natural justice. The proviso to S.45-A of ESI Act provides for a statutory mandate of giving a reasonable opportunity of being heard. The quantum of amount due has to be determined in respect of all contract workers engaged by the contractors. The principal employer would be entitled to recover the contributions from the contractor; they being the immediate employers. Whereas under PEF Act, the principal employer is statutorily liable in terms of the provisions of the Act to comply with the provisions therein; in terms of ESI Act, the principal employer is entitled to recover the amount of contribution payable by the immediate employer for them. S.45-A ESI Act enables the appropriate authority to recover such dues both from - principal as also the immediate employer. It provides for an opportunity of hearing to both of them.			 [Para 12,14]

heading: Contribution
Impleading third parties
Dist.	 [Para 15,17,19]
HeadNote.description:
Contribution - Impleading third parties - In a dispute with regard to applicability of ESI Act as also the quantum, the Competent Authority has requisite jurisdiction to implead the third party or summon them before it to produce relevant documents.

In reply to a notice issued under S.45-A of ESI Act, on the premise that Appellant had not deposited ESI contribution, it stated that workmen concerned were engaged by contractors who would be in possession of relevant records in respect of concerned workmen. A prayer to implead such contractors as parties as immediate employers was rejected by the competent authority. High Court dismissed the writ petition challenging the rejection. Further appeal, Supreme Court held the dispute being both in regard to the applicability (of ESI Act) as also quantum the respondent authority had the requisite jurisdiction to implead the third party or summon them before it to produce all relevant documents. heading: Contribution
Failure to contribute
HeadNote.description:
Contribution - Failure to contribute - Prayer for impleading third parties - Opportunity of hearing.

Act - It would be immaterial if such a Director was a sleeping Director, assuming that there were such Directors or not. (1995)1 CLR 517 - Distinguished.	(Para 22)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Employees' State Insurance (General) Regulations (1950) - Goa, Daman and Diu Employees' State Insurance (Medical Benefit) Rules (1975) - Circular of Corporation dated 31.7.2015 - Extending benefit of Insurance Act and Scheme to all construction site workers - Challenge - On ground that earlier circular dated 14.6.1999 has excluded workers of construction industry from benefit of ESI Scheme, due to peculiar characteristics of industry and peculiar nature of employment and there is no change in said situation - It further stated that there is stay to the circular from Court - Circular issued on premise that there is no stay prohibiting benefit of ESI Scheme to construction site workers within jurisdictional area of ESIC, Goa region - Held, merely because in 1999 such workers were exempted, policy decision of Government to extend benefit to said workers on basis of subsequent development and representation received from various authorities, cannot be interfered with.

	The circular extending benefit of ESI scheme to construction site workers, issued by ESI Corporation on the foundation that there was no stay of any Court, prohibiting enforcement of ESI coverage of construction site workers within the jurisdictional areas of ESIC Goa Region and thereby reiterated that registration under the Insurance Act is mandatory once an unit is eligible for coverage and to obtain the ESI Code numbers through online registration as proposed. This was after due deliberations so as to provide all benefits to all types of workers/ employees as contemplated under the Insurance Act. The extension is by Circular dated 31/07/2015 by referring to the Notification dated 21st June, 1977 under Section 1(5) of Insurance Act whereby several establishments and factories were covered. So there is notification containing exemption clause whereby certain establishments have been excluded/ exempted from the purview of the Act. The clarification, so issued, in the year 1999 was definitely kept in mind and in view of the subsequent development and requirement, based upon the decision so taken and in view of the recommendations received from various sources, the Authorities have taken decision by following due procedure and unanimously ratified the decision of coverage of the ESI Scheme to the construction workers, in any way, cannot be stated to be beyond the scope, purpose and powers of the Insurance Act, Rules, Regulations and the Scheme made thereunder. 

	Merely because, earlier in the year 1999 the exemption was made and not extended by the Insurance Act to such workers, the policy decision was taken by the Government based upon the material and the prevailing situation, it needs no interference. No validity of any clause and/or the provisions are challenged by the Petitioners and even, otherwise, considering the Scheme and the purpose of the Insurance Act, we see that the Insurance Act, in no way, can be stated to be against the employers and/or it is only in favour of the employees. Both will be benefit if the Act is extended for the various purposes, as contemplated under the Insurance Act. There is no illegality and/or issue in extending the provisions to the employees/workers, being a welfare legislation.	 [Para 11,12]

heading: Employees' State Insurance (General) Regulations (1950)
HeadNote.description:
Employees' State Insurance (General) Regulations (1950) - Goa, Daman and Diu Employees' State Insurance (Medical Benefit) Rules (1975) - Building and Other Construction Workers (Regulation of Employment and Conditions of Service) Act (1996) - Building and Other Construction Workers' Welfare Cess Act (1996) - Applicability of ESI Act, 1948 - To construction site workers - Vide Circular of Corporation dated 31.7.2015 - Challenge by petitioners/Construction agency - Ground that workers are already getting benefits under BOCW Act, 1996 and BOCWWC Act, 1996 which are similar to Insurance Act - Petitioners further stated that BOCW Act being special legislation, circular is in conflict with it - However, requirement under BOCW Act to have workers insurance scheme itself shows that BOCW Act and Insurance Act both are different on various aspects and are not in conflict with each other - Mere registration of such construction agencies under different provisions for different purposes that itself is not reason to deny benefit of Insurance Act to concerned workers - Further, workers employed by construction agencies at various work sites are employees within meaning of Insurance Act - Policy decision of Government to extend benefit of ESI Scheme to construction workers, proper.

	It is unacceptable the submission that benefits under the Building and Other Construction Workers (Regulation of Employment and Condition of Service) Act, 1996 (for short "BOCW Act"), are available to the building and other construction workers with similar benefits, as it also covers the elements such as leave, sickness benefit, protection measures and others and therefore, that being a special legislation which covers the field with regard to the construction site workers and, therefore, the impugned extension/Circular is in conflict with and/or bad in law. Merely because the members of association have been registered under the BOCW Act and so also the site workers are required to make application for registration, that itself is not a sufficient reason to deny the extension of Insurance Act to such workers/employees. The purpose and object of both the Acts is different, so also the respective schemes. The requirement to have workers insurance scheme under the BOCW Act itself means both the Acts are different on various aspects and are not in conflict with each other. The conflict and/or benefit, even if are available under one Act, it is settled that the employees/workers are not entitled to two parallel and similar benefits. In our view, there is no conflict.

	Similarly, the Building and Other Construction Workers' Welfare Cess Act, 1996 ("BOCWWC Act") has again different aims and object to achieve. Merely because the members of association have been paying such cess at 1% since 1996 and have contributed a huge amount to the State exchequer by way of cess payments that by itself cannot be a reason to deny the benefits of the Insurance Act to the construction employees/workers. The BOCWW Act provides for the levy and collection of a cess on the cost of construction incurred by employers with a view to augment the resources of the Building and Other Construction Workers' Welfare Boards constituted under the BOCW Act. The submission, therefore, that the existence of these Acts is sufficient to achieve the aims, objects and purpose of the Insurance Act is also unacceptable and we decline to accept the submission that the nature of the benefits provided under the Insurance Act is also provided under the BOCW Act and the BOCWWC Act.	 [Para 12,13]

heading: Applicability of Act
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of Act - Would be a jurisdictional question - Any action taken prior to or in furtherance of a report made on an inspection, prior to coming into force of Act would be ultra vires S.45(2).

Before an Act is made applicable, in the event, a dispute is raised, the authorities exercising statutory power must determine the jurisdictional fact. Applicability of the Act would be a jurisdictional question.  The Employer is entitled to raise such a question before the appropriate authority.  Such a question can also be raised for the first time before a court exercising the power of judicial review although ordinarily the same should be raised before the concerned authority as a preliminary issue.  AIR 1963 SC 569 - Ref.						 [Para 18]

The scheme of the Act does not suggest that all the employees would come within the purview of the said Act.  Those employees who draw wages as is defined in Section 2(22) of the Act would be the employees who would be covered thereunder.  Inspection of the factories was carried out prior to the date of coming into force of the Act.  Such inspections, thus, could have been carried out only in terms of the provisions contained in Section 45 of the Act, which could mean that the Inspector would be appointed for the purpose of the Act.  He is authorized under the Act to enquire into the correctness of any of the particulars stated in any return referred to in Section 44 or for the purpose of ascertaining whether any of the provisions has been complied with.  It is, therefore, evident that any action taken prior to or in furtherance of a report made on an inspection, prior to coming into force of the Act, would be ultra vires Section 45(2) of the Act.  Once the inspection is held to be illegal, Respondent could not have taken any statutory action for imposition of penalty.  [Para 20]
