heading: Wages
Interpretation of definition
HeadNote.description:
Wages - Interpretation of definition - Considering that ESI Act is a welfare legislation, any ambiguous expression should be given a beneficent construction in favour of employees - Inclusive portion of definition is not intended to be limited only of items mentioned therein.

	The Employees' State Insurance Act is a welfare legislation. It has been enacted to protect and safeguard the rights of the working class. Its preamble states that it is meant to "provide for certain benefits to employees in case of sickness, maternity and 'employment injury' and to make provision for certain other matters in relation thereto". The Employees' State Insurance Fund set up under this Act survives primarily on contributions paid to the Employees' State Insurance Corporation. All employees insured in accordance with this Act are entitled to benefits under the Act. Undoubtedly, the literal meaning of statutory provisions cannot be ignored. However, in cases where there may be two or more ways to interpret a statutory provision, the spirit of this legislation warrants a construction that benefits the working class. The inclusive part and exclusive portion of the definition of "wages" clearly indicate that the expression "wages" has been given wider meaning. Under the definition, firstly whatever remuneration is paid or payable to an employee under the terms of the contract of the employment, expressed or implied, is "wages". Secondly, whatever payment is made to an employee in respect of any period of authorized leave, lock-out etc. is "wages". Thirdly, other additional remuneration, if any, paid at intervals not exceeding two months is also "wages". Any ambiguous expression should be given a beneficent construction in favour of employees by the Court. If the definition of "wages" is read in its entirety including the inclusive part as well as the exclusive portion, it appears that inclusive portion is not intended to be limited only of items mentioned therein, particularly, having regard to the objects and reasons for which the Employees' State Insurance Act is enacted. The Act has to be necessarily so construed as to serve its purpose and objects. (2000) 3 SCC 185, (1984) 4 SCC 324 Ref. to. 		 [Para 8]

Manufacturing process - Appellant running hotel with 16 employees - Appellant's witness in oral evidence states that kitchen, meals and snacks were being prepared - LPG gas is used as source of heat energy - Further, statement that there was deep freezer for preservation, chilling of food articles - Preparation of food in kitchen is manufacturing process - Raw food articles are altered, served with garnishing - These activities are well within definition of 'Manufacturing Process'. 
1993 (4) SCC 364, 1980 LAB I C 100, 2012(1) CLR 84, 2005 (4) LLN 149, 2001 (2) LL J Karnataka 973, 1995 (1) Mh.L.J. 63 Ref. to. (Paras 19, 22)

heading: Act being a beneficial social security legislation must receive a liberal construction so as to promote its objects.			(Paras 15, 16)
HeadNote.description: Act being a beneficial social security legislation must receive a liberal construction so as to promote its objects.			(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Employee
Scope of definition
HeadNote.description: Employee - Scope of definition - It would cover "casual employees" employed for a few days on a work of perennial nature - Wages defined in S.2(22) and wage period defined u/S.2(23), do not exclude wages payable to casual workers - They cannot be deprived of beneficial provisions of the Act.	(Para 8)

heading: Employer's contribution
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Applicability of ESI Act to Turf club - Agreement between Turf club and ESI to the effect that employees of certain departments would be covered under ESI Act w.e.f. 28/1/1968, while some other departments were not covered - After issuance of notification dt.18/9/1978 remaining departments also covered under ESI Act - Notification has statutory force and agreement cannot supersede it - No benefit can be derived by consent terms.	(Para 13)

heading: Employer's contribution
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Claim for - Made beyond period of 5 years - Is maintainable. (2007) 1 SCC 584 Foll. 	(Para 16)

heading: Employer's contribution
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Claim for - From 2.7.1977 till 30.6.1996 - Plea of irretrievable prejudice by employer on account of belated demand, since record for said period already destroyed - Employer paid contribution for disputed period under protest - Evidence of employer's witness shows that contribution for disputed period was calculated on basis of personal files and service cards of employees - Plea of irretrievable prejudice cannot be accepted - Employer liable to pay contribution. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Employer's contribution
Delay in payment
HeadNote.description: Employer's contribution - Delay in payment - Liability to pay interest on delayed contribution is statutory - It cannot be waived by Corporation. 2008 ALL SCR 1796 Rel. on. 	(Para 21)

heading: Demand for contribution
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Demand for contribution - Limitation - Right of Corporation to claim contribution cannot be restricted to a period of five years - Claim can be made by Corporation within a reasonable time. (2007) 1 SCC 584 Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Appeal
Permissible
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Addition, alteration or reframing of substantial question of law - Permissible - Restricting the power of hearing appeal only to substantial question of law initially framed, would amount to putting fetters on provision u/S.82 of ESI Act - Substantial question of law can be added or re-framed by Court if it is felt necessary during course of hearing, subject to grant of opportunity to contesting party to meet such substantial question of law. 

	Section 82(2) of the said Act stipulates that an appeal would lie to the High Court from the order of the Employees Insurance Court only if it involves a substantial question of law. To restrict an appeal that has been admitted by framing a substantial question of law only to said question despite the fact that during the course of hearing it transpires that either an additional substantial question of law arises or that the substantial question of law already framed is required to be re-framed would amount to putting fetters on the Court hearing an appeal under Section 82 of the said Act. The provisions of Section 82 do not restrict the hearing of an appeal only on a substantial question of law that has been framed while admitting the appeal. In fact, Section 82(2) of the said Act merely requires an appeal to give rise to a substantial question of law for the same to be entertained under said provision. In absence of any such bar in Section 82 of the said Act, there is no reason whatsoever to confine hearing of an appeal filed under Section 82 of the said Act to only those substantial questions of law that have been framed while admitting the appeal. On the contrary, the course as prescribed by provisions of Section 100(5) of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 can be followed. If during the course of hearing of an appeal under Section 82 of the said Act, it is found by the Court that the appeal gives rise to a substantial question of law that has not been framed earlier or that a substantial question of law already framed is required to be re-framed, such substantial question of law can always be framed/re-framed subject to grant of opportunity to the contesting party to meet such substantial question of law as framed/re-framed.	 [Para 8]

heading: Demand for contribution
HeadNote.description: Demand for contribution - Towards difference amount of certain payments - Challenge, on ground of non-consideration of relevant material - Corporation contending that relevant material not produced by employer - Whereas employer taking plea that relevant documents were provided to Corporation in course of personal hearing but said documents are no more available with it - Even though Note Sheet of Corporation containing no entry as to production of material by employer, there is a letter on record, addressed by Corporation, indicating personal hearing of employer and production of certain documents - If Corporation failed to maintain proper records, employer cannot be blamed for it - Order u/S.45A not sustainable - Liable to be set aside. 			(Para 13)

heading: Factory
Scope of definition
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Factory - Scope of definition - Restaurant employing 17 employees held to be covered under definition of Factory - Submission made that Govt. Notification dated 19.11.1976 issued u/S.1(5) of ESI Act states that hotels, restaurants and shops would be covered only if twenty persons are employed - Not acceptable - Once Statute itself specifically defined term for application of ESI Act on such restaurant/hotel, notification would certainly not override statutory definition.  1980 LabIC 100 Ref. to. 	(Para 23)

heading: 'Manufacturing process'
HeadNote.description: 'Manufacturing process' - Preparation of food items in establishment with use of LPG cooking gas, kerosene ovens and wet grinding machine run on electricity - Amounts to 'manufacturing process' as defined u/S.2(k) of ESI Act.  1980 LabIC 100, 2010(1) ALL MR 968 (S.C.), 2010(3) ALL MR 973 (S.C.) Ref. to.  (Para 18)

heading: Use of power
In manufacturing process
HeadNote.description: Use of power - In manufacturing process - Use of LPG cooking gas in Restaurant for preparing food articles - Amounts to use of power and therefore, would be covered under expression "manufacturing process being carried on with aid of power" as used in S.2(12)(a) of ESI Act.	 (Paras 20, 21)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Applicability of ESI Act - To establishment running restaurant - Determination - Establishment/Restaurant was found employing 17 employees and using LPG cooking gas, kerosene ovens and refrigerator for preparing food during inspection - Report was prepared by giving details of all employees with their signatures and which was also countersigned by son of proprietor - Process of preparing food items with use of LPG gas amounts to "manufacturing process" u/S.2(k) - Observation sheet and preliminary report placed by corporation are enough material to show that establishment was indeed covered in definition of "factory"- Son of proprietor not examined to show signatures and details given by him under misrepresentation or coercion - Merely by producing muster roll of its employees of July, 1992 showing only seven employees, cannot be said to be enough - No illegality in holding restaurant as covered under ESI Act.  1980 LabIC 100, 2010(1) ALL MR 968 (S.C.), 2010(3) ALL MR 973 (S.C.) Ref.to.  (Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, 21)

heading: Order demanding contribution by corporation
HeadNote.description: Order demanding contribution by corporation - Can be challenged by filing appeal u/S.45AA of ESI Act - Petitioner failed to cooperate with corporation despite order demanding contribution passed against him - Cannot be permitted to take advantage of its own deliberate acts of stalling and non co-operation in proceedings - Orders by corporation found not without jurisdiction - Writ petition against, cannot be entertained for examining merits of quantum of contribution determined by corporation. 	(Para 19)

heading: Offence under
Prosecution for
Rel. on.
HeadNote.description:
Offence under - Prosecution for - Late deposit of prescribed contributions by employer - Admittedly there was delay in filing return and making contributions - Acquittal on ground that persons who visited premises and factory as also person who submitted proposal for sanction were not examined - Held, such acquittal merely on technicalities hence improper - Liable to be set aside.	(Para 5,10)

AIR 1961 SC 1, 2000 Cr.L.J. 1401, (1979) 4 SCC 573, (1958) 1 LLJ 598, (2000) I CLR 372 - Rel. on.

heading: Offence under
Prosecution for
Acquittal improper
Rel.on.
HeadNote.description:
Offence under - Prosecution for - Acquittal on ground of non-mentioning of amounts in notice or complaint or sanction order - Acquittal improper - Set aside.			(Para 13)

AIR 1961 SC 1, 2000 Cr.L.J. 1401, (1979) 4 SCC 573, (1958) 1 LLJ 598, 2001 I CLR 372 - Rel.on.

heading: Visit note
HeadNote.description: Visit note - Challenge, on ground that Inspector who visited establishment did not mention full name of employees with their designation - No thumb rule that Inspector who had prepared inspection note has to mention complete name of employee along with designation, length of service, etc. - This aspect has to be considered factually - Proprietor of establishment has not led any evidence to disprove contents of visit note - Despite maintaining muster register and register of salaries, same was not produced in Court - In absence of any material brought to doubt visit note, it cannot be faulted merely on ground that complete name of each employee was not mentioned therein. 	(Para 8)

heading: Registration of establishment
HeadNote.description: Registration of establishment - Opportunity of hearing not required to be given to establishment when Corporation intended to cover establishment under provisions of Act of 1948.  1980 LIC 100 Rel. on. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Interpretation of provisions
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of provisions - ESI Act is a beneficial legislation providing for health insurance of workers - Liberal interpretation is to be given to the provisions so as to achieve legislative purpose without doing violence to the language of enactment.	(Paras 18, 22)

heading: Establishment
HeadNote.description:
Establishment - Race club, whether an "establishment" so as to be subject to ESI Act - Test to find out "establishment" is whether a professional activity is systematically and habitually undertaken for production or distribution of goods or services with the help of employees in an undertaking - Race club is covered by expression - Decision in Hyderabad Race Club case [(2004) 6 SCC 191] does not require reconsideration.

(1996) 2 SCC 226 Ref. to.	(Para 39)

heading: Notification u/s.1(5)
Using term "shop"
HeadNote.description: Notification u/s.1(5) - Using term "shop" - Turf club engaged in horse racing would fall under scope of term "shop" - Provisions of ESI Act would extend upon them by virtue of notifications issued u/s.1(5) of Act.	(Paras 49, 71, 72)

heading: Maharashtra Shops and Establishments Act (1948), Preamble
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Shops and Establishments Act (1948), Preamble - Statutes in pari materia - Held, ESI Act is not in pari materia with Shops and Establishments Act - Therefore, assistance cannot be taken in the context of one statute for interpretation from definition clause of another statute. 			(Paras 59, 60, 61, 62, 63, 64)

heading: Interpretation of Notification
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Notification - Use of the term "namely" followed by description of business activities - Implies that the Notification seeks to enlist classes of establishments falling within purview of ESI Act - Narrow interpretation not to be given for said reason.

(1992) 4 SCC 245 Rel. on.			(Paras 67, 68, 69, 70)

heading: Notification u/s.1(5)
Using term "shop"
HeadNote.description: Notification u/s.1(5) - Using term "shop" - Appellant Chit Fund provides for services and in return the foreman receives commission - Held, activities of Chit Fund would fall within meaning of "shop" - Provisions of ESI Act would apply.			(Paras 86, 87)

heading: Manufacturing process
HeadNote.description:
Manufacturing process - Cooking of food stuffs in the kitchen of Gymkhana club - More than twenty persons working in the kitchen where refrigerator, geyser and other equipments were used for preparation of food articles with the help of power - Food stuffs were served to members of club and their guests for payments - Held, the club would come within meaning of 'factory' u/S.2(12) of the Act though it was a non-profit making organization. 

The object of ESI Act is to provide certain benefits to the employees in case of sickness, maternity and employment injury and also to make provision for certain other matters in relation thereto. ESI Act is a beneficial piece of social welfare legislation aimed at securing the well-being of the employees and the court will not adopt a narrow interpretation which will have the effect of defeating the objects of the Act. 				     [Para 18]

Even though the term "kitchen", "catering" of a club may not be called a factory in common parlance, having regard to the definition of "manufacturing process" and that ESI Act is a beneficial legislation, a liberal interpretation has to be adopted. Therefore, so long as manufacturing process is carried on with or without the aid of power by employing more than twenty persons for wages, it would come within the meaning of "factory" as defined under Section 2(12) of the ESI Act. The contention that the appellant-club is a non-profit making organization would not take away the same from the purview of the Act.

(2000) 1 SCC 332, (1992) 4 SCC 245 Rel.on. 				         [Para 20,25]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Order holding that club is covered under provisions of the Act passed on 4.8.86 demanding payment of contribution from 1-2-80 onwards - Held, appellant-club has not paid the ESI contribution of its employees for more than three decades and is not justified in seeking for prospective operation of the order. 			(Para 26)

heading: Factory
HeadNote.description: Factory - Whether hospital having Pathological Laboratory which caters for indoor and outside patients, is factory within meaning of S.2(12)(a) of ESI Act - Respondent-Scientific Research Institute carries out research activities and runs hospital for indoor and outdoor treatment - Authority hold respondent-institute under coverage of ESI Act on premise that pathology department of hospital carried activities of blood tapping, collecting cross machine and bottling with aid of power, which amount to manufacturing - No case that hospital is collecting blood samples with view to its use, sale, transport, delivery or disposal - Mere receiving blood samples, examining them and issuing reports would not amount to 'manufacturing process' as defined u/S.2(k) - Submission that hospital is earning profit by examining blood samples, cannot be considered in absence of material indicating usage of blood for any of purposes - Therefore, respondent-institute would not be covered under ESI Act. 2005 (106) FLR 1029, 2006-II-LLJ 443 Rel. on. 	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Manufacturing process
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing process - Drawing of blood sample for diagnosis did not include treating or adapting it with view to its use, sale etc - In absence of further use of blood as 'drug' by hospital, process resorted by them would not amount to any 'manufacturing process' as defined in S.2(k). 2006-II-LLJ 443 Rel. on. 	(Para 21)

heading: Applicability of Act
HeadNote.description: Notification No ESI 1677/3910/P11-15 Dt 18-9 1978, Sch. Col.1 Entry 3 - Applicability of Act - Employment of 20 employees in factory/establishment - Not enough for applicability of Act - All the 20 employees must be drawing wages less than the prescribed limit. AIR 1999 SC 803 Foll. 	(Para 22)

heading: Applicability of Act
Burden to disprove
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Act - Burden to disprove - Corporation demanding contribution on ground that respondent-establishment along with its branches employed more than 20 employees - Claim by respondent that some of employees draw wages above prescribed limit - Burden to prove its claim is on respondent as knowledge of wages paid is with respondent. 	(Para 27)

heading: Exemption of persons or class of persons
HeadNote.description: Exemption of persons or class of persons - Held, State Government is empowered to exempt "class of persons employed in any factory or establishment, or class of factories or establishments, to which the Act is applicable" - It does not restrict application of the exemption to a particular place - S.88 does not refer to a place pertaining to exemption - However, S.87 refers to the exemption in respect of any specific area. 2001(I) CLR 38 - Ref. to.		(Para 18)

heading: "Shop"
What is
HeadNote.description: "Shop" - What is - Company registered u/s.25 of the Companies Act performing function similar and akin to co-operative housing society such as collecting maintenance, charges from the lessee members to whom premises have been allotted on rent - Held, such companies cannot be said to be a "shop"within the meaning of the said notification. 1993(II) LLJ 795 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Para 48)

heading: Liability of principal employer
HeadNote.description: Liability of principal employer - Primary duty of principal employer is to pay not only employer's contribution but also the employee's contribution - Principal employer also is required to maintain certain record. AIR 1993 SC 1530 (A) - Followed.	(Paras 27 & 28)

heading: Scope
Power is discretionary
HeadNote.description:
Default in payment of contribution by employers - Power of Corporation to impose/levy damages - Scope - Though it is penal in nature - Power is discretionary - It is not to be exercised mechanically without giving opportunity or considering mitigating circumstances put forth by defaulting Employer - Deduction of contribution from wages of employers - Cannot be a sole ground to levy maximum damages.

In case of failure of employer to pay the amount due in respect of any contribution payable under the Act, or any other amount payable under this Act, it is not obligatory on the part of the Corporation to impose levy or recover damages.  The power to impose damages is discretionary.  The section does not empower the authority to recover minimum amount of damages from the defaultating employer.  The intention of the legislature seems to have been that in deserving cases considering the plea set up by the defaulting employers, authority can dispense with in its totality, the amount of damages or scale it down considering the fact-situation of the case.  The power to levy and recover the damages provided under Section 85(B) of the Act is in the nature of penal provision.  The proviso of section 85(B) does indicate that before recovering such damages the employer should be given reasonable opportunity of being heard and the adjudication in the matter is contemplated.  Since the failure to carry out this statutory obligation is provided with the adjudicatory forum and the levy of damages is penal in character.  Such damages shall not ordinarily be imposed unless the defaulting employer acted intentionally or in defiance of law or guilty of dishonest conduct or acted in conscious disregard of its obligation.  The circumstances, if are beyond the control of defaulting employer it shall have to be given due consideration by the authority.  On mere failure of the defaulting employer, Corporation is not empowered to recover damages mechanically without taking into account the facts and circumstances of each case.  While levying the damages by resorting to section 85(B), the authority has to record the finding, that the due opportunity was given to the defaulting employer and after considering mitigating circumstances putforth by the defaulting employer the order is passed.  The deduction of the contribution from the wages of the employees, cannot be a sole ground to punish the employers with maximum levy of damages.  The proviso which is appended to section 85(B), mandates an opportunity of hearing to the erring employers.  If the scheme of section 85(B) in its entirety is taken into consideration, the damages seem to be in penal nature.  Section contemplates levy of damages by the authority under the provisions of the said Act, 1948 after hearing the employer.  The question of payment of contribution as well as payment of interest in accordance with the scheme of the said Act, 1948 and the Employees' State Insurance (General) Regulations, 1950 has no relevance so far as to levy of damages is concerned.  However, equally it is important that the authority i.e. Regional Director has to apply his mind while dealing with the alleged mitigating circumstances and/or ground raised by the erring employer.  The nature of damages being penal, the authority is armed with the powers to levy the damages and/or waive the damages.  [Para 13,14]

heading: Default in payment of contribution by employer
HeadNote.description: Default in payment of contribution by employer - Non consideration of mitigating circumstances by Regional Director - Insurance Court is competent to adjudicate and pass appropriate order in appeal.	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: 'Power'
HeadNote.description: 'Power' - Use of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) - Establishment preparing sweets etc. with use of LPG - LPG cylinder would qualify as appliance which provides power - Gas travels from cylinder where it is stored to the cooking stove - It involves a valve mechanism or a regulator to ensure smooth flow - Hence use of LPG satisfies definition of power as it is mechanically transmitted without involvement of human or animal agency. Factories Act (1948), S.2(g).	(Paras 31-33)

heading: Determination of contribution
HeadNote.description: Determination of contribution - Second proviso introduced by 2010 Amendment in S.45A(I) of ESI Act - Restrict power of corporation to pass order for determination of contribution u/S.45A only for period of 5 years from date it becomes payable and not beyond that - It cannot be read to mean that if 5 years time period lapses, no order can be passed by, corporation for determination of contribution - Order dt.18.1.2016 demanding contribution by corporation for period of December 2010 to March 2015 - Covers period less than five years from date on which contribution become payable i.e. from order dt.14.12.2010 - Said order, held, was not hit by proviso. 			(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Bar under S.53
HeadNote.description: Claim for compensation under S.173 - Bar under S.53 - Motor Accident Claims Tribunal directed to work out entitlement for compensation by taking note of S.53 of the Employees' State Insurance Act. 1993 Suppl.(4) SCC 100, 1996(4) SCC 255 and 2003(2) SCC 138 - Rel. on.	(Para 9)

heading: Market Committee
"Shop"
HeadNote.description:
Market Committee - "Shop" - Application of ESI Act - Even if market committee is considered as a local authority for the purpose of APMC Act, it cannot be taken out of the application of ESI Act ipso facto - Market Committee is "Shop" under ESI Act.

Although under section 12(2) of the APMC Act, a Market Committee is declared to be a local authority for all purposes, there is no provision in the ESI Act excluding local authorities from its application.  In the Delhi Development Authority's case, under the Payment of Bonus Act itself the employees of the local authorities were excluded from the coverage of Bonus Act.  Under the ESI Act there is no such exclusion.  Thus, even if the petitioner Market Committee is considered as a local authority for the purpose of the APMC Act, it cannot be taken out of the application of the ESI Act ipso facto.

It cannot be disputed that the APMC is carrying on a systematic economic and commercial activity and renders services.  Hence, although the APMC Act declares the Market Committee to be a local authority under that Act, it will have to be held as covered under the definition of shop under the ESI Act.  1993 II CLR 1068 and (1992)4 SCC 245 - Followed 	 [Para 10,16]

heading: Accident
Employment injury
HeadNote.description:
Accident - Employment injury - Employee receiving compensation under E.S.I. Act - Cannot claim any other benefit under Motor Vehicles Act.

In the instant case, the respondent No.1 came to the place of employment by the bus provided by the employer, and after working hours were over, she went to the place outside the factory to go by some bus provided by the employer to take her back either to her residence or to pick up point near her residence. Considering Section 51(C) and one judgment of the Bombay High Court reported in 1995 ACJ 1087, it is a clear cut case of employment injury and therefore the contention of the counsel for the appellants that Tribunal had no jurisdiction is required to be accepted. Secondly, also when the respondent No.1 had received compensation under the ESI Act then she cannot claim any other benefit under the Motor Vehicles Act. Both these important aspects of the matter going to the root of the case were either ignored by the Tribunal or were not properly considered and therefore the Tribunal came to a wrong conclusion. The conclusions are perverse and against the provisions of law, they are required to be set aside.  [Para 17,18]

heading: Federal Society
HeadNote.description:
Federal Society - Grant of exemption from operation of ESI Act - Held, the internal co-operation and the motto "all for one and one for all" is the backbone of the co-operative movement - It is of common knowledge that the Government is expected to endeavour for giving booster dose to the co-operative movement in the State - The exemption granted from operation of the ESI Act is one kind of endeavour of the State Government to give helping hand to the appellants - It is within the powers of the State Government to grant exemption from operation of the ESI Act.

The internal co-operation and the motto "all for one and one for all" is the backbone of the co-operative movement. It is of common knowledge that the Government is expected to endeavour for giving booster dose to the co-operative movement in the State. The exemption granted from the operation of the ESI Act is one kind of endeavour of the State Government to give helping hand to the appellants. It is within the powers of the State Government to grant exemption from operation of the ESI Act. There cannot be duality of opinion that the ESI Act is a socially beneficial legislation. At the same time, in parallel field, the co-operative sector also is being given due support by way of subsidies or exemptions as permissible under the Government policies. It is also a social welfare legislation. In keeping with such intention of the Government while issuing notification in question, held, that mere reference in the Government Notification that it would be applicable to the appellant No.1, with reference to the address given of the Head Office, would not disentitle the appellant No.2 from claiming such exemption. Nor the fact that in the past contribution of the E.S.I. amount was made by the appellant No.2 will operate as estoppel from seeking exemption from legal liability to pay the same. It cannot be said that the appellant No.2 is a completely separate and segregated unit without having any nexus with the business of the appellant No.1. 2001(88) FLR 347 & 2000(84) FLR 869 - Ref. to.						 [Para 22]

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Termination of services of probationer - Setting aside by trial court - Appeal against - Trial court while decreeing the suit declaring action of corporation as unlawful could not have granted several reliefs of pay scale etc.	(Paras 35, 36)

heading: Insurance claim
Liability of employer
HeadNote.description: Insurance claim - Liability of employer - Claimant claiming that employer is liable to pay compensation to claimant as deceased was not told that insurance policy was applicable only in case of accidental death - Employer was acting as mediator for depositing premium of employees with insurance company and had no liability under insurance policy - However, as deceased died while on duty, liability of employer would be under Employees’ Compensation Act, 1923 - Proceedings under Act of 1923 already settled by Commissioner - Employer not liable to pay compensation under insurance policy. (2002) 3 CPJ 64 (NC) Disting. 	(Paras 13, 17)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Claim for by legal heirs of deceased-cleaner who was murdered - On ground that death of deceased occurred during course of employment - Deceased was alleged to be murdered by driver of truck while they were on truck - It was not established that driver of truck and owner of truck were lastly in company of deceased and deceased was with truck when murdered - Death of deceased cannot be said to be incidental to employment - Claimants not entitled to compensation. 	(Paras 11, 12)

headline: Provison as to filing of certificate of deposit of compensation amount along with memorandum of appeal at behest of employer, is applicable to appeal by insurer.

heading: Appeal by insurer
Necessity of
HeadNote.description:
Appeal by insurer - Filing of certificate of deposit of amount of compensation along with memorandum of appeal - Necessity of - Third proviso to S.30(1) mandates filing of certificate of deposit of amount of compensation along with memorandum of appeal at behest of employer - Third proviso to S.30(1) is equally applicable to appeal by insurer - It is necessary for insurer to file certificate of deposit of compensation along with appeal, otherwise appeal would not be maintainable.
Employee’s Compensation Act is a beneficial Legislation, whereby interest of the employee is sought to be protected. The object of adding third proviso to S. 30(1), is to ensure the compliance of the award passed by the Commissioner for Employee’s Compensation in the event of dismissal of the Appeal filed by the employer, so that the employee is not required to run from pillar to post for getting the amount of compensation for years together. The literal interpretation of the term ‘Employer’ as suggested by learned Counsel for the Appellant is bound to lead to an anamolous situation, where though the employer is required to deposit the amount of compensation before filing an appeal against the award and file certificate of deposit along with memorandum of Appeal, but the Insurer, if chooses to file an Appeal against the same award becoming liable to pay the compensation on account of a contract of insurance between the employer and the Insurer, can file Appeal without depositing the amount of compensation and without certificate of deposit. This could never be the intention of the Legislature while adding third proviso to S. 30(1), of the Act of 1923. Consequently, it is held that the third proviso to S. 30(1) of the Act of 1923 requiring the Employer to accompany certificate of deposit from the Commissioner for Employee’s Compensation of the amount of compensation along with the memorandum of Appeal is equally applicable to the Appeal filed by the Insurer, and the Appeal at the behest of the Insurer without such a certificate would not be maintainable.
(Paras 7, 8, 17, 19, 20)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Claimant-driver is of 34 years at time of accident - Monthly income taken as Rs.8,000/- - Factor 199.4 is to be applied - Considering percentage of disability of 80%, loss of income comes to Rs.12,76,160/- - Claimant entitled to only 60% of monthly wage calculated along with relevant factor - Loss of earning comes to Rs.7,65,696/- - Claimant entitled to Rs.11,51,000/- towards medical expenses - Claimant entitled to total compensation of Rs.19,16,696/- with interest at 7.5%. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Liability of insurer
HeadNote.description: Liability of insurer - At time of accident insured was working as driver under owner of insured vehicle - Claimant in his evidence stated that as per instructions of his employer who is owner of vehicle, while he was returning along with mechanic carrying some spare parts, they met with accident - Accident occurred only during course of employment - However, claimant was tort-feasor, he is not entitled to make claim u/S.166 - As per insurance policy cover under Intelligent Manual Transmission 28, for paid driver, compensation could be recalculated in accordance with provisions of Employees Compensation Act - Insurance company liable to pay compensation. 	(Paras 11, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Employees’ Provident Funds and Miscellaneous Provisions Act (1952)
heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Orders u/Ss.7A and 7B - Challenge - Issue as to whether pigmy agents can be treated as employees of a Banking Society - In view of judgment in Pachora People's Cooperative Bank's case [2014(3) ALL MR 658], matter remanded back to Provident Fund Commissioner for proper enquiry u/S.7A - Impugned orders set aside.  2014(3) ALL MR 658 Rel.on.			(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Employer’s contribution
Interest thereon
Liability
Waiver
HeadNote.description: Employer’s contribution - Interest thereon - Liability - Waiver - Liability of appellant to pay contribution from 30th March 1975 onwards attained finality - Interest at rate of 6% p.a. was demanded as per unamended Reg.31A - Only for arrears of contribution payable after 19th of October 1989, interest at rate of 12% claimed, as per S.39(5) inserted w.e.f. 20th October 1989 - In absence of any challenge to Reg.31A, demand for interest cannot be faulted with - Nothing on record to show that better medical facilities were provided by appellant, employer to its employees than what are provided under Act of 1948 - Therefore, in facts Supreme Court declined to exercise power under Art.142 of Constitution to waive interest.			(Paras 10, 12)

Interest thereon

heading: Sale of enemy property
HeadNote.description:
Sale of enemy property - Power of Custodian u/S.8 cannot override the power of Central Govt. u/S.6 - The sections have to be read together and harmoniously so as to subserve and uphold the legislative intent.

	While it is true that a transfer of property vesting in the Custodian by enemy or enemy subject of enemy firm is contemplated by section 6, a power equally is given to the Central Government to declare such transfer to be void if such transfer by an enemy or enemy subject or enemy firm is injurious to the public interest or so made with a view to evade or defeat the vesting of the property in the Custodian. Thus, being an enemy, the right to transfer the property could be exercised subject to this provision. This provision gives a power to the Central Government to declare the transfer to be void and thereupon it shall continue to vest or deemed to be vested in the Custodian. In the present case, it is this power which is exercised by the Central Government.	 [Para 40]

	The power of the Custodian under section 8 is therefore not such as would enable the Custodian to override the said Act. It is a discretion given to the Custodian to take or authorise to take all such measures for preserving such property and where the property belongs to an individual enemy subject, the Custodian may incur expenditure out of the property as is necessary or expedient for the maintenance of that individual or his family in India. This would also reinforce the conclusion that the enemy is not to be deprived of his right, title and interest in the property. If the enemy subject is an individual, he may also be in a position to provide for his family members in India through such measures as are devised by the Custodian. Therefore, vesting of the property in the Custodian is limited to the extent of possession, management and control over the property. It is towards that end that he has been conferred with such powers as would enable him to take suitable actions including transfer by way of sale, mortgage or lease or otherwise dispose of any of the properties of the enemy subject. This would apply in the case of the enemy subject holding more than one property. We do not see any conflict therefore in section 7(3) and section 8 of the said Act. By sub section (3) of section 7, the Custodian is mandated to deal with any money paid to him under the Defence of India Rules, 1962 or the Defence of India Rules, 1971 or under this Act or any property vested in him under this Act in such manner as the Central Government may direct. Therefore, the power is conferred in the Central Government and it is empowered to direct the Custodian to deal with the money and any property of the enemy subject in such manner as the Central Government deems fit and proper. When such direction is issued, then, the Custodian is bound to comply with it. That power under sub section (3) of section 7 is in the Central Government and it can direct the Custodian to act in terms thereof. Else, the Custodian is free to exercise his powers in respect of enemy property vested in him vide section 8. However, the powers of the Custodian under section 8 are to be exercised keeping in mind the intent of preserving the same. 		 [Para 41]

	The sections have to be read together and harmoniously so as to subserve and uphold the legislative intent. The legislative intent being clear, the words appearing in the section will have to be given their plain and natural meaning as held above. There is nothing vague in the expression and words appearing in section 6 of the Act. It is therefore transfer of property vesting in the Custodian by enemy or enemy subject or enemy firm may be permissible. He holds all rights, title and interest in the enemy property. The transfer can be declared to be void if it is injurious to public interest or made with a view as in this case. Such a provision has been inserted advisedly. The "enemy" is defined to mean a person or country who or which was an enemy, enemy subject or enemy firm as the case may be under the Defence of India Act but does not include a citizen of India. Once the person therefore is termed as an enemy, then, his property in Indiacannot be freely dealt with by him on par with an Indian citizen. TheIndian citizen is excluded from the term "enemy" or "enemy subject". Once the definition of the terms "enemy" or "enemy subject" or "enemy firm" are read in their proper perspective, it would be clear that the property for the time being belonging to or held or managed on behalf of an enemy vests in the Custodian. The property continues to be termed as an enemy property even when an individual enemy subject dies in the territory to which the Enemy Property Act extends. Therefore, the placement of section 6 of the said Act and reading it along with other sections which follow the same would throw light on the intention of the legislature. The powers of the Custodian in respect of the enemy property vested in him are to be exercised for taking such measures as he considers necessary or expedient for preserving such property and when such property belongs to an individual enemy, the Custodian may incur expenditure out of the property as he considers expedient for the maintenance of that individual or of his family in India. Thus, these powers are also to be exercised consistent with the aim and object that the Act seeks to achieve. The Act does not wish to deprive the enemy or enemy subject of his right, title and interest in the properties and therefore assists him by vesting the property in the Custodian to be appointed under the Act. The Custodian holds the property upon its vesting in him for preservation. He also is permitted to incur certain expenditure, if the property is held by an individual enemy subject, from such property for the maintenance of the individual enemy subject or his family members in India. The provisions like section 8 enable the Custodian to take measures as he considers necessary or expedient for preserving the property. It is therefore that he is conferred with several powers. Thus, the intent is to manage and administer the property by taking the afore-contemplated measures. By section 9 to 15, it would be apparent as to how when the property vests in the Custodian it is exempt from attachment etc. When persons are dealing with the Custodian while he exercises the powers conferred by section 8, those persons also have certain protection and that is apparent from the above referred sections. The Custodian is thus not free to dispose of the property as per his whims and fancies. He must deal with the property of the enemy subject consistent with the powers of preservation conferred in him. The legislature while using the words "preserving such property" is conscious that nothing should be done by which the enemy subject deals with the property situated in India as if he is an Indian citizen. His right and freedom to hold the property even if it is in India is intact but subject to the Custodian's intervention. It is to ensure that the enemy's rights qua his property are not jeopardised nor the enemy is deprived of the same. Equally, the Custodian should not allow the enemy subject to deal with his property in any manner and contrary to the Act itself.

	Further, it is the Central Government alone which is conferred with the power to divest the enemy property vested in the Custodian. By section 18, it is the Central Government which is empowered to direct that any enemy property vesting in the Custodian under this Act and remaining with him shall be divested from him and to return in such manner as may be prescribed to the owner thereof or to such other person as may be specified in the direction and thereupon such property shall cease to vest in the Custodian and shall re-vest in the owner or other person. This provision reinforces above conclusion that any enemy property vested in the Custodian under this Act and remaining with him shall be divested from him only by the Central Government and none else. 				 [Para 60]

heading: Disability pension
Denial of
HeadNote.description:
Guide to Medical Officers (Military Pension) (2002), Paras 7, 8, 9 - Disability pension - Denial of - It must be affirmatively proved that deterioration in the health of the member of service was not on account of Army service or had been aggravated by it by recording reasons therefor.

On a comprehensive consideration of the Regulation, Rules and the General Principles as applicable, the service profile of the respondent and the proceedings of the Medical Board, claimant soldier had been wrongly denied the benefit of disability pension. His tenure albeit short, during which he had to be frequently hospitalized does not irrefutably rule out the possibility, in absence of any reason recorded by the Medical Board that the disability even assumed to be constitutional or genetic, had not been induced or aggravated by the arduous military conditions. The requirement of recording reasons is not contingent on the duration of the Army service of the member thereof and is instead of peremptory nature, failing which the decision to board him out would be vitiated by an inexcusable infraction of the relevant statutory provisions. There may indeed be cases where the disease is wholly unrelated to Army service but to deny disability pension, it must affirmatively be proved that the same had nothing to do with such service the burden to establish disability would lie heavily upon the employer, for otherwise the Rules raise a presumption that the deterioration in the health of the member of the service was on account of Army service or had been aggravated by it. 		         [Para 22,23]

HeadNote.act_name: Entitlement Rules for Casualty Pensionary Awards (1982)
heading: Disability pension
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description:
Guide to Medical Officers (Military Pensions) (2002), Paras 7, 8, 9 - Disability pension - Entitlement to - Guiding principles. 

Only two conditions have been specified for the grant of disability pension viz. (i) the disability is above 20%; and (ii) the disability is attributable to or aggravated by military service. From a conjoint and harmonious reading of Rules 5, 9 and 14 of Entitlement Rules (supra) the following guiding principles emerge:

i) a member is presumed to have been in sound physical and mental condition upon entering service except as to physical disabilities noted or recorded at the time of entrance;

ii) in the event of his being discharged from service on medical grounds at any subsequent stage it must be presumed that any such deterioration in his health which has taken place is due to such military service;

iii) the disease which has led to an individual's discharge or death will ordinarily be deemed to have arisen in service, if no note of it was made at the time of the individual's acceptance for military service; and

iv) if medical opinion holds that the disease, because of which the individual was discharged, could not have been detected on medical examination prior to acceptance of service, reasons for the same shall be stated.         [Para 8,11]

The provision for payment of disability pension is a beneficial provision which ought to be interpreted liberally so as to benefit those who have been sent home with a disability at times even before they completed their tenure in the armed forces. There may indeed be cases, where the disease was wholly unrelated to military service, but, in order that denial of disability pension can be justified on that ground, it must be affirmatively proved that the disease had nothing to do with such service. The burden to establish such a disconnect would lie heavily upon the employer for otherwise the rules raise a presumption that the deterioration in the health of the member of the service is on account of military service or aggravated by it.      [Para 15]

heading: Noise Pollution (Regulation and Control) Rules (2000) R.5(3) (As amended in 2002)
HeadNote.description:
Noise Pollution (Regulation and Control) Rules (2000) R.5(3) (As amended in 2002) - Use of loud speaker between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. - Further relaxation between 10 p.m. and 12 midnight i.e. for two hours allowed as reasonable for a maximum period of 15 days during the year.

Looking at the diversity of cultures and religions in India, a limited power of exemption from the operation of the Noise Rules granted by the Central Government in exercise of its statutory power cannot be held to be unreasonable. The power to grant exemption is conferred on the State Government. It cannot be further delegated. The power shall be exercised by reference to the State as a unit and not by reference to districts, so as to specify different dates for different districts. It can be reasonably expected that the State Government would exercise the power with due care and caution and in public interest. However, the scope of the exemption cannot be widened either by increasing the number of days or by increasing the duration beyond two hours. If that is attempted to be done, then the said sub-rule (3) conferring power to grant exemption may be liable to be struck down as violative of Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution. The State Government should generally specify in advance, the number and particulars of the days on which such exemption will be operative. Such specification would exclude arbitrariness in the exercise of power. The exemption, when granted, shall not apply to silence zone areas. This is only as a clarification as, this even otherwise, is the position of law.   [Para 9]

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Notification dt. 19-2-1991 (As substituted in 1997 in respect of CRZ No. II) - Word "existing" repeatedly occuring therein - Meaning of - It carries the same meaning viz existing as on the date of the notification.

The word "existing" as used in the concerned part of the Notification, cannot be read differently at different places within the same part. The word "existing" used in the material part of the Notification refers in several places to structures which were already physically existing on the date of the Notification and to roads exiting already on the date of the Notification. The use of participle 'existing' to qualify "local Town and Country Planning Regulations" and "Norms of Floor Space Index/Floor Area ratio" is, not merely accidental. It serves an important purpose, namely, to highlight that irrespective of what local Town and Country Planning Regulations may provide for in future in any nook or corner of the country, and irrespective of how the norms of Floor space Index/Floor Space Ratio might be revised at some future point of time, the building activity permitted under the Notification in CRZ-II shall be frozen to the laws and norms existing on the date of the Notification. This interpretation, is perfectly in consonance with the legislative intention behind the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986.  [Para 70]

Progress is reflected in change and no frozen action, contend the Petitioners' Counsel. But, progress is a concept with deeper philosophical, ethical and moral overtones. One man's meat may be another's poison. So with progress too. Ultimately, it is for the collective will of the people, as expressed by law, to asset itself and answer this question. Whether depredation of environment is progress or regress is a matter of collective wisdom reflected in legislative policy. If Parliament intended that there shall be no "progress" of such type in future, one cannot demur or protest, at least in a Court of law.  [Para 71]

What the notification intends is that the F.S.I. norms be pegged at the level at which they existed in February 1991. This was the extent to which the coastal area had already been built upon. If, therefore, even in future, notwithstanding reduction of the F.S.I. norms elsewhere, the CRZ-II zone  is given this benefit, we see nothing wrong or objectionable therein, nor any reason against such construction being adopted.  [Para 72]

Further, by virtue of the provisions of Section 21 of the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986, the provisions of the Act, the rules or orders made therein shall take effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any enactment other than the Act. Thus, whatever be the Heritage TDR Regulation No. 67, brought into force in the year 1995, it can have no application in the areas falling within CRZ-II.  [Para 73]

heading: Interpretation of Statutes
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statutes - Construction of dwelling Units - Possibility of two views - Held, even if two views are possible, the one in favour of environment has to be accepted - When an expert committee has already given its opinion on merits, such a decision cannot be substituted by the Court in the absence of any other cogent material on record. Constitution of India, Art.226.

Clause (iii) of CRZ-III deals with construction/reconstruction of dwelling units between 200 metres to 500 metres. Considering the aforesaid provision of the Regulations, the construction of jetty falls within the "permissible activities" and such a permissible activity is permitted in CRZ-III, however, subject to other requirements i.e. taking permission from the MOEF. In the instant case, respondent No.1 has now already taken such a permission and considering the said aspect, it is not possible to accept the submission of Mr. Subramanian that there is a total prohibition on construction of jetty in CRZ-III as the area upto 200 metres is to be considered as No Development Zone. As pointed out earlier, even under the No Development Zone, there are certain activities which are permissible. Even construction of schools, community toilets are also permissible and as argued by Mr. Fereira, learned Assist. Solicitor General construction of a jetty is definitely a permissible activity, as in different parts of the Country such constructions are permissible in CRZ-III even within the No Development Zone. It is true, even if two views are possible, the one in favour of environment has to be accepted. It cannot be said that two views are possible on reading of the Notification. As per the notification, the construction of the jetty, as pointed out earlier, is a permissible activity and on reading of the entire notification and the clarification thereof, it cannot be said that even construction of permissible activity cannot be carried out in CRZ-III, in an area upto 200 metres from the HTL which is earmarked as No Development Zone. When an expert committee has already given its opinion on merits, such a decision cannot be substituted by the Court in the absence of any other cogent material on record.  [Para 21]

heading: Scope and validity
Unsustainable
HeadNote.description: CRZ Notification dt: 19-2-1991, Para 2 (viii) (as amended on 9-7-1997) - Requirement of notice U/R.5(3)(a) before imposition of restriction - Dispension with such notice in "public interest" - Scope and validity - Held, power to Govt. as U/R.5(4) can be exercised only in public interest - Contention that power to dispense with notice is unguided and unbridled power - Unsustainable - Such notice was for benefit of persons who may be interested in filing objections against imposition of restrictions - Persons who supported restrictions cannot complain that notice was not given. 	(Para 20)

heading: apparent or otherwise
HeadNote.description:
Construction of Sea Rock hotel on land allotted by authorities - Land exempted under Urban Land Ceiling Act - No contravention of any Regulation - Provisions of any Statute also not breached - Construction is legal and is beyond challenge. 

Maharashtra Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Act (1960), S.4(3); Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act (1966), S.37 ; Urban Land (Ceiling and Regulation) Act (1976), S.30; Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act (1888), S.346; Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act 1966 and Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991), Reg. 59; Industrial Disputes Act (1947), S.2(j), Companies Act (1956), S.591, 394A, 391(7), Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act (1974), S.25 ; Income tax Act (1961),  Chap. XX C ; S.269 UA ; Constitution of India Art. 226.

The Land's End Bandra is a peninsular piece of Land which juts into the sea, being covered on the East, North and West by the Sea. The land was exempted under the Urban Land Ceiling Act. There has been considerable development on this peninsular piece of land and a developed road runs North-South almost to the tip of the peninsular area. Towards the West seaward of this road, there exists a five star hotel, "Sea Rock", whose construction had been permitted much before the Coastal Regulation Zone Notification under the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986 was brought into force. Hotel Sea Rock is situated towards the North of the Bandra fort within about 100 meters therefrom. A plot of land measuring 45,000 square yards situated opposite the Hotel Sea Rock i.e. towards the Eastern side of the developed road is the subject matter of this Writ Petition. Towards the East of this plot the hill slopes down to the Mahim Bay and there is a large tract of open land which now has been encroached upon and dotted by numerous unauthorised structures, though continued to be shown as green area in the sanctioned and revised Development Plan for H-West Ward of Mumbai. The construction of the hotel Sea Rock has been challenged by a writ petition by way of public Interest Litigation by number of petitioners. The construction was challenged on the grounds as below :

(a) Violation of Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) Rules.

(b) Contravention of Urban Land Ceiling Act and the exemption order made thereunder.

(c) Contravention of the provisions of the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966.

(d) Violation of the sanctioned Development Plan.

(e) Challenge to the decision of the Ministry of Environment & Forest, Government of India. 

(f) Challenge to the Corrigendum Notification dated 22nd November 1966.

(g) Challenge to sanctioned Development Plan.

(h) Challenge to permission granted by the State Pollution Control Board.

(i) Contravention of the provisions of the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966 and Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay, 1991.

(j) Contravention of the Development Control Regulation No. 59.

(k) Amalgamation of sixth and ninth Respondents, fraudulent, illegal and intended to circumvent law.

(l) Application of Chapter XX-C of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

Held, that the Construction of the Hotel Sea Rock was valid and there was no contravention of any of the provisions of statutes or statutory rules or notifications under the Statutes.  [Para 17]

Basically, the Coastal Regulation Zone is one which falls within 500 meters of the High Tide Line. Merely because the Bandra Fort is situated at the tip of the peninsular plot of land, the entire peninsular plot of land does not fall within CRZ-I. The restrictions against construction in CRZ-I would apply only to a stretch of 500 meters from the High Tide Line as long as that area falls within the area declared as heritage monument under the Maharashtra Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Act. Looking at the revised dimensions in the Notification of 31st July 1998, it is not possible to accept the contention that the concerned plot would fall within CRZ-I area so as to completely prohibit constructional activity on it.  [Para 33,34]

The expression industry used in Para 2(i) of the CRZ Notification dt. 19-2-1991 must take colour from the concept of environmental pollution such as Trade effluents which are discharged by the industry which would otherwise require permission from the Pollution Control Board. A careful scrutiny of the different types of activities prohibited under the different clauses of paragraph 2 of the Notification supports this view. In fact, construction of hotels is permitted in CRZ-II and CRZ-III as evidenced from paragraph 7 of the said Notification. Hence, it could not be contended that the hotel is an "industry" and as such construction of the hotel on the concerned plot is prohibited under paragraph 2 of the CRZ Notification.  [Para 35]

The contention that Sub. cls. (v) (vii) (viii) (ix) (xii) and (xiii) are violated by the construction of hotel "Sea Rock" cannot be accepted. What is prohibited by sub-clause (v) of Clause 2 of the 1991 CRZ Notification is "discharge of untreated wastes and effluents from industries, cities or towns and other human settlements" within the coastal regulation zone. There is no material on record to show that the hotel constructed by the Respondents discharges untreated wastes and effluents into the sea. As to the grievance against the Bombay Municipal Corporation Sewerage purification Plant, the grievance has no substance since the Bombay Municipal Corporation Sewerage Purification Plant is intended to treat city wastes and effluents and render them innocuous before being discharged into the Sea. Hence there is no violation of sub-clause (v) of Clause 2 of 1991 CRZ Notification.  Sub-clauses (viii) and (xii) of Clause 2 of the Notification are intended to permit land reclamation for limited purposes and to permit construction activity between Low Tide Line and High Tide Line for carrying of treated effluents and wastes water discharges into the sea. The Bombay Municipal Corporation Sewerage Purification Plant and the proposed pipeline fall within the activity permitted by these clauses. In fact, by the Notification dated 9th July 1997, sub-clause (viii) has been completely substituted and the activity of construction of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Sewerage Purification Plant is wholly permitted thereunder. Further sub-clause (ix) of Clause 2 of the CRZ Notification has no application at all. Sub-clause (xiii) of Clause 2 of the 1991 CRZ Notification cannot be said to be violated if what is done is permissible construction activity and anything that is reasonably necessary to carry out the permissible activity or construction of a building without violation of any of the provisions of the CRZ Notification.  Sub-clause (xiii) cannot be read in isolation and has to be read subject to the regulation of permissible activities under sub-clause (iii). That is why sub-clause (xiii) of Clause 2 of the Notification uses the expression "except as permissible under the Notification". If the construction activity is permitted under any other part of the Notification, then the prohibition contemplated by Clause 2, sub-clause (xiii) is not attracted.  [Para 38,39,40]

It could not be contended that the exemption granted under the Urban Land Ceiling Act (ULCA) was violated by the respondents. One of the conditions of the order dated 25th July 1978 made under Section 20 of ULCA granting exemption specifically stipulated was that "no transfer by way of sale, mortgage, gift, lease or otherwise" shall be made of the exempted land and that in case of violation of this condition, the exemption order was liable to be revoked. There was also a condition that the sixth Respondent was to give an area of 7000 square yards free of cost to the Bombay Municipal Corporation for being maintained as a public park. There was no violation of the conditions. Under Section 19 of ULCA read with section 5 of the Banking Regulation Act, and Section 591 of the Companies Act, Citibank is one of the entities in whose favour the land, even though exempted under section 20 of the ULCA, could have been mortgaged. Further, there was an express order made by the Government of Maharashtra on 7th February 1980 issuing a no objection certificate for transfer of the exempted vacant land to the ninth Respondent on amalgamation with the sixth Respondent subject to certain conditions as to shareholding. This issue also could not be reagitated since those pleas were repeated in earlier petition being barred under principles of res judicata.   [Para 43,44]

The contention that the sanctioned building plans could never have been extended is, therefore, of no substance.  [Para 46]

The project was rejected on an earlier occassion but permission was granted after matter was reconsidered. The reconsideration on the part of Ministry of Environment and Forest could not be said to be malafide or arising on account of non-germane considerations. In fact, in the letter of 30th September 1993, the Ministry of Environment and Forest has indicated clearly the reasons which moved it to reconsider its stand and grant no objection to the proposal made by the State Government, after considering in detail the clarifications provided by the State Government. It has also stipulated and laid down the safeguards which should be adhered to while implementing the project. The clearance given by the Ministry of Environment and Forest is an administrative act and, as long as it satisfies the principles of Wednesbury rationality, it is not the function of Court to sit in appeal over the reasons which moved the Government to grant such sanction. First, the Ministry of Environment and Forest had the power under the CRZ Notifications read with the Environment Protection Act to grant such sanction for the proposed project. Secondly, that it could not be said that the sanction was irrational or that it proceeded on account of any collateral or impermissible motives.   [Para 50]

There was some change in the sanctioned plan. This exercise of power by the Commissioner or by the State Government does not amount to a modification of the sanctioned Development Plan requiring the following of the prescribed procedure of inviting objections, considering them and sanctioning the plan.  [Para 54]

(Matter not decided).  [Para 56]

The height restriction in this Regulation would apply if the plot on which the construction is being done falls within category I or category II.  [Para 70,71,72]

Respondents 6 and 9 were amalgamated under the Companies Act by the Court. Therefore, it is not open to the High Court while exercising writ jurisdiction in a Public Interest Litigation to sit in judgment over the correctness of an order made under Section 391 by the Company Court which has become final, conclusive and binding.  [Para 79,80,82,83]

Therefore, Chap. XX-C of the Income tax Act does not apply to such a transfer by operation of law.   [Para 96,103]

The term "Apparent consideration", as defined in clause (b) of Section 269UA of the Income Tax Act, is an inalienable factor which must be reckoned with in the application of Chapter XX-C for if the Appropriate Authority is satisfied that there is undervaluation, then it is empowered to purchase the property at the apparent consideration. The valuation put on the shares cannot be treated as "apparent consideration" for the purposes of transfer. [Para 111,112]

heading: CRZ Notification dt.19.2.1991
MOEF Guidelines Dt.27.3.1998
Imaginary line
HeadNote.description:
CRZ Notification dt.19.2.1991 - GOI Ministry of Environment and Forests (MOEF) Notification Dt.9.7.1997 - MOEF Guidelines Dt.27.3.1998 - MOEF  Clarification Dt.8.9.1998 - Permission for construction of building - To fall on landward side proposed building must be behind existing authorised structure - Imaginary line - How to be drawn when there is an authorised structure only on one side.

It is not necessary that to fall on the landward side the building to be constructed must be behind an authorised structure, so that there must be an existing authorised structure between the building sought to be constructed and the sea before permission can be granted to permit construction of such a building.  We must also hold that an imaginary line may be drawn even if there is an authorised structure on the adjacent plot only on one side, and if the building constructed falls on the landward side of the imaginary line drawn in accordance with the clarification contained in the letter of the Government of India dated 8th September, 1998, it must be held that the building falls on the landward side of the existing authorised structure.  [Para 34]

heading: Falling in CRZ-II
HeadNote.description:
CRZ Notification dt: 19-2-1991 Cls. 2,3 Annexure I - GOI, Ministry of Environment and Forests (MOEF) Notification Dt:9-7-1997 - MOEF Guidelines Dt: 27-3-1998 - MOEF clarification Dt: 8-9-1999 - Maharashtra State Coastal Zone Management Plan - Construction of Bulk Receiving Station - Falling in CRZ-II - Plot in Developed Area and adjoining authorised structures - No space available behind authorized structures - Imaginary line should be drawn from seaward side of authorised structure on adjoining plot - Distance between two authorized structures spread over several plots - Not possible to draw imaginary line - Construction had started about 7 yrs. ago - Huge sum of money already invested - Also Bulk Receiving station to function as integrated plant along with existing sub-stations on adjoining plots - Larger public interest to prevail in competition between two public interests - On facts, construction does not violate CRZ notification.

heading: Construction of jetty
Permission of MOEF
HeadNote.description: Construction of jetty - Permission of MOEF - Held, for construction of "jetty", in CRZ-III, permission from Ministry of Environment and Forests (MOEF) is required to be obtained as per law.	(Para 15)

heading: Prohibition of
Quantum of work
HeadNote.description:
"Same work or work of similar nature" - Prohibition of - Difference in wages of male and female members - No difference in their skill, effort or responsibility - Quantum of work - Not relevant.

When complainants are performing "same work or work of similar nature", section 4 prohibits employer from paying remuneration at different rate/less rate than the rate at which remuneration is paid to male members.  The persons of opposite sex were working as wet sweepers in Boys hostel and Girls hostel. It is, therefore, apparent that there is no difference in their skill, effort or responsibility. The words contemplated same work or work of similar nature. Here, the work is same. The question of quantum of work, therefore, is not very relevant.

It is thus clear that the provisions of the Equal Remuneration Act, 1976, squarely govern the controversy which has been looked into by the Industrial Court.  		 [Para 10]

Appropriate Government
HeadNote.description: Offence u/s.10(1)(a) - Cognizance of - Appropriate Government - Petitioner company doing life insurance business registered under Companies Act, covered by S.2(a)(ii) - Appropriate Government for violation of the Act would be State Government and not the Central Government - Labour Enforcement Officer (central) not authorised to take action under the Act - Complaint would be liable to be quashed. HeadNote.description:
Criminal P.C. (1973), S.167 - Special Court under Act also assigned to try cases under NDPS Act - After lapsing of Essential Commodities (Special Provisions) Act Special Court ceasing to exist but continued for purposes of NDPS Act - It cannot remand accused charged under E.C.Act.

On a fair reading of the above provisions it is clear that during the period the EC (Special Provisions) Act was in force the special Court constituted for trial of offences under EC Act had exclusive jurisdiction to try such cases. The special Court had also the power to pass order of remand under S.167 but the position changed after the EC (Special Provisions) Act lapsed by efflux of time. Thereafter, the position that used to prevail before the EC (Special Provisions) Act was enforced, stood restored and the judicial magistrates who were previously competent to try the EC Act cases got the jurisdiction to deal with such cases. The position is beyond any pale of doubt that the remand orders passed by the special Court at Madurai, long after it had ceased to exercise jurisdiction in cases under the EC Act are incompetent. Coming to the question whether the special Court constituted for trial of cases under the NDPS Act could exercise the power of remand of an accused in the EC Act case, which it was doing when the special Court constituted for the EC Act cases was in existence, the answer to the question is in the negative: for the simple reason that the special Court constituted for NDPS Act cases is a Court of exclusive jurisdiction for trial of the particular class of cases provided under the NDPS Act and it has not been vested with power of judicial Magistrate for the purpose of dealing with EC Act cases. To accept the contention raised on behalf of the appellant in this regard would in our view be contrary to the scheme of things under the Criminal Procedure Code which specifically vests the power of remand under S.167 in judicial Magistrate.  [Para 16,17]

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description: Expiry of temporary statute - Effect - On the expiry of temporary statute no proceedings can be taken under it and it ceases to have any further effect - However, if under the temporary statute there is any saving provisions, then by virtue of such saving provision the pending proceedings will have to be dealt with as if the legislation is still in force. AIR 1959 SC 609 and AIR 1951 SC 301 - Rel. on. 	(Paras 13 & 14)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for recovery of immovable property - Jurisdiction - Question of jurisdiction is not always a vital question - The objection as to place of suing may be considered within the ambit of 21(1) of Civil P.C.

The provisions of Section 16(a) of the C.P.C. would make it manifest that the suit for recovery of immovable property with or without rent or profits has to be instituted in the Court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the property is situate.  That is the ordinary place where the suit of that kind could be instituted.  The provisions of Section 20 would come into play only when the suit is not governed by any of the clauses enumerated u/s.16 of the C.P.C.  In the present case, however, the suit is clearly covered by sub-clause (a) of Section 16 of the C.P.C. and hence, the place where suit property is situated is the place where the suit shall be filed.  The suit property is situated at Kopargaon.  It was therefore, rightly filed in the Civil Court at Kopargaon.  There appears no jurisdictional error committed by the trial Court while entertaining the suit.  That apart, the question of jurisdiction is not always a vital question.  The objection as to place of suing may be considered with the ambit of Section 21(1) of the C.P.C., 1908.  (1993)2 SCC 130 - Rel. on.					 [Para 12,13]

heading: Grant of permission to establish new college
HeadNote.description:
Grant of permission to establish new college - MCI is only an administrative authority and not quasi-judicial - Compliance with rigid rules of natural justice not necessary. 

MCI, while deciding to grant permission or not to grant permission, is not functioning as a quasi-judicial authority, but only as an administrative authority. Rigid rules of natural justice are, therefore, not contemplated or envisaged. Rule 8(3)(1) of the Establishment of Medical College Regulations (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Part II), provides for only an "opportunity and time to rectify the deficiencies". Compliance report is called for only to ascertain whether the deficiencies pointed out were rectified or not. If the MCI is not satisfied with the manner of compliance, it can conduct a surprise inspection. After that, no further time or opportunity to rectify the deficiencies is contemplated, nor further opportunity of being heard, is provided.

In this case the deficiencies pointed out by the MCI team in its report dated 06.07.2013. In our view, the deficiencies pointed out are fundamental and very crucial, which cannot be ignored in the interest of medical education and in the interest of student community. MCI and the College authorities have to bear in mind, what is prescribed is the minimum, if the MCI dilutes the minimum standards, they will be doing violence to the statutory requirements. An order refusing approval for renewal of permission is not vitiated by violation of principles of natural justice, especially, when no allegation of bias or mala fide has been attributed against the two doctors who constituted the Inspection Team, which conducted the surprise inspection.     [Para 19,20,21]

heading: Applicability of Reg.8(3)(1)(a)
Not tenable
