heading: Renewal of permission for academic year 2018-19
HeadNote.description: Renewal of permission for academic year 2018-19 - Refusal to grant by Central Govt. - Writ Petition against, allowed by High Court and College was ordered to submit compliance and direction issued to MCI to conduct inspection of College in order to reconsider case for grant of renewal of permission for said academic year - High Court opined that in view of order passed by Apex Court on 13/11/2017 to grant opportunity to make compliance and remove deficiencies, opportunity ought to have been granted - Pursuant to order dt.13/11/2017, MCI had carried out inspection and gross deficiencies were found in College - As it was already a case of conditional permission subject to removal of deficiencies, Executive Committee of MCI recommended to Central Govt. not to grant renewal of permission for admitting students for academic year 2018-19 and also invoked Reg.8(3)(1)(a) of Regulations of 1999 due to which compliance verification could not have been made - Held, order dt.13/11/2017 cannot be taken to mean that despite gross deficiencies as per Reg.8(3)(1)(a), compliance opportunity should be given - High Court erred in law in considering purport of order of Apex Court and also ignored academic calendar - College not entitled to any further indulgence - Order of High Court set aside - Order of Central Govt., held proper.			(Paras 15-28)

heading: Manipulation of record
Punishment
HeadNote.description: Inspection of medical college - Manipulation of record - Punishment - Fake patients shown to be admitted and full time practicing doctors shown as teaching faculty - Several times, order of re-inspection sought from Court on basis of false records - Court was misled and defrauded - Dean of college gave declaration in petitions that information furnished by him is true to his knowledge - Apology tendered by college just before imposition of punishment, not acceptable - It ceases to be apology - Fraudulent conduct must be dealt with seriously - College debarred from making admissions for next two academic years - Dean of college directed to be prosecuted u/S.193 IPC - Fine of Rs. 5 crore imposed on college - Admission fees also directed to be refunded to students along with compensation of Rs.1 lakh. HeadNote.description: Establishment of Medical College - Refusal to renew permission for admission to second batch on account of deficiencies noticed in inspection - However, Cl.8(3)(1)(a) of 1999 Regulations, is applicable to admission of third batch - Inspection report itself reveals that though bed occupancy is shown 01% at 10 a.m., it is shown as 45.30% on random verification done on that date - OPD attendance shown at 2.00 p.m. as 703, whereas casualty attendance is shown as 30 and number of admissions is shown as 39 - Not clear as to how bed occupancy is 01% if number of admissions is 39 - Though faculty for all subjects is available, faculty is shown as 87% deficient only because they have signed after 11.30 a.m. - No opportunity given to College to remove deficiencies and to rectify them, when Parent Statute and Regulation themselves provide for such opportunity - Approach of authority in conducting inspection is not in accordance with Scheme of Act and Regulation - Direction issued to re-inspect medical college of petitioner. HeadNote.description: Establishment of new medical college - Refusal of permission to admit students for academic year 2017-18 and 2018-19 - Ground that deficiencies in respect of faculty, residents, bed occupancy, salary slips, etc. were found in petitioner-college - Petitioner-college submitted that representation submitted by it explaining deficiencies was not considered by Hearing Committee or Competent Authority (CA) - Explanation offered by petitioner was accepted by Oversight Committee (OC) but its opinion was also not considered by CA - CA also has not given any reason why it has deviated from opinion of OC - CA has not followed directions given by Supreme Court to give opportunity to petitioner before taking final decision on issue of permission - But deficiencies found by MCI in respect of faculty, residents, bed occupancy, etc. were beyond permissible limits - Further plea of petitioner that inspection is in violation of Regn.8(3)(1)(d) is not maintainable - Inspection was carried out three days prior to Diwali holidays - Refusal of permission for academic year 2017-18, proper - However, students who have been admitted in 2016-17 in view of conditional letter of permission shall continue their studies - Medical Council of India directed to conduct fresh inspection for academic year 2018-19. heading: Essentiality certificate
Not permissible
HeadNote.description:
Essentiality certificate - Withdrawal by State Govt. - For irregularity in functioning of College - Not permissible - Withdrawal of said certificate not permissible for any reason except fraud - Considering purpose of essentiality certificate, power of its issuance can be said to be exhausted once it is exercised.

	The Essentiality Certificate certifies that it is essential having regard to specified factors that the opening of the proposed college is essential in the State, in public interest. Further, that the applicant has the necessary land and building for running it. What is significant to note is that the law requires that an applicant must possess an Essentiality Certificate from the State Government mentioning therein that it is essential to have a Medical College as proposed by him. The purpose is inter alia to prevent the establishment of a college where none is required or to prevent unhealthy competition between too many Medical Colleges.

	Thus, the Legislative scheme for permission to establish a Medical College prescribes, as a qualifying criterion, that the applicant must have an Essentiality Certificate issued by the State Government. The State Government certifies the justification for establishing a proposed Medical College as a part of the Legislative scheme under the Act. It does not do so under any other law including a State enactment. The only purpose of the Essentiality Certificate is to enable the Central Government acting under Section 10A to take an informed decision for permitting the opening or establishment of a new Medical College. Once the college is established, its functioning and performance and even the de-recognition of its courses is controlled only by the provisions of the IMC Act and not any other law.

	It would be impermissible to allow any authority including a State Government which merely issues an Essentiality Certificate, to exercise any power which could have the effect of terminating the existence of a Medical College permitted to be established by the Central Government. This the State Government may not do either directly or indirectly. Moreover, the purpose of the Essentiality Certificate is limited to certifying to the Central Government that it is essential to establish a Medical College. It does not go beyond this. In other words, once the State Government has certified that the establishment of a Medical College is justified, it cannot at a later stage say that there was no justification for the establishment of the College. Surely, a person who establishes a Medical College upon an assurance of a State Government that such establishment is justified cannot be told at a later stage that there was no justification for allowing him to do so. Moreover, it appears that the power to issue an Essentiality Certificate is a power that must be treated as exhausted once it is exercised, except in cases of fraud.

	The question of justified existence of a college and the irregular/illegal functioning of an existing college belong to a different order of things and cannot be mixed up.				 [Para 14,15,16,17]

heading: Essentiality certificate
Conditions
HeadNote.description: Essentiality certificate - Conditions - Conditions incorporated by State Govt. in Essentiality Certificate regarding periodic inspection of Medical College and provided that certificate would be withdrawn in case of failure to comply with prescribed conditions - IMC Act or Regulations do not confer any express or implied power of inspection on State Govt. - Such power arrogated by State Govt. on its own - Conditions so imposed are therefore ultra vires. 	(Para 21)

No illegality
HeadNote.description: Medical college - Permission for increased intake of students - Revocation for the academic year 2013-14 - Basis of CBI report regarding misconduct in academic year 2008-09 - No illegality - MCI need not wait till culmination of trial for initiating cancellation of permission - When investigation by premier agency like CBI has prima facie revealed that petitioner college had used fake and forged materials to get sanction in 2008-09, MCI can revoke the permission in accordance with Reg.8(3)(1)(d). heading: Competency of Income Tax Officer (Trust-cum-Estate Duty Circle)
HeadNote.description: Competency of Income Tax Officer (Trust-cum-Estate Duty Circle) - For making assessment under Estate Duty Act - They are appointed by Central Board of Direct Taxes by issuing notification dated 03.05.1976 - However, law does not empower Board to appoint such Controllers - Such power is given to Central Govt. - Therefore, Income Tax Officers appointed by Board are not competent to make assessment under Estate Duty Act. (Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Prosecution for possession of contraband and liquor - Delay in sending sample to laboratory - It was only stated that sample was kept in police station godown - Nothing to show as to how and in what conditions articles were preserved and how safely they were taken to chemical examiners - Explanation that concerned Investigating Officer had passed away - Not acceptable - Prosecution could have examined any other witness associated with investigation to prove said aspect - Guilt of accused not proved beyond reasonable doubt - Acquittal proper. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Government Notification Dt.6/9/2004
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Government Notification Dt.6/9/2004 - Rebate on excise duty - Rejection, for non-production of ARE-1 forms as stipulated by Excise Manual and relevant Notification - Validity - Production of ARE-1 forms is procedural requirement to satisfy the authorities that goods have been exported and that the exported goods were of duty paid character - If the exporter can establish these two things by production of some other documents his claim for rebate can be maintained - Procedure under the Manual and Notification cannot be raised to the level of mandatory requirement.

The procedure which has been laid down in the notification dated 6 September 2004 and in CBEC's Manual of Supplementary Instructions of 2005 is to facilitate the processing of an application for rebate and to enable the authority to be duly satisfied that the two fold requirement of the goods having been exported and of the goods bearing a duty paid character is fulfilled. The procedure cannot be raised to the level of a mandatory requirement. Rule 18 itself makes a distinction between conditions and limitations on the one hand subject to which a rebate can be granted and the procedure governing the grant of a rebate on the other hand. While the conditions and limitations for the grant of rebate are mandatory, matters of procedure are directory.

1991 (55) ELT 437 (S.C.), 2009 (233) ELT 367, 2007 (217) ELT 264, 2003 (156) ELT 777 Rel. on.	 [Para 12,17]

heading: Murder by unlawful assembly
HeadNote.description: Murder by unlawful assembly - Accused persons by forming unlawful assembly alleged to have thrown country made bomb on deceased which resulted in his death - Case was based on testimony of eye-witnesses who were political rivals of accused - There were many contradictions in testimony of eye-witnesses - No reliance can be placed on their testimony - Some of important witnesses were not examined by prosecution without giving sufficient explanation - Daily diary report was also not proved or produced - There were deficiencies and contradiction in prosecution case - Accused entitled to be acquitted. heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Murder by unlawful assembly - Acquittal on ground that there was a free fight - Legality - Case of prosecution that accused persons holding lethal weapons came to house of deceased, threw bomb on him and assaulted others - Homicidal death of deceased and injuries of eye witnesses proved by medical evidence - Injured witnesses lent support to each other's version in all material particulars - Support also found from initial allegations in FIR - Minor discrepancies not making their testimony untrustworthy - Ample evidence on record prove that accused persons were aggressors - Two of accused were caught by villagers on spot and pelting of stone also took place resulting into injuries to accused - Finding of free fight on this count, erroneous - Appellant accused liable to be convicted u/Ss.302, 149 IPC - Reversal of his acquittal, proper.(Paras 17, 20, 27)

heading: Offence under
Acquittal for
Validity
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss. 120B, 121A, 420, 468, 471 - Evidence Act (1872), S. 27 - Offence under - Acquittal for - Validity - Allegation of making bomb blast against accused persons - explosion took place at distance of 400 meters from venue of Narkasur effigy competition - Explosion took place in scooter belonging to close relation of accused persons - Evidence on record that accused persons had close link with sanatan sanstha and this sanstha was protesting holding of any Narkasur effigy competition for period between 2001 to 2009 - However that itself not sufficient to prove offence against accused persons - Prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that arms or explosives or any other substances specified in S. 15 of Act of 1908 were recovered from possession of accused persons and they were used in commission of such offence - Prosecution has also to prove that evidence of expert, finger prints of accused or any other definitive evidence suggesting involvement of accused in offence were found at site of offence or on anything including arms and vehicles used in connection with commission of such offence - Only if these matters are proved beyond reasonable doubt by prosecution, court shall presume, unless contrary is shown that accused had committed such offence - Prosecution failed to prove any of these circumstances beyond reasonable doubt - Further no consent from District Magistrate was obtained for proceeding against accused under Act (1908) - No trial warranted against accused persons for offences under Act (1908) - Acquittal of accused, proper. (Paras 64, 66, 68, 72, 74)

headline:
Explosive Substances Act (1908), Ss. 3, 4, 5, 15, 7 – Offence under – Acquittal – Prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that arms or explosives or any other substances specified in S. 15 of Act of 1908 were recovered from possession of accused persons and they were used in commission of such offence – Prosecution has also to prove that evidence of expert, finger prints of accused or any other definitive evidence suggesting involvement of accused in offence were found at site of offence or on anything including arms and vehicles used in connection with commission of such offence – Only if these matters are proved beyond reasonable doubt by prosecution, court shall presume, unless contrary is shown that accused had committed such offence – Prosecution failed to prove any of these circumstances beyond reasonable doubt – Acquittal of accused, proper. 

2) Criminal P.C. (1973), S. 154 – Veracity of FIR – Doubt upon – Validity – FIR lodged against accused persons due to an explosion took place at distance of 400 meters from venue of Narkasur effigy competition – Explosion took place in scooter belonging to close relation of accused persons – Evidence on record that accused persons had close link with sanatan sanstha and this sanstha was protesting holding of any Narkasur effigy competition for period between 2001 to 2009 – Material on record may be not sufficient to convict accused persons – However material on record certainly not sufficient to doubt veracity of FIR – Observation regarding doubt upon veracity of FIR liable to be set aside.

heading: Arms Act (1959), Ss.3, 5 r/w. S.25
HeadNote.description:
Arms Act (1959), Ss.3, 5 r/w. S.25 - Evidence Act (1872), S.3 - Possession of fire arms - Possession means possession with requisite mental element, that is, conscious possession and not mere custody without the awareness of nature of such possession - Suspicion however strong, cannot take the place of proof beyond reasonable doubt.

In the case at hand, as the prosecution belatedly realized, the house did not belong to the accused but belonged to his mother in which three more adult persons were residing, namely the accused, his wife and also the sister as reflected on the electoral roll later produced on behalf of the prosecution.  The only evidence led by the prosecution to support its case that the accused was in possession of the said arms, ammunitions or explosives is the fact that the accused opened the door of the said room when directed to do by the raiding party.  That the house of the accused was searched, is a story PSI Dessai had to give up when the Mamlatdar informed him that the house stood in the name of the mother of the accused.  Prosecution produced no evidence that the room which was searched was in exclusive possession of the accused.  The house appears to have been in joint occupation of 4 adult members of the family, including that of the accused.  No doubt, the accused is a mechanic and only male member found in the said house and this would raise a strong suspicion against him that he was in possession of the articles but suspicion however strong cannot take the place of proof beyond reasonable doubt.  The house, admittedly, was in joint occupation of the aforesaid persons and in case the prosecution wanted to nail the accused with the exclusive possession of the said articles found in the said room something more was required to be done to prove that the accused was in exclusive and conscious possession of the said articles in the said room.  Prosecution has failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the said articles found in the said room were in exclusive and conscious possession of the accused and on that count the accused certainly deserves to be given benefit of doubt.  AIR 1972 SC 1899 and (1994)5 SCC 410 - Rel.on.   [Para 16]

Punishment for making or possessing explosives -  - No evidence to prove that accused was in conscious possession or actual control of any explosive substance - Merely because accused had sustained injuries on account of blast of explosive substance - It cannot be concluded that he was in actual possession of said explosive substance - Articles viz. white powder, match box, thread bundle and grey scrapping recovered from spot - Though could constitute ingredients of low explosives (throw down type country made bomb) - But cannot give rise to reasonable suspicion as required by S.5 - Accused entitled to benefit of doubt. 	(Paras 14, 18, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Sanction to prosecute
No interference
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.136 - Sanction to prosecute - Prosecution case that explosion took place in appellant's shop causing death of 14 persons and injuries to several persons - Sessions Judge earlier discharged appellant because there was no sanction - But prosecution subsequently obtained sanction which was accepted by Sessions Judge and affirmed by impugned order passed by High Court - No interference - Trial Court directed to frame additional charges against appellant under Ss.3, 4, 5 and 6 of the Act and to proceed with trial. 

In the present case, the explosion which took place in the appellant's shop resulted in death of 14 persons. Several persons were severely injured. Seriousness of the occurrence can hardly be disputed.At no stage, sanction was refused by the competent authority. It is not the case of the appellant that sanction is granted by the authority, which is not competent. It is true that the proceedings are sought to be initiated under the said Act against the appellant after three years. But, in the facts of this case, where 14 innocent persons lost their lives and several persons were severely injured due to the blast which took place in the appellant's shop, three years period cannot be termed as delay. It is also the duty of the court to see that perpetrators of crime are tried and convicted if offences are proved against them. The plea of appellant that the lapse of three years has caused prejudice to the accused. The case will be conducted in accordance with the law and the appellant will have enough opportunity to prove his innocence. Besides, equally dear to us are the victim's rights. Although the Sessions Judge discharged the appellant of the charges under Sections 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the said Act because there was no sanction. But, the prosecution has now obtained sanction. The Sessions Judge has accepted the sanction and has directed that the trial should be started against the appellant for offences under Sections 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the said Act, as well. The order of the Sessions Judge is affirmed by the impugned order passed by the High Court.Supreme Court has no reason to interfere in the matter and trial Court directed to frame additional charges against the appellant under Sections 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the said Act and to proceed with the trial.  [Para 13,14]

heading: Consent for prosecution
HeadNote.description: Consent for prosecution - Authority of District Magistrate to give consent - There can be delegation by Central Govt. to the District Magistrates - Consent granted by District Magistrate cannot be treated as vitiated - Further, examination of District Magistrate to prove his consent is not necessary when the same has been proven by competent person. heading: Conviction
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Possession of ammonium nitrate - Conviction - Challenge - Ground that ammonium nitrate not being an explosive substance, mere possession by accused is no offence - Evidence on record show that apart from large quantity of ammonium nitrate, fuse wire, empty boxes and other materials were also seized - As per expert evidence, said combination was sufficient to prepare bomb - Possession of these articles in large quantity indicates it was conscious and intended to be used for blast - No interference with conviction.			(Paras 64, 65)

Restrictions on trial
HeadNote.description: Extradition - Restrictions on trial - Extradition of appellant allowed for trial of offenses punishable under the 1908 Act - Prosecution, conviction and sentence for offences punishable under Explosive Substances Act cannot be said to be without jurisdiction or in excess of authority of law. heading: Search and seizure
Explosive material recovered

heading: Punishment for
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.31 - Possession of explosive substances - Punishment for - Accused persons found in possession of explosive substances in criminal conspiracy with each other - Evidence showing that accused persons along with absconding/missing accused are from poor strata of society - Evidence of fathers of missing accused that those accused though had sacred higher education but were jobless - In circumstances, there is no need to direct sentences to run consecutively - Accused persons in custody for about six years sentenced to period already undergone by them. 	(Para 62)

heading: Not proper
HeadNote.description: Explosion of explosive substance - Trial for offences under Act - Restriction imposed in terms of provisions of S.7, considering punishment prescribed, to extent of imprisonment for life - Interpreting S.7 by referring S.9 of Explosives Act 1884 - Not proper - Obtaining consent of District Magistrate for trial of offences under Act - Is mandatory in nature and not directory. (Paras 20, 29)

heading: Circumstantial evidence
HeadNote.description: Explosion of explosive substance - Trial for offences under Act - Circumstantial evidence - Blast in house of bus conductor - Appellant, accused allegedly planted explosive in box in bus containing radio and also one receipt of mobile purchased in name of “G”, member of Scheduled Caste, as he wanted to take revenge against him - No evidence to prove the same - Evidence of mobile shop owner and his employee claiming to have identified appellant as person, who had purchased said mobile in name of “G”, not reliable - No identification parade held - Statement of appellant recorded in panchnama, in form of confession, while in custody, hit by Ss.25 and 26 of Evidence Act and not admissible - Evidence of radio shop owner not supported prosecution case - Prosecution thus failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that appellant purchased mobile handset and radio from alleged shops - No evidence to show technical expertise of appellant to convert radio by connecting certain wiring to such an extent that after insertion of battery cells there would be an explosion of radio containing Gelatine - No disclosure statement made by Appellant accused voluntarily while in police custody - Scanty evidence produced by prosecution to show motive on part of appellant to use explosive for blast of radio to take revenge against “G” - Prosecution, therefore failed to complete chain of circumstantial evidence - Accused, held entitled to acquittal for offences u/S.338 IPC and S.3 Explosive Substances Act 1908 - Similarly on basis of scanty evidence “G”, conviction of accused u/S.3(2)(ii) of Atrocities Act, also liable to be quashed and set aside. (Paras 35, 37 to 46)

heading: Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Possession of explosive substance - Evidence and proof - Accused persons, members of Students Islamic Movement of India (SIMI) found in possession of explosive substances - No evidence showing that said explosive substance were of nature likely to endanger life - Offence under S.4 not made out - However, conviction of accused persons for offence punishable under S.5 is proper. 	(Para 59)

heading: Bail
Bail rejected
HeadNote.description: Bail - Recovery of explosive substances - Accused in jail for period exceeding one year - Statements under Section 164 Cr. P.C. revealed involvement of accused in the procurement of illegal explosive substances and of their use in his quarrying activities - Prima facie material available to establish involvement of petitioners in activities violating provisions of the Explosive Substances Act - Consequences of such violation are extremely serious - Some of the accused are still absconding - Releasing accused from jail at the said juncture, when prosecution has not even commenced to examine the main witnesses, could prove detrimental to the eventual outcome of  trial - Atleast till the culmination of evidence of material witnesses, it is not proper to order the release of petitioners on bail - Bail rejected - It shall be open to the petitioners to move a fresh application for bail, after the examination of all the material witnesses. (Paras 12, 16)

heading: Bail
Application for
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Arms Act (1959), Ss.5, 28 - Maharashtra Police Act (1951), S.135 - Bail - Application for - Applicants found in possession of explosives - Statements of naxalities who surrendered before law that applicants are die hard supporters of naxal movements - Contention raised that applicants are residents of internal parts of forests where naxalities regularly visit, therefore, they had no other option except to extend active help to naxalities in view of their threats - Not acceptable - Merely because challan is presented that by itself cannot be ground for granting bail - Bail declined. 	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Cognizance of offence under TADA
HeadNote.description: Cognizance of offence under TADA - Sanction of Competent Authority not obtained - In view of the fact that the Designated Court could not try the offence under TADA being debarred from taking cognizance thereof on account of want of sanction by the competent authority under the mandatory provisions of Section 20-A(2), it could not try any offence under any other Act as well - Hence, Designated Court could have tried and convicted the appellant under Explosive Substances Act. (1997)7 SCC 744 - Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Cognizance of offence
HeadNote.description:
Arms Act (1959), Ss.7, 25(1A) - Cognizance of offence - Conviction of accused is vitiated on account of non-compliance of mandatory requirement of prior approval under S.20A(1) of Act - Confessions recorded under Act cannot be looked into to establish guilt under Arms Act and Explosive Substances Act - Conviction and sentence of accused under other penal provisions also illegal and unsustainable.

In the present case the accused persons besides being held guilty under Section 3 and 5 of TADA, have also been found guilty under Section 7 and 25(1A) of the Arms Act and Section 4, 5 and 6 of the Explosive Substances Act. It is relevant here to state that the Designated Court, besides trying the case under TADA, can also try any other offence with which the accused may be charged at the same trial if the offence is connected with the offence under TADA. When the Designated Court had the power to try offences under TADA as well as other offences, it is implicit that it has the power to convict also and that conviction is permissible to be ordered under TADA or other penal laws or both.

The conviction of the accused to have been vitiated on account of non-compliance of Section 20-A(1) of TADA and thus, it may be permissible in law to maintain the conviction under the Arms Act and the Explosive Substances Act but that shall only be possible when there are legally admissible evidence to establish those charges. The Designated Court has only relied on the confessions recorded under TADA to convict the accused for offences under the Arms Act and the Explosive Substances Act. In view of finding that their conviction is vitiated on account of non-compliance of the mandatory requirement of prior approval under Section 20-A(1) of TADA, the confessions recorded cannot be looked into to establish the guilt under the aforesaid Acts. Hence, the conviction of the accused under Section 7 and 25(1A) of the Arms Act and Section 4, 5 and 6 of the Explosive Substances Act cannot also be allowed to stand. [Para 38,40]

heading: Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Illegal possession of arms and ammunition - Appeal against conviction - Allegedly, 18 cartridges, gun and some naxal literature was recovered from appellant - Lot of inconsistencies in evidence of eye-witnesses - Some of them stated about recovery of explosives while others did not - One witness specifically mentioned that gelatin was seized - However, Sub-Divisional Police Officer did not indicate as to what articles and in what quantity were seized - Two members of police party who caught appellant stated that appellant was in civil dress - Naib Tahsildar, who had conducted identification parade had not given any details about it - Chemical Analysis report is favourable to prosecution - But seizure itself is found to be highly questionable - Hence, plea of implication of accused in false case cannot be denied - Appellant acquitted.  (Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description:
Conviction u/S.304 Part I r/w S.149 - For causing death of one and injuries to others - Legality - Case of prosecution that appellants firstly assaulted a victim on road who was rescued by his family members - While they were returning home, appellants hurled bomb from rear side which resulted in death of one and injuries to others - No major discrepancy in prosecution witnesses as to manner of assault - Conduct of appellants in assembling together with lethal weapons, indicative of their common object to assault victim family - However, considering that deceased was not specific target and bomb was hurled randomly, conviction cannot be u/S.304 Part I r/w S.149 - Modified to S.304 Part II r/w S.149. 
(2001) SCC 621, 2019 ALL MR (Cri) 5286 (S.C.), 2006 ALL MR (Cri) 1172 (S.C.), (2002) 3 SCC 327, 2019 ALL SCR (Cri) 972 Disting. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Murder
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Murder - Evidence and proof - Prosecution case that accused in course of altercation went to his house, came back and threw a bomb which hit deceased resulting into his death - Evidence of witnesses truthful and corroborated with each other - No contradiction or discrepancy of any material nature in statement of witnesses - Delay in lodging FIR stands fully explained by statement of witnesses - Conviction of accused is proper. (Paras 24 to 26)

heading: Possession of 180 detonators without licence
HeadNote.description: Possession of 180 detonators without licence - Detonators were of a company in Orissa and were seized at a far away place like Surat - Controller of Explosives report disclosing that they were explosives falling under class 2 & 6 of Sch.I - Plea that they were meant for digging wells was not tenable in view of the large quantity seized - Accused also tried to run away when apprehended by police - Custodial sentence and fine imposed upheld.	(Para 9)

heading: Arms Act (1959), Ss.3, 5 r/w. S.25
HeadNote.description:
Arms Act (1959), Ss.3, 5 r/w. S.25 - Evidence Act (1872), S.3 - Possession of fire arms - Possession means possession with requisite mental element, that is, conscious possession and not mere custody without the awareness of nature of such possession - Suspicion however strong, cannot take the place of proof beyond reasonable doubt.

In the case at hand, as the prosecution belatedly realized, the house did not belong to the accused but belonged to his mother in which three more adult persons were residing, namely the accused, his wife and also the sister as reflected on the electoral roll later produced on behalf of the prosecution.  The only evidence led by the prosecution to support its case that the accused was in possession of the said arms, ammunitions or explosives is the fact that the accused opened the door of the said room when directed to do by the raiding party.  That the house of the accused was searched, is a story PSI Dessai had to give up when the Mamlatdar informed him that the house stood in the name of the mother of the accused.  Prosecution produced no evidence that the room which was searched was in exclusive possession of the accused.  The house appears to have been in joint occupation of 4 adult members of the family, including that of the accused.  No doubt, the accused is a mechanic and only male member found in the said house and this would raise a strong suspicion against him that he was in possession of the articles but suspicion however strong cannot take the place of proof beyond reasonable doubt.  The house, admittedly, was in joint occupation of the aforesaid persons and in case the prosecution wanted to nail the accused with the exclusive possession of the said articles found in the said room something more was required to be done to prove that the accused was in exclusive and conscious possession of the said articles in the said room.  Prosecution has failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the said articles found in the said room were in exclusive and conscious possession of the accused and on that count the accused certainly deserves to be given benefit of doubt.  AIR 1972 SC 1899 and (1994)5 SCC 410 - Rel.on.   [Para 16]

heading: Appeal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Against order granting explosives licence - Maintainability - As per provisions of S.6F of Explosives Act and R.121 of the Rules appeal can be filed only by person who is aggrieved by order of licensing authority either refusing to grant licence or varying condition of licence or suspending licence - Appellant was not applicant for licence under provisions of Act - Appellant not aggrieved by either refusal to grant licence or suspension or revocation thereof or varying of conditions of licence granted in his favour - Appellant not an aggrieved person within meaning of S.6F and R.121 of Rules - Appeal filed by appellant not maintainable. 	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Conviction
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Possession of ammonium nitrate - Conviction - Challenge - Ground that ammonium nitrate not being an explosive substance, mere possession by accused is no offence - Evidence on record show that apart from large quantity of ammonium nitrate, fuse wire, empty boxes and other materials were also seized - As per expert evidence, said combination was sufficient to prepare bomb - Possession of these articles in large quantity indicates it was conscious and intended to be used for blast - No interference with conviction.			(Paras 64, 65)

heading: Consent for prosecution
HeadNote.description: Consent for prosecution - Consent obtained after commencement of trial but before completion of the same - Consent was not ex post facto consent - Consent though delayed, was not barred - Trial, therefore, not vitiated.	(Para 41)

heading: LPG gas bottling plant
HeadNote.description:
LPG gas bottling plant - Categorization of activity as Commercial or Manufacturing for levying electricity rate accordingly - Neither CGRF nor Ombudsman have considered provision of Explosives Act and Gas Cylinder Rules - Judgment relied by petitioner was not considered by Electricity Ombudsman - Said judgment makes it clear that activity of Gas bottling plant is manufacturing activity - Matter liable to be remanded to Electricity Ombudsman to decide categorization of activity conducted by petitioner. 
AIR 1992 Guj. 237 Rel.on.  (Paras 21, 22)

heading: Not proper
HeadNote.description: Explosion of explosive substance - Trial for offences under Act - Restriction imposed in terms of provisions of S.7, considering punishment prescribed, to extent of imprisonment for life - Interpreting S.7 by referring S.9 of Explosives Act 1884 - Not proper - Obtaining consent of District Magistrate for trial of offences under Act - Is mandatory in nature and not directory. (Paras 20, 29)

heading: Appeal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Against order granting explosives licence - Maintainability - As per provisions of S.6F of Explosives Act and R.121 of the Rules appeal can be filed only by person who is aggrieved by order of licensing authority either refusing to grant licence or varying condition of licence or suspending licence - Appellant was not applicant for licence under provisions of Act - Appellant not aggrieved by either refusal to grant licence or suspension or revocation thereof or varying of conditions of licence granted in his favour - Appellant not an aggrieved person within meaning of S.6F and R.121 of Rules - Appeal filed by appellant not maintainable. 	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Appointment
HeadNote.description: Appointment - Post of Laboratory Assistant Grade-II in Export Inspection Council of India - Claim for appointment under General category - R.9 of Export Inspection Agency (Recruitment) Rules and proceedings issued by Department of Personnel and Training laid down stipulation to be followed for recruitment to posts under Central Government - R.9 and proceedings expressly bar candidates belonging to SC/ST/OBC who have availed age relaxation for being considered for appointment on post of General category candidates - Appellant-candidate has applied under OBC category by availing age relaxation - She has also attended interview under OBC category - Also appellant-candidate has not challenged constitutional validity of R.9 as well as proceedings - Cannot claim appointment under General category. 2010 ALL SCR 1057 Disting.  (Paras 7, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Extra Departmental Assistant (Conduct and Service) Rules (1964)
heading: Misconduct
HeadNote.description: Misconduct - Allegation against respondent Branch Post Master as to illegal withdrawal of depositors' money - Enquiry Officer found charges not proved against respondent - However, Disciplinary Authority disagreed with findings of Enquiry Officer - Though delay caused in furnishing disagreement note to respondent, no complaint of any prejudice made - Even if personal hearing not given, respondent was given opportunity to make representation in respect to disagreement note - Principles of natural justice, not violated - Statement of depositors as also confessional statement of respondent were duly recorded and supplied to respondent - Disciplinary Authority was well within its right to disagree with Enquiry Report wherein material on record were not properly appreciated - Order of removal from service was justified - Order of reinstatement, liable to be set aside.  	(Paras 21, 24, 25, 27, 28, 29)

heading: Request for extradition
HeadNote.description:
Request for extradition - Must undergo strict scrutiny test.

When a proceeding under the Act is initiated, the civil liberty of a person would be directly affected. The provisions of the Act, therefore, should be strictly construed. Any request for extradition therefore must undergo the strict scrutiny test. Extradition offence keeping in view its definition in Section 2(c) of the Act in relation to a treaty State must be one provided for the extradition treaty therewith.   [Para 47]

heading: Request for extradition
Procedure
HeadNote.description: Request for extradition - Procedure - Requirements are specific and imperative in character.	(Para 48)

heading: Extradition Treaty is subject to provisions of the Act
HeadNote.description: Extradition Treaty is subject to provisions of the Act - Red Corner notice by itself cannot be a basis of arrest or transfer of Indian Citizen to foreign jurisdiction.			(Para 53)

heading: Red Corner Notice
HeadNote.description:
Red Corner Notice - Consequences of.

A Red Corner Notice has large number of consequences, some of which are:

(i)	The requesting country may make a deportation request.

(ii)	The law enforcement agency in India is required to "take follow up action with regard to the arrest of a fugitive criminal".

(iii)	The information emanating from the red corner notice is required to be distributed all over the Interpol website.

(iv)	The requesting Embassy would instruct the CBI to carry out its instructions for surveillance, arrest and detention.

(v)	The requesting Embassy can even contact the Indian police directly.

(vi)	Thereafter extradition proceedings may follow.   [Para 46]

heading: Arrest of person for offence in a foreign jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Arrest of person for offence in a foreign jurisdiction - When can be effected.

A person wanted for an offence in a foreign jurisdiction may be arrested on fulfillment of the following conditions:

(i)	That the offence should be counted as one by Indian Law as well, and

(ii)	The person must be liable to be arrested in India - either under any law relating to extradition, or otherwise.

Such an arrest can be effected only pursuant to a warrant issued by the Magistrate in view of Sections 6, 16 and 34-B of the Act or an arrest warrant issued by a foreign country and endorsed by the Central Government under Section 15 of the Act. It is also not in doubt or dispute that in a case where there is no treaty, it is only the Magistrate who issues the warrant for arrest subject of course to the condition that the Central Government had ordered a Magisterial Inquiry in terms of Section 5 of the Act.   [Para 54,55]

heading: Provisional arrest
HeadNote.description:
Provisional arrest - In terms of Art.12 of Extradition Treaty - Must satisfy requirements of S.34-B.

When a request for provisional arrest in terms of Article 12 is communicated, it must satisfy the requirement of Section 34-B of the Act. Such request from a foreign country must be accompanied by the requisite documents and not a communication from INTERPOL alone. An arrest can be effected at the instance of the Central Government only when such a request is made by the foreign country and not otherwise.   [Para 56]

heading:
Act and Extradition Treaty is subject to municipal law.

The Act as also the treaties entered into by and between India and foreign countries are admittedly subject to our municipal law. Enforcement of a treaty is in the hands of the Executive. But such enforcement must conform to the domestic law of the country. Whenever, it is well known, a conflict arises between a treaty and the domestic law or a municipal law, the latter shall prevail. [Para 59]

Act and Extradition Treaty is subject to municipal law.

The Act as also the treaties entered into by and between India and foreign countries are admittedly subject to our municipal law. Enforcement of a treaty is in the hands of the Executive. But such enforcement must conform to the domestic law of the country. Whenever, it is well known, a conflict arises between a treaty and the domestic law or a municipal law, the latter shall prevail. [Para 59]

heading: Extraditable offence
HeadNote.description:
Extraditable offence - Matrimonial dispute does not constitute extraditable offence.

Matrimonial dispute as such does not constitute an extraditable offence and, thus, no effect could be given thereto. However, whether case concerns an extraditable offence or not has to be determined by the Magistrate under the Act.   [Para 60]

heading: Red Corner Notice
HeadNote.description: Red Corner Notice - Kidnapping of child in case of matrimonial dispute per se is not considered an extraditable offence.			(Para 143)

heading: Release of persons arrested on bail
HeadNote.description: Release of persons arrested on bail - Scope and applicability of S.25 - S.25 applies only to a fugitive criminal.	(Para 13)

heading: Discharge of accused
Fugitive criminal
Powers of Magistrate
HeadNote.description:
Discharge of accused - Fugitive criminal - Powers of Magistrate - While dealing with a fugitive criminal wanted in a State with which India has no treaty, the Magistrate can inquire into the case in the same manner as if the case was triable by Court of Sessions or High Court - However, while dealing with a fugitive criminal wanted in a treaty State, such inquiry and such a trial is not open - Held, there is no provision enabling the Magistrate to take evidence - He cannot discharge the fugitive criminal.

While dealing with a fugitive criminal wanted in a State with which India has no treaty, the Magistrate can inquire into the case in the same manner as if the case was triable by Court of Sessions or High Court, however, while dealing with a fugitive criminal wanted in a treaty State, such inquiry and such a trial is not open. There is no provision enabling the Magistrate to take evidence. He cannot discharge the fugitive criminal. He has to only see whether the warrant is duly authenticated and whether the fugitive criminal is concerned with an extradition offence. If these two conditions are satisfied, the Magistrate shall commit him to prison. The use of the word "shall" is significant. The Magistrate has then no option but to commit him to prison. He has to then submit the result of his inquiry to the Central Government together with written statement which the fugitive criminal may desire to submit for the consideration of the Central Government. The reason for this is obvious. Section 29 gives power to the Central Government to discharge any fugitive criminal. It states that if it appears to the Central Government that by reason of the trivial nature of the case or by reason of the application for surrender or return of a fugitive criminal not being made in good faith or in the interests of justice or for political reasons or otherwise, it is unjust or inexpedient to surrender or return the fugitive criminal, it may, by order, at any time stay any proceedings under this Act and direct any warrant issued or endorsed under the Extradition Act to be cancelled and the person for whose arrest the warrant has been issued or endorsed to be discharged.  [Para 17]

heading: Case of extradition of fugitive criminal from treaty States
HeadNote.description:
Case of extradition of fugitive criminal from treaty States - Magistrate cannot make a roving inquiry into facts - He has to only see whether the warrants are endorsed properly and whether the fugitive criminal is involved in an extradition offence - He cannot assume the role of a trial judge - The moment he is satisfied that the above two conditions are satisfied, he shall commit the fugitive criminal to custody.

In case of extradition of fugitive criminal from treaty States, the Magistrate cannot make a roving inquiry into facts. He has to only see whether the warrant is endorsed properly and whether the fugitive criminal is involved in an extradition offence. He cannot assume the role of a trial judge. The moment he is satisfied that the above two conditions are satisfied, he shall commit the fugitive criminal to custody. The reason for such stringent provision is obvious. The Extradition Act recognizes the sanctity of an extradition treaty. Extradition treaty implies mutual obligations. It demands mutual respect for warrants or notices issued by States party to it. Since an extradition treaty falls within the domain of the Central Government as per the provisions of the Extradition Act, the ultimate authority to take vital decisions is left with it. Treaty obligations have to be respected. They are international obligations. Disrespect or disregard shown to warrants issued by a treaty State may result in similar response from that State to warrants issued by India. Such approach will result in frustrating the extradition treaty.						  [Para 18]

heading: Writ jurisdiction
Red Corner Notice
HeadNote.description:
Writ jurisdiction - Red Corner Notice - Notice plays a vital role in tracking, tracing and extraditing internationally wanted fugitives - It is issued to seek the provisional arrest and extradition of the fugitive on basis of valid arrest warrant - Held, it is not possible for the Court to stay warrants issued against the petitioner by American Courts - Red Corner Notice cannot be tinkered with.

Red Corner Notice is International Criminal Police Commission Notice (Interpol Notice). It plays a vital role in tracking, tracing and extraditing internationally wanted fugitives. It is issued to seek the provisional arrest and extradition of the fugitive on the basis of valid arrest warrant. It is not possible for High Court to stay warrants issued against the petitioner by the American Courts. Red Corner Notice cannot be tinkered with. The procedure prescribed under the law must be followed. Apart from the fact that warrants issued by American Courts and the Red Corner Notice cannot be stayed, Court would not like to set a precedent which could be used to hamper investigation of crimes which have global dimensions and for the investigation of which, Red Corner Notice is a critical tool.	 [Para 22]

heading: International law
Extradition Treaty
HeadNote.description:
International law - Extradition Treaty - Offences that can be tried - Contention that the Appellant has been convicted for the offences not mentioned in the Extradition Order, hence conviction illegal, without authority - Held, if the accused is charged for a higher offence and on the evidence, the Court finds that the accused has not committed that offence but is equally satisfied that he has committed a lesser offence, then he can be convicted for such lesser offence - The same principle applies to extradition cases.

Section 365, IPC had not been mentioned but Section 364-A, IPC had been included in the order of extradition. It is well-settled that if the accused is charged for a higher offence and on the evidence led by the prosecution, the Court finds that the accused has not committed that offence but is equally satisfied that he has committed a lesser offence, then he can be convicted for such lesser offence. The same principle applies to extradition cases. The principles of administration of criminal justice applied to Domestic/Municipal Law has also been extended to International Law or Law of Nations and to cases covered by Extradition-Treaties. It cannot be disputed that an offence under Section 365 is a lesser offence than the offence punishable under Section 364-A. Since extradition of appellant was allowed for a crime punishable with higher offence, her prosecution and trial for a lesser offence cannot be held to be without authority of law.						 [Para 28,29,30,32,34]

heading: Extradition
Restrictions on trial
HeadNote.description: Extradition - Restrictions on trial - Extradition of appellant allowed for trial of offenses punishable under the 1908 Act - Prosecution, conviction and sentence for offences punishable under Explosive Substances Act cannot be said to be without jurisdiction or in excess of authority of law.		(Paras 13, 14, 16)

heading: Extradition treaty
Existence
HeadNote.description: Extradition treaty - Existence - Treaty entered between Great Britain, Ireland and Republic of Chile on 26/01/1897 - India was in "British possession" at that time - By virtue of Indian Independence (International Arrangements) Order, 1947 all international agreements continued in independent India - Hence, said treaty can be said to exist even today between India and Chile - Existence also supported by Parliamentary proceedings in 1956 wherein list of pre-independence treaties including said treaty of 1897 was tabled by the then Prime Minister as treaties in force - Other materials such as Parliamentary Debate on Extradition Bill in 1962, Document prepared by Secretariat of International Law Commission and Consular Manual issued by Ministry of External Affairs also support existence of 1897 treaty between India and Chile - Mode of termination as contemplated in treaty, never resorted to by India - On the contrary, by virtue of statutory recognition u/S.2(d) and Govt. notification u/S.3(1) in respect of Chile, existence of treaty acknowledged.  (Paras 89, 90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95, 105, 106, 107, 109)

heading: Extradition treaties
HeadNote.description: Extradition treaties - Scope and extent of judicial review - No crystallized ruling of courts as regards the extent to which judicial intervention is permissible - However, certainly, there cannot be complete judicial abstinence.

heading: Provisional arrest of a fugitive criminal
HeadNote.description: Provisional arrest of a fugitive criminal - Is subject to the condition that request for extradition made by foreign State - Issuance of "Red Notice" not a condition precedent - Absence of Red Notice does not preclude Govt. of India from arresting a fugitive criminal and producing him before Magistrate in accordance with law.

heading: Provisional arrest of a fugitive criminal
HeadNote.description: Provisional arrest of a fugitive criminal - Request to be made by foreign State - Request of representative or Embassy of foreign State, whether acceptable - Held, in view of definition of foreign state u/S.2(e), request made by Embassy is as good as request of foreign State itself. (Para 123)

heading: Request for extradition
HeadNote.description: Request for extradition - Primary consideration is assurance of reciprocity - Even in the absence of extradition treaty between two countries, fugitive criminal can be extradited on reciprocal basis. 2011 ALL MR (Cri) 251 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 127, 128, 129)

heading: Notification u/S.3(1)
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Notification u/S.3(1) - For applying the Extradition Act to Republic of Chile - Objection as to non-application of mind - Not acceptable - No suggestion by petitioner as to what particular procedure was required to be followed by Govt. of India except issuance of notification u/S.3(1) - When such a notification was issued, natural presumption is that this official act was done after due application of mind - In any case, whether to apply Extradition Act to a particular country or not, is entirely a political question - Not a subject of judicial review. 	(Para 130)

heading: No illegality
HeadNote.description: Arrest of fugitive criminal - Set aside by HC on ground that notification u/S.3(1) was not issued in respect of Republic of Chile - However, liberty given for initiating the process of extradition once again - No illegality - It is for Republic of Chile to decide whether it would like to renew its request - If Govt. of India chooses to act upon renewed request, that is its political and diplomatic decision - Petitioner has no say in the matter.  (Para 131)

heading: Doctrine of Speciality
HeadNote.description: Restriction on trial of person extradited - Provision of S.21 recognizes doctrine of Speciality - Doctrine of Speciality is a universally recognized principle of international law and partakes of doctrines of both double criminality and reciprocity - Doctrine of Speciality - Explained.			 (Paras 24, 25)

heading: Term "lesser offence"
Interpretation of
HeadNote.description:
Term "lesser offence" - Interpretation of - Lesser offence cannot be equated with term 'minor offence' as mentioned in S.222, Cr.P.C. - Punishment provided for the offence is relevant and not the ingredients for the purposes of interpretation of the term "lesser offence".

"Lesser offence" in S.21(b) of the Act means an offence which is made out from the proved facts and provides lesser punishment, as compared to the offences for which the fugitive has been extradited. The offence has to be an extradition offence, as defined under Section 2(c)(ii) of the Act i.e. an offence punishable with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year under the laws of India or of a foreign State. The lesser offence cannot be equated with the term "minor offence" as mentioned in Section 222 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The Legislature has deliberately used the word "lesser" in Section 21(b) of the Extradition Act instead of the word "minor". Thus, the punishment provided for the offence is relevant and not the ingredients for the purposes of interpretation of the term "lesser offence".  [Para 29]

heading: Restriction on trial of person extradited
HeadNote.description:
Restriction on trial of person extradited - Accused can be tried for offences for which he has been extradited - He can also be tried for lesser offence/offences in view of S.21 disclosed by facts proved for purposes of securing his surrender.

It is true that there is no Extradition Treaty between India and Portugal. However, the laws of both the countries permit entertaining request for extradition from Non Treaty States also. The extradition request was made to the Government of Portugal by the Government of India under the provisions of the Extradition Act applicable to Non Treaty States i.e. Section 19 of the Act. Although the Convention was also relied upon for the extradition, as rightly pointed out by the respondent, it was not the sole basis as is apparent from the Letter of Request. The primary consideration for the request of extradition was the assurance of reciprocity. The notification dated 13.12.2002 by the Government of India directing that the provisions contained in the Extradition Act shall be applicable to the Republic of Portugal was issued keeping in view the said principle of reciprocity. For the purpose of extradition proceedings, appellant was treated as a fugitive criminal as defined under S.2(f) of the Act. In view of notification dated 13-12-2002 it is clear that the provisions of Extradition Act shall apply to Portuguese Republic in accordance with the principle of reciprocity. The provisions of the Act are applicable in respect of the extradition of appellant. The Court of Appeals of Lisbon has recognized this principle of reciprocity and the applicability of the provisions of the Extradition Act, 1962 to the Republic of Portugal. The Supreme Court of Justice and Constitutional Court of Portugal have also approved it. None of these Courts have mentioned in their orders that the accused could not be tried in India for the offences for which his trial could take place as per the domestic laws of India. A bare reading of S.21 of the Act would indicate that accused can be tried for the offences for which he has been extradited. The Supreme Court of Justice, Portugal has granted extradition of appellant for all the offences mentioned in para-1 of the order dated 27-01-2005. In addition, can also be tried for lesser offence/offences in view of Section 21 of the Extradition Act disclosed by the facts proved for the purposes of securing his surrender. The contention of the appellant that he can be tried only for the offences covered under Article 2(1) of the said Convention is misconceived in view of the fact that he was extradited not only under the said Convention but also in the light of the principle of reciprocity made applicable through the application of the Extradition Act to the Republic of Portugal. A complete reading of Article 2 of the said Convention makes it clear that it deals not only with those accused who commit the substantive offences as defined in Article 2(1) but also includes all the conspirators and those who have constructive liability for commission of the substantive offences as per Sub-section 3 of Article 2 of the Convention, which fact has also been mentioned by the Supreme Court of Justice, Portugal in para 9.4 of its order. The Court of Appeals in Lisbon, has recognized this principle of reciprocity and the applicability of the provisions of Extradition Act to Portugal. The Supreme Court of Justice and Constitutional Court of Portugal have also approved it. In view of the fact that the provisions of the Extradition Act, 1962 have been made applicable to Portugal, provisions contained in Section 21 of the Act would come into operation while conducting the trial of appellant. Thus can be tried for 'lesser offences', even if, the same are not covered by the Extradition Decree since the same is permitted under Section 21(b) of the Extradition Act. No bar has been placed by the Portuguese Courts for the trial of lesser offences in accordance with the provisions contained under Section 21(b) of the Extradition Act although Portuguese Courts were aware of the said provisions of Extradition Act. In the instant case the extradition has been allowed by the requested State on the specific undertaking of the Government of India that the extradited criminal will not be subjected to death penalty or imprisonment beyond 25 years. Therefore, the basic human rights considerations have been taken into account. Thus, primacy has been accorded to human right norms in the extradition process.  [Para 28,32,59]

heading: Extradition
HeadNote.description:
Extradition to fugitive criminals - Extradition - Distinguished from deportation and exclusion.

Extradition has been evolved by way of International treaty obligation which ensures a mode of formal surrender of an accused by the one country to another based on reciprocal arrangements. But extradition is different from deportation by which competent State authorities order a person to leave a country and prevent him from returning to the same territory. Extradition is also different from exclusion, by which an individual is prohibited from staying in one part of a Sovereign State. As a result of such orders, sometimes deserters or absentees from Armed Forces of a particular country are returned to the custody of Armed Forces of the country to which they belong. Both deportation and exclusion basically are non-consensual exercise whereas extradition is based on a consensual treaty obligation between the requesting State and the requested State. Extradition, however, is only to be resorted to in cases of serious offences. [Para 40,43,44]

heading: Ingredients
HeadNote.description: Extradition to fugitive criminals - Ingredients - Doctrinally speaking, Extradition has five substantive ingredients - They are : (a) reciprocity, (b) double criminality, (c) extraditable offences, (d) specialty and (e) non inquiry. 	 (Para 60)

heading: Extradition
HeadNote.description:
Extradition - Power of Sessions Court u/s.439 to issue any direction regarding extradition - Extradition is not mechanically made only on the basis of requisition coming from the Government of India - In any event while exercising power under S.439 of Criminal P.C.; the Sessions Court has no jurisdiction to issue such a direction.

Extradition is not mechanically made only on the basis of requisition coming from the Government of India. The warrant of arrest received from India is required to be forwarded by the Minister of Justice of Kingdom of Belgium to the proper Judicial Authority. It provides that the foreigner may claim to be provisionally set at liberty in any case in which a Belgian enjoys that right, and under same conditions. Before completion of procedure of extradition, hearing has been contemplated under the Agreement. The material placed before the learned Additional Sessions Judge showed that the procedure has been initiated in India for seeking extradition of the first Respondent under section 19 of the Extradition Act of 1962. The learned Additional Sessions Judge could not have directed the concerned officers to take action for bringing back the first Respondent to India and that also after his release on bail. After a requisition for extradition was submitted by the Government of India, it was for the authorities in the Kingdom of Belgium to take appropriate decision. Therefore, such a direction was uncalled for. In any event, while exercising power under section 439 of the Criminal P.C., the Sessions Court had no jurisdiction to issue such a direction.  [Para 15,16]

HeadNote.act_name: Maharashtra Sugar Factories (Reservation of Areas and Regulation of Crushing and Sugar Supply) Order (1984)
heading: Some sugarcane growing area reserved for factory
HeadNote.description:
Some sugarcane growing area reserved for factory - Failure by factory to harvest and crush sugarcane in its area - Sugarcane growers are entitled to compensation.

The sugarcane growers cannot supply their sugarcane to any other Karkhana other than the Karkhana for which the same area is reserved and clause 14 of the Reservation Order stipulated that any person who contravenes any of the provisions of the said Order or of the terms and conditions of a licence/permit shall be punishable under Section 7 of the Essential Commodities Act 1955.  It is thus clear that the sugarcane growers are not only estopped from exporting the sugarcane to some other Karkhana but they are liable to be prosecuted on account of such action.  In addition, clause 13 of the Reservation Order gives powers to the Director of Sugar or any officer authorised by him to require production of books of account, documents, inspection of record, to break open and search any place, to search, seize and remove and to take into custody the crop of sugarcane.  This power is wide enough to cast a duty on the director and his subordinates to ensure that the provisions of the Reservation Order are complied with by all the concerned.  It is, therefore, a legal or public duty cast on the sugar factory to harvest, lift and crush the sugarcane cultivated within its reserved area pursuant to the Zoning/Reservation Order passed by the State Government and the Director of Sugar and his subordinates are duty bound to ensure that the terms of the said order are strictly complied with by the parties concerned, namely, the sugar factory and sugarcane growers.  Thus in case of failure to harvest and crush sugarcane by the Karkhana in its reserved area the Karkhana is liable to pay compensation to the sugarcane grower.  That apart in the instant case, the High Court had directed the owners of Karkhana to give compensation to the sugarcane growers for failure to harvest and crush the sugarcane and the SLP filed by the Karkhana was allowed to be withdrawn and hence the Karkhana owners could not take plea that the High Court has no power to grant compensation.
